Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RVX-C1Y1-JC8X-63XK-00000-00Moet Big Tech worden opgesplitst?2018-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisEconomieBlz. 31Moet Big Tech worden opgesplitst?PETER DE WAARD

De kwestie

Een eeuw geleden was het in de VS een goede gewoonte om bedrijven die te machtig werden, te ontmantelen, zodat er weer concurrentie en eerlijke prijsvorming mogelijk was.

In 1911 werd op last van de overheid de superreus Standard Oil van de Rockefellers, die 90 procent van de oliemarkt beheerste, in liefst 33 stukjes gehakt. Ook American Tobacco en American Sugar werden op grond van de antitrustwetten opgeknipt. In 1982 werd nog de nationale telefoonmaatschappij AT&T - 'Ma Bell' - opgesplitst in zeven regionale telefoonmaatschappijen, de zogenoemde Baby Bells.



De automatisering en digitalisering creëerden daarna nieuwe monopolies, niet alleen in de VS maar zelfs wereldwijd. In 2000 werd Microsoft op grond van de antitrustwetten gelast het bedrijf op te splitsen vanwege een monopolie op het besturingssysteem van computers. In hoger beroep werd het oordeel bevestigd. Niettemin wist Microsoft een schikking te treffen met de Amerikaanse autoriteiten: het hoefde zichzelf niet op te splitsen, als het de technologie zou delen met andere aanbieders. Sindsdien durft geen rechter zijn vingers er meer aan te branden.

De monopolies van de huidige Big Tech-reuzen als Google, Facebook en Amazon zijn veel bedreigender dan die van Standard Oil en American Sugar ooit zijn geweest. Deze bedrijven met honderden miljarden aan beurswaarde en reserves opereren wereldwijd en zijn machtiger en rijker. Ze hebben een zo grote klantenkring dat nieuwkomers op hun markt kansloos zijn. En wie toch aan hun marktaandeel knaagt (YouTube, WhatsApp en Instagram) wordt opgekocht. Ze zijn op grond van de huidige mededingingsregels ook bijna niet aan te pakken, omdat ze hun diensten gratis beschikbaar stellen. Ze benadelen geen consumenten door prijsmanipulatie.

Ze verdienen hun geld met de verkoop van big data en advertenties. Er zijn al diverse procedures tegen ze aangespannen. De EU legde Google in september een boete op van 2,4 miljard euro vanwege machtsmisbruik. Het grootste gevaar is dat ze dankzij hun big data regeringen, bedrijven, consumenten en zelfs kiezers naar hun hand kunnen zetten - of zich daarvoor laten gebruiken. Weliswaar wordt getracht daar in de marge iets tegen te doen, via onder meer GDPR-wetgeving (General Data Protection Regulation), maar dat lijkt meestal op een achterhoedegevecht.

De huidige antitrustwetgeving in de VS is gebaseerd op de Sherman Act uit 1890 die werd ingevoerd onder president Benjamin Harrison (wie kent hem niet....). Toen was de wereld nog heel groot. Nu is het door automatisering en digitalisering een dorp geworden, waar concerns als Google dagelijks miljarden klanten of gebruikers hebben.

Daarom zou er wereldwijde regelgeving moeten komen om te voorkomen dat die concerns de echte Big Brothers worden.

Ook Google zou moeten worden opgeknipt. Minimaal in 33 stukjes.

Reageren?

p.dewaard@volkskrant.nl

Google zou net als Standard Oil fijngemalen moeten kunnen worden in 33 stukjes

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y84-71F1-JCW9-24MW-00000-00Mohamed A. El-Erian: We must be ready for the brave new world2020-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisVIEWS NEWSMohamed A. El-Erian: We must be ready for the brave new world

[i]Climate change, technology, disruption of globalisation, and demographic shifts are heralding rapid change. Decision-makers must prepare, says <strong>Mohammed A El-Erian</strong>[/i]

GOVERNMENTS and firms must accept the likelihood of an acceleration of four secular developments that will influence what political and business leaders do and how they do it. If these trends occur simultaneously, they could overwhelm those who fail to adapt their thinking and practices in a timely manner.

The most important trend is climate change, which has evolved from a distant concern, about which there is ample time to take remedial action, to an imminent, urgent threat.

The mobilisation of various concerned segments of society, owing partly to unusual climatic disruptions in recent years, has greatly increased the pressure on companies to act now.

BP's recent announcement that it intends to achieve 'net-zero' carbon emissions by 2050 - a notable promise by an energy company that operates in several highly challenging settings -is the latest example of business responding to such calls. It is only a matter of time until this pressure also prompts governments to take further steps, not only to encourage green activities, but also to tax and regulate polluters.

Second, privacy concerns have grown alongside technical innovations in artificial intelligence and big data.

Technological advances allow not only for more efficient compilation of huge amounts of personal data, but also for use of this information to monitor and alter behaviours.

Broadly speaking, data are controlled and exploited either by governments (particularly in China), big tech companies (as in the US), or by users (as in Europe). But none of these three operating paradigms provides sufficient comfort and assurance to most people.

The third secular force is disruption to the multi-decade process of economic and financial globalisation.

[readmore]982715[/readmore]

The initial trigger for this was the trade-policy pivot by US president Donald Trump's administration - from cooperative conflict resolution to explicit confrontation, from multilateralism to bilateralism (or even unilateralism), and from rule-based to more ad hoc arrangements - which was aimed at creating a still-free, but fairer trading system. But de-globalisation has been turbocharged by the outbreak of the deadly coronavirus, which has disrupted the flow of goods and services in China and beyond.

These challenges to globalisation have opened the door for governments to weaponise economic tools to meet objectives that transcend economics, such as national security. This, in turn, is calling into question conventional wisdom about cross-border supply chains, just-in-time inventory management, and reliance on external demand to boost domestic growth.

The final trend is demographic and concerns more than the aging of societies in Europe and Asia and this trend's economic and political implications. It also goes beyond the growing realisation that millennials' starkly different expectations - regarding professional careers, personal engagement, political action, and the delivery of goods and services - will persist and deepen.

For starters, businesses need to be smarter about 'anywhere, any place, any time' delivery. Furthermore, job loyalty and tenure are decreasing, while expectations of comprehensive job fulfillment and engagement are rising. Self-mobilisation for political and other causes, often with no visible leadership structure, has become much easier, yet often is less durable and raises tricky questions about what comes afterward.

And all of this is taking place amid the continued migration of an ever-expanding range of interactions, from physical to virtual spaces.

Each of these secular forces will have an important impact on the effectiveness and success of companies and governments alike. And while being challenging overall, the four trends involve a diverse and geographically dispersed set of winners and losers. Executives and policymakers, therefore, must make timely revisions (including pre-emptive changes) not only to their business models and operational approaches, but also to both their tactical and strategic mindsets.

Getting this right will require cognitive diversity, openness to constructive criticism, repeated scenario analyses, and multi-disciplinary approaches. Moreover, because each of the secular forces involves a considerable degree of uncertainty (with lots of known unknowns, and probably more than a few unknown unknowns behind them), a combination of resilience, optionality, and agility is important. And this is even before one considers unanticipated, periodic shocks, such as the Covid-19 outbreak.

The challenges to sound decision-making and leadership, in both business and government, are not limited to mapping the four secular forces and the required adaptation.

Decision-makers must also consider correlations and causalities between these trends, which can make their impact multiplicative rather than merely additive.

Consider another aspect of demographic change: Migration and the humanitarian challenges that often come with it. Climate change confronts countries with the possibility of waves of migratory human flows, which they will find hard to accept and inhumane to refuse.

The combination of deglobalisation and the misuse of artificial intelligence and big data to infringe individual privacy is similarly troubling. This could lead to questionable behaviour by some governments and encourage malicious, non-state actors to disrupt societies and economies.

The world is in a period of accelerating change, the leading edge of which is the ever-growing list of developments that have gone from impossible to inevitable. Many (though by no means all) of the challenges facing business and political leaders may be broken down into four secular changes that can anchor the timely formulation of required responses at the local, national, regional, and global levels. The faster that companies and governments recognise this, the likelier they will be to alter the balance of benefits, costs, and risks in their favour.

<strong>Mohamed A. El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, the corporate parent of PIMCO, where he served as CEO andco-chief investment officer, was chairman of US president Barack Obama's Global Development Council.

He previously served as CEO of the Harvard Management Company and deputy director at the International Monetary Fund. He is the author, most recently, of The Only Game in Town: Central Banks, Instability, and Avoiding the Next Collapse.</strong>

[readmore]982514[/readmore]

urn:contentItem:5WK1-0TS1-JB20-G3FY-00000-00Mollie Hemingway, Susan Ferrechio And Jessica Tarlov Examine The Coverage Of The Jeffrey Epstein Debacle, His Ties To Donald Trump And Bill Clinton, The Resignation Of Alex Acosta And The Latest Epstein Accusers; Mike Pence Hits CNN Border Coverage After Taking Reporters To Overcrowded Center; The Vice President Tweeted That CNN Is So Dishonest, Rather Than Broadcasting Full Story, CNN Only Played Video Of Men In The Temporary Facility And Didn't Play Any Footage Of The Family Facility At All; President Trump Strafes Media Targets; The Media, Both The Left And The Right Are Having a Feast On The Infighting Between Veteran Democrat House Speaker Nancy Pelosi Versus Four New Freshmen In The House Who Are All Women Of Color; Mollie Hemingway's New Book "Justice On Trial" Tells The Story Of How The Media's Coverage Between Brett Kavanaugh And Christine Blasey Ford Was So Biased; President Trump's Ally, Sebastian Gorka And CNN Contributor Brian Karem Had An Intense Back-And-Forth At The White House Rose Garden During An Event When The Latter Poked And Threatened Gorka2019-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMEDIA BUZZ11:00 AM ESTSusan Ferrechio, Buck SextonNEWSDomestic071401cb.269Mollie Hemingway, Susan Ferrechio And Jessica Tarlov Examine The Coverage Of The Jeffrey Epstein Debacle, His Ties To Donald Trump And Bill Clinton, The Resignation Of Alex Acosta And The Latest Epstein Accusers; Mike Pence Hits CNN Border Coverage After Taking Reporters To Overcrowded Center; The Vice President Tweeted That CNN Is So Dishonest, Rather Than Broadcasting Full Story, CNN Only Played Video Of Men In The Temporary Facility And Didn't Play Any Footage Of The Family Facility At All; President Trump Strafes Media Targets; The Media, Both The Left And The Right Are Having a Feast On The Infighting Between Veteran Democrat House Speaker Nancy Pelosi Versus Four New Freshmen In The House Who Are All Women Of Color; Mollie Hemingway's New Book "Justice On Trial" Tells The Story Of How The Media's Coverage Between Brett Kavanaugh And Christine Blasey Ford Was So Biased; President Trump's Ally, Sebastian Gorka And CNN Contributor Brian Karem Had An Intense Back-And-Forth At The White House Rose Garden During An Event When The Latter Poked And Threatened GorkaHoward Kurtz, Mollie Hemingway, Jessica Tarlov; Mara Liasson, Carley Shimkus

HOWARD KURTZ, FOX NEWS HOST: On MEDIA BUZZ this Sunday, a media frenzy over sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein with some pundits pointing fingers at his former friends Donald Trump and Bill Clinton.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE O'DONNELL, MSNBC HOST: He was a fan. He said Jeffrey Epstein was a terrific guy. He said Jeffrey Epstein was a lot of fun to be with. And Donald Trump knew -- Donald Trump knew as he said publicly at the time that Jeffrey Epstein pursued girls "on the younger side."

JOE SCARBOROUGH, MSNBC HOST: Both Donald Trump and Bill Clinton knew Jeffrey Epstein very well. A lot of powerful people in New York knew him very well and they all knew the stories, every one of them.

CHRIS RUDDY, CEO, NEWSMAX MEDIA: I think it's highly unfair of people like you and others, Guilt by Association, whether it's Donald Trump, Bill Clinton, Al Gore, Alan Dershowitz just because they knew the guy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The media is trying as much as they can do to connect the administration with a horrific charge against the democratic donor Jeffrey Epstein, trying to make it about Trump, about members of his administration when the real story is that Epstein and Bill Clinton.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Are the journalists investigating Epstein targeting Trump and others through Guilt by Association? Is the press cheering the resignation of Labor Secretary Alex Acosta, the former prosecutor who approved a sweetheart deal for Epstein a decade ago? The White House stages a social media summit with conservative critics of big tech who basked in praise from the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Some of you are extraordinary. I can't say everybody.

(LAUGHTER)

TRUMP: No, but some of you are extraordinary. The crap you think of is unbelievable.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: But can Trump back up his charges? Facebook, Twitter and Google discriminate against the right. Plus, a new book by Mollie Hemingway denounces the coverage of the Brett Kavanaugh confirmation fight and charges there was a double standard for his accuser Christine Blasey Ford. I'm Howard Kurtz and this is MEDIA BUZZ.

Federal prosecutors in New York charged Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking and found hundreds of thousands of sexually suggested photos of young girls in his Manhattan mansion. It did more than rekindle the media debate over why he got such a lean deal in Florida 11 years ago. It put journalists' spotlight into Epstein's most prominent former friends.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Well, I knew like everybody in Palm Beach knew him. I mean, people in Palm Beach knew him. He was a fixture in Palm Beach. I had a falling out with him a long time ago. I don't think I've spoken to him for 15 years. I wasn't a fan.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Bill Clinton issued a statement saying he had flown on Epstein's jet four times, had two other brief meetings, and hadn't spoken to him in more than a decade. Here it is. "President Clinton knows nothing about the terrible crimes Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to in Florida some years ago, or those with which he has been recently charged in New York."

Joining us now to analyze the coverage: Mollie Hemingway of The Federalist, a Fox News contributor and co-author of the new book "Justice on Trial: The Brett Kavanaugh Nomination Fight," which we will talk about a bit later; Susan Ferrechio, chief congressional correspondent for the Washington Examiner; and Jessica Tarlov of Bustle.com, a Fox News contributor.

Mollie, Donald Trump was friends with Jeffrey Epstein, as we just heard. He said they had a falling out years ago. Are some in the media trying to imply or insinuate that Trump knew and condoned of his behavior with underage girls?

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR, AUTHOR, SENIOR EDITOR AT THE FEDERALIST: I think the whole interest in the story is because we have this guy who got a sweetheart deal, he had powerful friends, and when the media were able to tie it to a member of the Trump administration, recently departed Secretary Acosta, that made them have better interest.

But that really is a legitimate part of the story, how he was able to engage in this behavior over a long period of time. It's clearly not -- I mean, yes, he knew Donald Trump, that's clearly not where all of the interesting things will be. I hope they pursue it with other people, you know.

KURTZ: Yeah. He is a rich guy who got favorable treatment and was enabled or legitimized by a whole bunch of other rich, famous glitterati. Same question to you, Jessica. Are some in the media trying to imply or insinuate that Bill Clinton knew of and condoned Epstein having sex with underage minors or perhaps joined him himself?

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR, HEAD OF RESEARCH AT BUSTLE: Yeah, absolutely, but I think they are right to do that. There are number of people -- you know, hats off to Julie K. Brown who broke this right for the Miami Herald --

KURTZ: I'm glad you mentioned that because more often we don't devote enough attention to good journalism --

TARLOV: Yeah.

KURTZ: -- and she got some of these women to go on the record long after everybody forgot the story.

TARLOV: She also tracked the story, lived off her own money when she couldn't get the expenses covered. So, that's most important here. There is a network of wealthy individuals, Bill Clinton, Donald Trump, Prince Andrew, Alan Dershowitz, who did enable this. There is a great New York Times piece about how Jeffrey Epstein was welcomed back into New York society, hosting dinner parties again. How he got in with people at Harvard, Larry Summers.

All of that is important to the story because you can better understand how young girls were victimized, were raped, because powerful men protected that. So I think this line of questioning is totally legitimate. I don't think the president dodges any bullets by saying, oh, I don't really know him and I'm not a fan.

Everyone knows about his "Calendar Girls" party. Everyone knows about people traveling on the Lida Express (ph). I think journalists should be following this.

KURTZ: Dershowitz, for the record, was Epstein's lawyer, but, Susan --

TARLOV: He is also accused of assaulting two women.

KURTZ: Which he has denied. Yeah, he has been accused and he has denied it. There is a lot of recycling by the press at this 2002 quote from the president in New York magazine. "I've known Jeff for 15 years. He is a terrific guy. He is a lot of fun to be with. He even said he likes beautiful women as much as I do, many of them on the younger side, but that doesn't necessarily mean the younger side could have been 22."

SUSAN FERRECHIO, CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: That's right. The stronger connection is to Bill Clinton and his time spent with Jeffrey Epstein. President Trump allegedly kicked Epstein out of Mar- a-Lago --

KURTZ: Yes.

FERRECHIO: -- for allegedly assaulting an underage woman there and that he worked with prosecutors to help them build the case. There is one part of the story that really bothers me. I am so glad that the Miami Herald pursued this. They do give reporters a time to work on these very important stories. It bothers me that it seems the reason the story got legs again is because of President Trump.

What would have happened if Hillary Clinton was elected president? Would that story have had legs or would that be the end of it? It is an important question that I think we in the media should think about.

TARLOV: I don't actually see that SDNY won for this because it has to do with President Trump. I think --

FERRECHIO: I think she said so. I believe the reporter mentioned that that interest percolated again amongst editors and others because his secretary was the prosecutor.

KURTZ: Yes. Clearly --

FERRECHIO: Very important.

KURTZ: -- that as Acosta secretary of labor who was the U.S. attorney in Miami, who presided over his deal where Epstein went to jail for 13 months. It was part time because he could leave every day and go to work. Let me play some sound here. First, Alex Acosta struggling to save his job, holding a news conference at President Trump's direction, and then the resignation. Roll it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALEX ACOSTA, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF LABOR: Simply put the Palm Beach state attorney's office was ready to let Epstein walk free. Without the work of our prosecutors, Epstein would have gotten away with just that state charge.

TRUMP: I just want to let you know this was him, not me, because I'm with him.

ACOSTA: I have seen coverage of this case, that is over 12 years old, that had input and vetting at multiple levels of Department of Justice. It would be selfish for me to stay in this position and continue talking about a case that's 12 years old.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: So, Acosta is basically blaming the press coverage. It is true, there was a huge amount of press coverage, given the public revulsion of the magnitude of these alleged crimes and the deal 11 years ago that he approved, that he personally negotiated, not a pretty big and legitimate story.

HEMINGWAY: It's illegitimate story but I don't know if it has been covered that well. Debra Saunders had a great piece in the Las Vegas Review-Journal this morning, looking at how -- the only person to actually get this guy in jail was Alex Acosta. That can be for a number of reasons.

It can be because the evidence that they had for trafficking wasn't strong enough to secure a conviction, so a plea deal is a better thing. It could be that he -- as has been reported by Miami Herald, that he was serving as a government informant and that he did work that they found sufficiently helpful there, or it could be that powerful people in the administration at that time called him.

There are still journalistic questions to ask and making it as simple as this guy is bad, you know, because he was part of the plea deal doesn't really go to the fullness of the problem.

KURTZ: It's been reported, Jessica, that the president thought Acosta did well at the pressure but then saw the coverage over the next 24 hours which was very negative. Another problem for him is that the former top prosecutor in Palm Beach County says Acosta is wrong, that there was a 53- page draft indictment and that that was tossed aside after secret negotiations with Epstein lawyers and Acosta himself.

TARLOV: That 7:00 a.m. meeting at the Marriott that Alex Acosta what have us believed couldn't have taken place at the office because no one goes to the office at that hour is ridiculous. President Trump was probably the only person in America who thought that that press conference went well.

There seemed to be absolutely no concern for the real victims of all this which are the young women. President Trump as well when he was first asked about this said he feels very badly for Alex Acosta. He didn't talk about the victims.

Barry Krischer, who is the prosecutor, said there was a 53-page indictment ready to go. He is absolutely right. You also need to look at what happened to Jeffrey Epstein when he got back in New York. He didn't even have to check in. That goes to Cy Vance. What was going on? How are you overseeing this? If that was a person of color or someone --

HEMINGWAY: Or stands as the (ph) Manhattan --

(CROSSTALK)

HEMINGWAY: -- listed as a sex offender.

KURTZ: Manhattan, yeah.

HEMINGWAY: And you don't hear a lot of people focusing on that even though he is highly connected in New York circle.

TARLOV: Julie Brown is focusing on it though which is wonderful.

KURTZ: And Julie Brown in The Herald has also reported at least a dozen new accusers that have come forward. By the way, it may well be that President Trump did not ask Acosta to resign, that he was going to back him.

But others in the White House maybe not so much because while Acosta was trying to hang on to his job, there was a leaked to Politico saying that Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, wanted him out because he felt he was damaging the administration.

That is how these things are done. That is how the stage is set. You mentioned the victims are not getting attention. There is woman who came out. Her name is Jennifer Araoz and she had to say on the "Today Show," talking about when she was 14 years old.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JENNIFER ARAOZ, JEFFREY EPSTEIN ACCUSER: I just did what I was -- what he told me to do. I was really scared. I didn't necessarily think that he was, you know, going to rape me.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC HOST: Did he hold you there?

ARAOZ: Yeah. I was terrified and I was telling him to stop. Please stop, you know.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: She said she was raped by Epstein. This reminds me almost of the Harvey Weinstein case where more women are emboldened to come out, speak in the media about these traumatic experiences that for years, they just didn't want to grapple with publicly and deal with, you know, sometimes harsh attention of the media spotlight.

FERRECHIO: It is part of the evolution of the "Me Too Movement" and how it's made it easier for women to come forward when these things are in the past. But in the Article Two where it is not just this interview but the article about this interview where she talks about Epstein, describing his trips to the White House.

I'm really sad that there's no way to search those White House logs to see how many times he visited various presidents because that's another string to the story that deserves to be examined.

KURTZ: Yeah. I do wonder though about, you know, for all of the outrage and public revulsion and I'm outraged. It is sickening to look at what this guy did and is accused of. If he had not happened to have been a Palm Beach pal of President Trump, it wouldn't be getting much media attention at this point.

HEMINGWAY: It is obvious that it wouldn't be getting this level of media attention and it is important given the global network of powerful people and even just how he had the money and how he was financed to enable this lifestyle.

KURTZ: Right. Jessica, briefly, you very much include Bill Clinton in this and I raised the question why is Bill Clinton being targeted by Guilt by Association, but you say it is perfectly legitimate for the media to pursue these questions.

TARLOV: They have to look at every single man who went to these parties, engaged with these women. If people are on the record saying, you know, we know that he had beautiful women on the younger side, apparently there were these women there, Buckingham Palace had to release a statement about Prince Andrew. This is very serious. This is how powerful people are protected in these networks.

HEMINGWAY: Having said that, it is also important that we don't do Guilt by Association. People could be close to him. And it is important to just nail down these facts. Who was on the planes at this time --

TARLOV: I am just saying --

HEMINGWAY: -- and what --

TARLOV: It opens up grounds for questioning --

HEMINGWAY: Absolutely.

TARLOV: -- of everybody. If you were hanging out in his mansion and it was described what was going on in there, you should be questioned about it.

KURTZ: I think you too actually agree on that.

TARLOV: Yeah.

KURTZ: I think some pundits have engaged in guilt by insinuation, shall we say. When we come back, President Trump hosts a mini presser on all kinds of topics: Epstein, census, social media, Nancy Pelosi. How much do these sessions help him dominate the news? And later, AOC and three other liberal freshmen, lawmakers and their nasty spat with Pelosi, how the media are feasting on this fight.

KURTZ: President Trump covered a whole bunch of hot-button topics with reporters when he announced Alex Acosta's resignation, including his decision not to include a citizenship question on the 2020 census in the face of an adverse Supreme Court ruling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think we will have it in the end where it will be actually more accurate than a census. No, no, not only didn't I back down, I backed up because anybody else would have given this up a long time ago.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Mollie, the president had little choice but to retreat on the question on the census because the Supreme Court had ruled adversely, but is this how he uses his exchanges with reporters to show he's still fighting for his base even if he has certain tactical setbacks?

HEMINGWAY: Yes. I'm actually not sure that he should have stepped back on the census question and giving up the fight was probably not good for him, but that's why these things are helpful for him. He comes out and answers questions in a certain way to be able to reshape the coverage or to bring things out that aren't going to be covered by the media otherwise.

It's good that he's very open. It would be good to be able to ask him some more questions about whether it's the census or Paul Ryan or other issues, but --

KURTZ: Speaking of Paul Ryan, you set up me up nicely for Jessica. So Paul Ryan is quoted in the new book by Tim Alberta saying Trump didn't know anything about government, former house speaker saying he was knee-jerk in his reactions, he always wanted to scold the president.

President then hit back that Ryan was a lame duck failure, lost control of the House, and he did that in that half-hour presser as well. But interestingly, some of the anti-Trump pundits are faulting Paul Ryan for not speaking out when it counted, when he had some power.

TARLOV: Totally. I mean, (INAUDIBLE) liberal that I feel about this. There are all of these people who feel emboldened once they leave office or not when they're standing up. Bob Corker, Jeff Flake, like some good you are out of office. So, yeah, absolutely, if you think that he's morally bankrupt and you don't think he should be in office, you have a platform. Use it when it's meaningful. I completely agree with the criticism.

KURTZ: And so we are going to talk a little later in the program about this increasingly nasty spat between Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Nancy Pelosi and some of other freshmen. The president was asked about that. I mean, I was scribbling a lot of notes here, and he had this to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think Cortez is being very disrespectful to somebody that's been there a long time. I will tell you something about Nancy Pelosi that you know better than I do. She is not a racist, OK? She is not a racist. For them to call her a racist is a disgrace.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Susan, is this Trump playing commentator in chief and is it a bit odd that he's coming to Nancy Pelosi's defense?

FERRECHIO: Well, I think that I have a little bit of a problem with that story. I feel like we in the media need to be very careful that we are not generating news, we are just covering news. And I think --

KURTZ: That ship sailed a long time ago.

FERRECHIO: I think you need to be careful with stories like this when you're interviewing people on Capitol Hill. Are you putting the idea in the head? I will tell you this. There is no organic feeling on Capitol Hill amongst anyone including "The Squad," AOC and company, that Nancy Pelosi is a racist. This was generated, I think, in the media and pushed by the media because it's a good cookie story.

KURTZ: OK.

FERRECHIO: And I think that we need to be careful.

KURTZ: The president right there wasn't asked a question, do you think Nancy Pelosi was racist, he volunteered that, but you are saying he didn't respond to the media coverage?

FERRECHIO: Well, in my view, this was the definition of fake news.

KURTZ: OK. We are going to talk more about that. Also, the president on Friday talked about the ice raids, the immigration raids that have begun today to run up illegal immigrants. Interestingly, I thought he said, well, they will focus on criminals as opposed to people who have broken the law by being here. And so I am just wondering, do they help him shape the news cycle?

HEMINGWAY: Not just the news cycle but the overall narratives. So what is his big issue? It is talking about enforcement of border laws. He threatened he was going to do this several weeks ago, then he backs off and says, " I am going to give Congress some time." Then by the time they don't do anything, which is the least surprising thing ever, then it makes it more credible that they were going to begin these raids and he starts saying, "We are focusing on criminals."

KURTZ: Brief comment, Jessica.

TARLOV: I don't think that this necessarily helped him with anyone but with his base. That is what he certainly is looking to shore up for 2020 saying we are going to be focusing on the criminals, these are the ones who needs to get out there. That's in the stratosphere.

KURTZ: That might be true, but we all cover it all the time and I think that helps in control of the narrative or at least heavily influenced. Jessica Tarlov, Susan Ferrechio, thanks very much for coming by this Sunday.

Ahead, Mollie Hemingway will be back to talk about the revelations at her new book on the Kavanaugh nomination battle. But up next, Vice President Pence leads reporters into two facilities at the Texas border and complains that CNN's coverage is unfair.

KURTZ: Vice President Pence took a whack at CNN after visiting two detention centers at the Texas border. Pence spoke with children and others at a family center.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Are you comfortable? Are you being well taken care of? Do you have a place to get washed up and cleaned?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: But the picture was grimmer at a sweltering and badly overcrowded facility where nearly 400 men were fenced in on a concrete floor and said they were hungry and they lacked beds, showers or toothbrushes. Pence addressed the situation with reporters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PENCE: A temporary facility -- look, this is tough stuff. To be honest with you, I was not surprised by what I saw. And because on the way here, I knew we would see a system that is overcrowded. It is overwhelmed. That is why Congress has to act.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: When Pence did an interview with CNN's Pamela Brown, the network showed video only of the overcrowded men center. The vice president tweeted, "CNN is so dishonest. Rather than broadcasting the full story, showing the compassionate care the American people are providing to vulnerable families, tonight CNN only played video of men in the temporary facility and didn't play any footage of the family facility at all."

A White House official told me CNN made zero effort to show administration efforts to improve the border situation. In fairness, CNN's Pamela Brown asked Pence about the contrast between the two facilities.

The V.P. deserves credit for taking reporters in to see the terrible conditions at the men center, after President Trump had called The New York Times reporting on one such facility in Texas "phony," and tweeted today that the men's holding center that Pence visited was clear but crowded, and yet he again called the Times story on a different facility in Texas "fake."

That offensive began with a tweet storm last weekend which the president also vented about Comcast Trump haters at NBC and MSNBC who he said do the bidding of the parent company's top executives. He took a swipe at lying Brian Williams, who "totally fabricated a war story." Williams, of course, is the MSNBC host who lost his job as NBC anchor after making up a story about his chopper coming under fire in Iraq.

President also went after the weekend anchors at Fox News, declaring them worse than CNN. He tweeted that Fox, which failed to get the very boring Dem debates, is now loading up with Democrats and even using fake unsourced New York Times as a source of information. Part of the news division's job at Fox is to cover the democratic race which at times seems to annoy the president.

Ahead on MEDIA BUZZ, the president addressing social media companies, accusing them of blatant bias against the right. Does he have the evidence? But first, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez accuses Nancy Pelosi of singling out her and other women of color. But does her clout extend beyond Twitter and Instagram?

KURTZ: The media love a good juicy internal party fight and they also love to talk, right, opine and prognosticate about Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, so they are all over the increasingly nasty spat between Nancy Pelosi and four liberal freshmen Democrats, AOC, Rashida Tlaib, Ayanna Pressley and Ilhan Omar.

The house speaker started the latest of invecting (Ph), dismissing to them as having no power and AOC hit back telling the Washington Post, "I kind of thought that she was keeping the progressive flank at more of an arm's distance in order to protect more moderate members, which I understood. But the persistent singling out, it got to a point where it just outright disrespectful, says AOC, the explicit singling of newly elected women of color."

Pelosi told her caucus not to tweeting at each other invoking a posting from AOC's chief of staff that liking more moderate Democrats are the old southern segregationists.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NANCY PELOSI, UNITED STATES SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: They took offense because I addressed -- at the request of my members an offensive tweet that came out of one of the members' offices that reference our blue dogs and our new Dems essentially as segregationists. Our members took offense to that.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY): Knowing the media environment that we're operating in, knowing the amount of death threats that we get, knowing the amount of concentration of attention, I think it's just -- it's worth asking why.

MANU RAJU, CNN SENIOR CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Do you think she has a racial animus? Is she a racist?

OCASIO-CORTEZ: No, no, absolutely not. Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Joining us now from New York, Buck Sexton, a radio talk show host and former CIA analyst, and here in Washington Mara Liasson, national political reporter for NPR and a Fox News contributor.

Buck, don't the media just adore this party infighting stories especially since AOC ratchet up the rhetoric by saying Pelosi is going after women of color.

BUCK SEXTON, RADIO HOST AND FORMER CIA ANALYST: Yes. But the media is right here, I think in covering this, because it's more than just the squabble, the intermural fights that are going on here which makes for good copy and obviously good coverage people kind of want to see what's going on.

There really is a challenge underway inside the Democratic Party between young and old, between far left and more centrist establishment Democrats and in the social media era in which we currently live and I think this is only going to get stronger, somebody like AOC is able to change the news narrative with a single tweet. And so, Pelosi is trying to fight a war in the media with somebody who has a whole new slew of weapons that she can use and she just can't honestly control it.

So, I think it's important that they're covering this and I think we're just going to see this continue on for a while because AOC is a true believer.

KURTZ: I agree with most of what you said and it sets me up for my question to Mara, which is in the world of Twitter and Instagram Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is a huge star, she become a household name.

MARA LIASSON, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. Millions and millions.

KURTZ: Yes. A 29-year-old freshman. But in the tradition bound Houses Pelosi accuse (Ph) them running reporters --

LIASSON: Right.

KURTZ: -- she and Omar and Pressley and Tlaib, have no power. They can't even get their bills on the floor. So --

(CROSSTALK)

LIASSON: Well, and they were the only four votes against the border bill. And others are saying hey --

KURTZ: A $4.5 billion of emergency aid.

LIASSON: -- totally not right. Only the four of them voted no.

KURTZ: Yes.

LIASSON: In other words, if they have some power why aren't they getting any followers inside the House. Look, both outside power is important because that's how you encourage activists and get the grassroots energized and turn out voters but power inside is what counts. If you're going to, a, keep your majority and defeat the Republicans.

KURTZ: Buck, it seems to me that conservatives in the media love to beat up on AOC and it's good for clips and ratings, it's good copy, and liberals in the media love to praise her and she's very savvy you got to say in drawing attention sometimes by going a little over the top. Do the media overcover Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez?

SEXTON: No, I think that she is able to set the narrative and I think it's because of the following she has and because of what she represents which is this new far-left progressive increasingly Democrat socialist Democratic Party and, you know, I will just say that some conservatives in media see the way that AOC is going after, specifically Nancy Pelosi, with what are pretty clearly, pretty clear insinuations at least of some kind of a racial undertone or racial animus.

There's a bit of shot for conservatives in the media in the right, saying, you know, this is stuff that goes all the time, it's usually Democrat against Republican, true in the media, true in politics, for this to get turned on Pelosi and some Democrats, maybe now the left will realize that calling people racist for no reason is a nasty and underhanded thing to do and they would be a little slower.

I don't think that will happen, Howie. But I do think we are seeing the media coverage of this affected by that dynamic playing out in front of us. And I think that AOC is only going to get a bigger voice and Nancy Pelosi - - because there's not going to be a legislation.

KURTZ: All right.

SEXTON: I mean, to Mara's point, there's not going to be a legislation.

(CROSSTALK)

KURTZ: Let me -- yes. There's not going to be a Green New Deal, et cetera.

SEXTON: Yes.

KURTZ: But interesting point. But talk about media coverage, it's about to go into the stratosphere because President Trump tweeted this morning that these four Democratic women who, I'm just quoting the president here, "originally came from countries whose governments are corrupt, why don't they go back and help fix the totally broken and climate infested places from which they came then come back and show us how. Nancy will help make the travel arrangements."

So, of the four women only Ilhan Omar she was born in Somalia, the others were born in America. So, Mara, I see the media just completely exploding over this that the president is kind of telling them to leave America.

LIASSON: Look, the Democrats have formed a circular firing squad, that's what Republicans want them to do. Donald Trump decided to put himself in the middle of that, now the Democrats are rallying around Pelosi against these pretty extreme comments, "go back where you came from."

Pelosi issued a statement today saying that was really xenophobic and I think he's going to end -- end up helping them solve this squabble at least for the moment, because the one thing that unifies the Democrats is Donald Trump.

KURTZ: Are the media terms, Buck Sexton, the president also keeps the story alive. This has been going on for a week now.

SEXTON: Yes. I think that he's -- we're going to see others plays out, Most of what Mara said I would cause on onto and that at least now the Democrats are going to have a shift in the narrative away from their internal fighting here, this wasn't -- this wasn't a good tweet from the president. I support the president, I think a lot of his tweets are actually effective on messaging, this one is just going to get picked apart.

I would like to see more focus on the border issue but the media is going to have field day with this and it's going to move away from essentially AOC, as we just discussed saying that Pelosi and some very prominent Democrats perhaps along with her, have a disrespect of women of color. Now the Democrats are going to unify around no, it actually all comes from the right and from Trump.

So, we'll see how it plays out over the next couple of days. But you know, Trump's messaging, by the way, even when sometimes people think he's getting it wrong, we find out that he actually got it right, we just didn't expect it, I don't think that's the case with this tweet, though.

KURTZ: OK. Rare moments of agreement here between the two of you. Buck Sexton and Mara Liasson, great having you guys. Thanks very much for joining us.

SEXTON: Thank you.

KURTZ: Coming up, Mollie Hemingway's new book says the media were blatantly unfair to Brett Kavanaugh and went easy on Christine Blasey Ford. She will make that case next.

KURTZ: We have an exclusive first look on last week's program, and a new book that has landed with quite an impact. "Justice on Trial: The Kavanaugh Confirmation and the Future of the Supreme Court" quickly shot up to number one on Amazon.

Mollie Hemingway is back. She is the co-author along Carrie Severino of the Judicial Crisis Network which lobbied for Kavanaugh's nomination. Mollie, you report that the Trump team heled back derogatory information on Cristine Blasey Ford because the White House felt that any criticism of Ford would be treated as a smear and depict as victim shaming.

My question isn't that true and isn't it the rationale that women who are victims of sexual assault or believe they are would be more reluctant to come forward if they believe their past will be picked apart.

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. These are legitimate questions and that was part of why the White House, not just the White House but also Senate Republicans had this information. They both had ways of people calling in and they were getting quite a bit of information of how Christine Blasey Ford that what people were saying to these people, what people are saying to these investigators, it was very much at odds with that media presentation.

So, I do think it's important to be careful. It's also important for the media to be careful in how they are telling a story and making sure that they are not being one-sided that they're not leaving out information or they're not becoming champions for one side or the other.

KURTZ: You and your co-authors spoke to people who said that Christine Ford back in high school, remember this is decades ago, was a heavy drinker, who was much more aggressive with boys than we were led to believe. Did you have any reluctance about publishing that information now?

HEMINGWAY: Well, we actually had so much more stuff. We spoke with quite a few people who knew Christine Blasey Ford in high school, or knew Brett Kavanaugh in high school and they had incredibly salacious stories. We felt that in order to tell the specifics of some of those stories we needed them to put names with it and when people were --

(CROSSTALK)

KURTZ: They were not on the record.

HEMINGWAY: People were understandably worried about having their name associated with it.

KURTZ: Right.

HEMINGWAY: Because they would say, well, I'm trying to get kid into school and if it comes out and the people, the media would go after me, I'm scared to do it. So, we had those stories, we had a lot of those stories, we felt we needed to pull back on that, while also being accurate and describing what her friends say and what they have said.

And these are people who don't have necessarily completely negative views of Christine Blasey Ford, they also liked her, they thought she was nice. They just say there was this other aspect and that the way that the media were portraying it was completely at odds.

And they also say that they had talk to some reporters here in town and that this was not completely not well known but that when they would tell stories they weren't pursued as aggressively as any anti-Kavanaugh story.

KURTZ: Right. Well, maybe they also had the problem that you wrestled with which in fact getting people to go on the record.

You accuse the media of having an irrational personal dislike of Brett Kavanaugh at that time and despite the fact that seems like a genuine guy who, you know, allegations aside, you know, coaches his girls' basketball team. Why do you think that would have been?

HEMINGWAY: I'm not entirely sure why that was, but just looking at how they handled different stories or even how at some point in the process you start seeing the media suggesting, you know, it goes from him being a gang rapist. You see in USA Today they're running story saying he shouldn't be around children as a coach --

(CROSSTALK).

KURTZ: Yes. Let me quote that. This is something I had missed, Erik Brady, writing in USA Today, that Kavanaugh should give up his school coaching duties, this is during the fight, because a credibly accused sex offender should stay off basketball courts for now when kids are around. Did the press call foul on that kind of personal invective?

HEMINGWAY: And in fact, they did pull back on some of that, but just overarching the story was one where any allegation against Brett Kavanaugh, it seemed no matter how thinly sourced would be getting full treatment.

You know how you want to be careful about victims.

KURTZ: Yes.

HEMINGWAY: That's true. It is, reputation is also an issue and you want to be careful about defaming someone or going after their reputation without the goods.

KURTZ: I mean, people forget. He threw ice in a bar once, and you know, maybe he did or maybe he didn't, but that became like the days' top headline. Julie Swetnick, one of the accusers represented by Michael Avenatti, now has some other legal problems, claimed to have been raped at 10 house parties, who said there were gang rapes attended by Kavanaugh and others. He also said that Kavanaugh and friend spiked the punch at some of these parties, then she was interviewed by NBC, what happened?

HEMINGWAY: Well, NBC found that her -- she was not such a credible witness but even more than that, NBC actually knew that the supposed witness to corroborate her allegations had denied what Michael Avenatti had claimed about her statement. They sat on that.

(CROSSTALK)

KURTZ: So, let's just slow down. So Avenatti said, hey, here is somebody else a friend of Julie Swetnick who can vouch for what she's saying.

HEMINGWAY: Right.

KURTZ: And then what happened?

HEMINGWAY: They talked to her, she said actually what he is telling you is not what I said, she was very upset. They sat on that for weeks. They had the information before his confirmation vote, they didn't reveal it until weeks after.

And this is, you know, there are so many different ways the media cannot do their jobs well and omitting information or sitting on information is one of them, or even how I was struck by how and we tell the story in the book of how when Christine Blasey Ford said she had four witnesses to support her account, and all four say that they don't support her including one who's a very close friend.

And when that comes out that the friend says I cannot -- you know, I cannot corroborate this allegation, the people close to the Kavanaugh's think this is it, finally the media coverage will change.

KURTZ: Right.

HEMINGWAY: And the media barely noted that Leland Keyser was not backing up her friend.

KURTZ: But was there some coverage of the other sides, some coverage when there are questions raised about whether it's Blasey Ford or Swetnick, some coverage when some of the charges against -- or charges allegations against Kavanaugh were not corroborated.

HEMINGWAY: There was always some coverage.

KURTZ: Yes.

HEMINGWAY: But this is just about the deluge on one side versus a little pittance on the other. And so, we need to be -- there's so many different ways that we need to be careful with our coverage including the amount of - - amount of attention we give to one claim or another.

KURTZ: All right, Mollie Hemingway, "Justice on Trial." Congratulations on the book's success.

HEMINGWAY: Thank you.

KURTZ: Great to see you as always.

After the break, a CNN contributor taunted Sebastian Gorka at the White House social media summit. Did he go away over the line?

KURTZ: President Trump's social media summit was filled with conservative critics of Twitter, Facebook, and Google, which weren't invited, and he said the target was dishonesty and discrimination by big tech, and that it would be covered by the fake news media. Trump argued that Twitter is unfairly reducing the number of people who follow him.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: We had terrible bias, we have censorship like nobody has any understanding, or nobody can believe, because I millions of people, so many people I wouldn't believe it but I know that we've been blocked. People come up to me and they say, sir, I can't -- I can't get you, I can't follow you, they make it impossible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Joining us now from New York, Carley Shimkus, a reporter for Fox News Headline 24/7 on SiriusXM. So, as I said, you know, it's mostly conservative critics of big tech, some Republican congressmen and women.

Look, these are left-leaning companies, nobody disputes that, they've acknowledged it, there been times where they have suspended or exiled, or shut, or banned, or minimized conservatives and in a couple of instances they had to apologized. But did the summit make that case?

CARLEY SHIMKUS, FOX NEWS REPORTER: You know, it kind of depends on what side of the aisle you sit on, there was a CNN headline that reads "Circus show summit, Trump delivers meandering speech to his digital armies of supporters at the White House."

But then Diamond and Silk and Jim Hanson appeared on Fox News the next day they attended the summit, and they said that it was really helpful and they talked about the grievances they have with social media and then the president is going to talk to tech companies the next day.

I think the purpose of this summit was twofold. One, so that the president can kind of rub elbows with the people that support him the most strongly on social media and the other was to kind of alert big tech and say that regulation might be coming down the pipeline.

KURTZ: Yes, I think that that is a real possibility and I think they have mostly themselves to blame, such a lousy job of policing their own sites.

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: But on your point about the media coverage, even before this White House summit got underway, the New York Times, this is a news story, the guest list has a long critics who feared is bringing together people who decimate threats, hate speech and actual fake news.

So, you have also the Times tech columnist, Kevin Roose said, these were bunch of right-wing trolls --

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: -- and a motley grab bag of pro-Trump influences. So, he's -- Trump is calling the media fake and they are saying, you invited people who put out fake stuff.

SHIMKUS: Fake news, yes. It's like mindboggling. So, at the beginning of the summit the president called the attendees online journalists. There were some online journalists there but some of them weren't. There was one person that was -- that attended who spread some false information about Kamala Harris' race, another person who posted this unflattering video of Joe Biden.

So, some of the attendees were controversial, and I think that's why the White House didn't release the guest list in advance.

One of the reasons this whole summit received such negative press it's because it's unusual for a politician to be so buddy, buddy with his social media supporters because sometimes they say crude and controversial things but the president sometimes says crude and controversial things on social media as well. And he knows how important this group of people were to him in 2016 and wants to make sure that they are there for him in 2020 as well.

KURTZ: Yes. I think it's fair for the press to point out, there were a couple of conspiracy theorist there.

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: On the other hand, because we didn't have the whole list it was hard to reach any sweeping conclusion. But as we play at the top, so the president says Twitter is making harder for people to follow his. He's got 62 million followers by the way, and Twitter --

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: -- Twitter keeps reducing follower account which the company says it's just a periodic reading out of bots and fake accounts that's reduced a lot of people's follower accounts, including mine, including everyone I know. So, is there evidence to back up the president's charges on this point?

SHIMKUS: Yes. You know, it's interesting in January 2015, the president received an average of 79 retweets per tweet which is kind of crazy to think about because now he regularly receives tens of thousands of retweets per tweet.

KURTZ: Yes.

SHIMKUS: So, he's also been really good for Twitter. I can't imagine them silencing him personally but they have --

KURTZ: Sure.

SHIMKUS: -- censored other conservatives and had to apologize for them.

KURTZ: Zillions of dollars of free advertising from the president. OK.

SHIMKUS: Absolutely.

KURTZ: So, one of the people at the summit was former White House official Sebastian Gorka now with Salem Radio and Brian Karem, a Playboy reporter and CNN contributor picked a fight with him. Take a look.

SHIMKUS: Yes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIAN KAREM, CNN CONTRIBUTOR: This is a group of people that are eager for demonic possession."

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Demonic. Mr. Gorka, get him.

SEBASTIAN GORKA, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You are a punk. You're not a journalist, you're a punk.

KAREM: Go home.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Go, Gorka.

KAREM: Go home. Hey, Gorka, get a job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHIMKUS: My.

KURTZ: Carley, can CNN justify having somebody on its payroll that acts like that?

SHIMKUS: yes. This was, it was almost like a metaphor for how much team Trump and the media just don't get along, it's no surprise that this would happen given the close proximity of the two groups. I think that both sides really displayed some poor sportsmanship, if you will, and both should be reprimanded by their employers.

KURTZ: Well, Gorka is an aggressive guy when he thinks he's been unfairly accused. But there's simply no question that Brian Karem, a very liberal commentator started this fight and I think CNN --

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: -- might want to take a look at that.

SHIMKUS: Yes.

KURTZ: Carley Shimkus, great to see you as always.

SHIMKUS: Thank you, I appreciate it.

KURTZ: Thanks again. Still to come, a very personal and poignant story involving our colleague Ed Henry and why he's in the hospital.

KURTZ: Ed Henry, my colleague and friend here at Fox News just did a very courageous thing. He went into surgery to make an organ donation to his ailing sister Colleen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: So, I'm going to donate part of my liver on Tuesday. It's just hard to (Inaudible) because there's a lot of people who need organ donates (Ph).

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A lot of people probably going through exactly what you're going through right now and you sharing the story is going to make a huge difference.

HENRY: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And I give you huge kudos for this, Ed, honestly.

HENRY: That was few days -- few days ago. And --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I got to say --

HENRY: -- she's really happy there. That's all I want to do to make her happy, to give her a little life.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Wow. Ed donated 30 percent of his liver and doctors hope both of them will regenerate full livers and he provided an update yesterday from the hospital.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: It immediately started working, immediately.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wow.

HENRY: It's just a miracle. The prayers that we are feeling, I cannot thank -- I can't thank everyone personally, I want to thank everybody now, you've been amazing, I totally underestimated the outpouring.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KURTZ: Ed, you've been amazing, my hat is off to you, and wishing you and your sister a very speedy recovery. Nice to have that live update.

That's it for this edition of MEDIA BUZZ. I'm Howard Kurtz. Hey, check out my new podcast MEDIA BUZZ Meter. We rift on everything from politics to sports, to culture, and entertainment and you can subscribe at Apple iTunes or at Google Play or foxnewspodcast.com.

We hope you like our Facebook page. Check it every day. We post my columns there, original videos, and we'll continue the conversation and debate cacophony on Twitter. We're back here next Sunday, 11 Eastern with the latest BUZZ.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60JT-D9B1-DYTY-C08N-00000-00Molly Russell's father backs 'stocktake' of digital world;Duty of care TELEGRAPH CAMPAIGN2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Molly Russell's father backs 'stocktake' of digital worldDuty of care TELEGRAPH CAMPAIGNAmy Jones

A "STOCKTAKE" of the digital world is long overdue, the father of Molly Russell has urged, as he pledged his support for a new consultation into online harms.

The campaigner claims that graphic self-harm images on Instagram played a role in his daughter's suicide and wants the internet to be a "safer place" for young and vulnerable people.

Ian Russell said: "Today's current big tech platforms were born at about the same time as my youngest daughter, Molly. The powerful tech corporations live on, sadly Molly ended her own life in 2017 and I am convinced what she found online helped kill her."

Writing for The Telegraph website, the founder of the Molly Rose Foundation argues that a "stocktake of our digital world is long overdue" and backs Labour's new Our Digital Future Consultation.

will examine children's safety, hate speech and the spread of disinformation online.

Jo Stevens, the shadow culture secretary, said: "Labour believes that technology has already changed lives for the better, but it also provides a space where disinformation, hate speech and other online harms have been allowed to flourish.

"This is something that should worry all of us."

Labour is also calling on the Government to prioritise the Online Harms Bill, which was unveiled in April last year in response to the death of Mr Russell's 14-year-old daughter.

The proposals included a "duty of care" on tech firms and a regulator with the power to issue heavy fines to platforms which do not sufficiently censor potentially harmful content.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X39-NXV1-DY0W-43XY-00000-00Momentum grows for a digital watchdog to regulate tech giants2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMomentum grows for a digital watchdog to regulate tech giantsBen BrodyBloomberg NewsMissoula, Mont.FULL TEXT

WASHINGTON - With Big Tech accused of everything from decimating industries to abusing privacy, calls are growing for the creation of a federal regulator.

Presidential candidates, consumer advocates and some antitrust enforcers have focused on breaking up Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc., Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google - or at least forcing them to unwind past acquisitions. Yet those moves could take years and face lengthy court challenges.

The desire for faster action is fueling demands for a new agency to oversee the industry, an idea that's gaining traction among liberal and free-market economists in the U.S., Europe and Australia. They say there's plenty of precedent: The U.S. and other countries have watchdogs for specific industries, such as aviation, medicine, financial services and the environment, so why not digital markets?

Advocates say a digital regulator could referee disputes between competitors, set standards for privacy, make it easier to move one's data between networks, and make sure the biggest companies aren't squelching innovation or smothering potential rivals.

"If the search engine discriminates against you vigorously enough, you're not alive for very long," said Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale University economist and a former antitrust official at the Justice Department. "You need a regulator to be alerted to the problem on Monday and be able to have a hearing the next Monday, figure it out and keep the victim alive rather than taking two or three years to bring a case."

The European Union on Tuesday took a big step in this direction when the president-elect of the EU Commission enlarged the portfolio of Margrethe Vestager, one of the world's toughest antitrust regulators as the bloc's competition commissioner. As the head of digital affairs, she will oversee such matters as big data, innovation, cybersecurity and artificial intelligence, along with antitrust.

In the U.S., efforts to establish such an agency would be met with many obstacles. Republicans, who opposed the creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in 2010, would likely fight another bureaucracy. Democrats may see it as diluting antitrust inquiries. The tech companies, too, would likely try to stop it. An agency with the power to require changes to their business practices could be even more threatening to their bottom lines than budding federal and state antitrust investigations.

Besides Scott Morton, who led a University of Chicago panel that produced a report on the digital economy in July, supporters include Jason Furman, President Barack Obama's former chief economic adviser who was the lead author of a similar study for the British government.

President Donald Trump might welcome a digital authority, which could also monitor social-media companies for alleged bias. He has been a persistent critic of Facebook, Google and Twitter Inc. for what he says is suppression of conservative political opinions, a charge the companies have denied.

It's notable that a digital agency was a key proposal in the report by the University of Chicago's Stigler Center for the Study of the Economy and the State. The so-called Chicago School's laissez-faire thinking on antitrust has dominated the approach of courts and enforcers since the 1970s. Many experts now think that stance went too far, clearing the way for industry overall to become more consolidated and for the tech giants to rise.

To foster more competition, a digital agency could, for example, mandate that companies can't discriminate against rivals that operate on their platforms. It might ban Amazon, on which many third-party merchants depend to sell their goods, from punishing a successful outside vendor by pushing it down in its search rankings. Or it might require that Apple lower its fee for app store purchases of third-party services, such as Spotify Technology SA's music-streaming service, which competes with Apple Music.

A digital authority was also the central recommendation in Furman's report. The U.K.'s competition authority in July said a new regulator might be needed to police the digital platforms, mirroring Furman's recommendations. A version is under consideration in Australia, whose competition commission also issued a similar report in July.

Some American lawmakers are warming to the idea, including Senator Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who is a close ally of Trump's. "It seems that a regulatory body is the right way to go," Graham told reporters after a hearing on technology and competition in May.

Even Facebook's Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg has called for global regulations on data ownership by consumers, policing harmful content, protecting the integrity of elections and guarding privacy rights. Erin Egan, Facebook's chief privacy officer, last week outlined areas where a regulator or other outside group could help improve choice and promote innovation - two goals of antitrust enforcement.

A regulator could oversee data portability, in which consumers move their data from one social-media site to another. It could establish standards to make sure Facebook users who want to move to an alternative network can easily take their lists of friends, photos and posts with them. Congress did something similar when it passed the 1996 Telecommunications Act, which forced carriers to let consumers keep their phone numbers when switching networks.

A related idea would have digital companies pay consumers for the use of their data. California is looking into it, while Democratic Senator Mark Warner of Virginia and a Republican colleague, Josh Hawley of Missouri, back legislation that would make companies publicize the value of the data they hold. If consumers are going to own and sell their own data, a regulator would have to set up a marketplace and establish basic rules.

Facebook and Google say users can already download their data for personal use, but critics have said the process is too cumbersome, or the data that users are allowed to move is too limited, to represent true portability.

All four companies have also said they face robust competition and don't monopolize their respective markets or block access to their platforms by competitors.

Amazon spokesman Jack Evans said the company represents 1% of global retail, including e-commerce and brick-and-mortar stores, and that it depends on third-party sellers for its success.

Apple referred to July testimony before the House antitrust panel by a company vice president who said Apple runs a fair marketplace that has allowed apps, including Spotify, to succeed, and that its own apps face tough competition.

Some doubt a single regulator could tackle the diversity of issues involved. "The fact that the businesses are so different and that we would try to slam them all together in some sort of tech regulator" seems an impossibly hard legislative challenge, said Neil Chilson, a former Federal Trade Commission official who now serves as a senior research fellow in technology at the libertarian Charles Koch Institute. "It's just not clear to me how you achieve that."

Such hurdles aren't stopping digital agency proponents. Some are calling for urgent action not just to end the tech giants' dominance but also to prevent them from controlling the next tech revolution - artificial intelligence and machine learning.

"In every society a lot of the same issues are bubbling up," said Gene Kimmelman, one of the authors of the University of Chicago report and a former Justice Department antitrust official. "It's going to take quite a bit more than antitrust to actually drive competitive forces in these markets," he added.

___

(With assistance from David McLaughlin.)

urn:contentItem:5X2W-XMR1-JBCN-40W0-00000-00Momentum grows for a digital watchdog to regulate tech giants2019-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisLOCAL NEWSMomentum grows for a digital watchdog to regulate tech giants

Bloomberg News (TNS)

WASHINGTON With Big Tech accused of everything from decimating industries to abusing privacy, calls are growing for the creation of a federal regulator.

Presidential candidates, consumer advocates and some antitrust enforcers have focused on breaking up Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc., Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google or at least forcing them to unwind past acquisitions. Yet those moves could take years and face lengthy court challenges.

The desire for faster action is fueling demands for a new agency to oversee the industry, an idea that’s gaining traction among liberal and free-market economists in the U.S., Europe and Australia. They say there’s plenty of precedent: The U.S. and other countries have watchdogs for specific industries, such as aviation, medicine, financial services and the environment, so why not digital markets?

Advocates say a digital regulator could referee disputes between competitors, set standards for privacy, make it easier to move one’s data between networks, and make sure the biggest companies aren’t squelching innovation or smothering potential rivals.

"If the search engine discriminates against you vigorously enough, you’re not alive for very long," said Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale University economist and a former antitrust official at the Justice Department. "You need a regulator to be alerted to the problem on Monday and be able to have a hearing the next Monday, figure it out and keep the victim alive rather than taking two or three years to bring a case."

The European Union on Tuesday took a big step in this direction when the president-elect of the EU Commission enlarged the portfolio of Margrethe Vestager, one of the world’s toughest antitrust regulators as the bloc’s competition commissioner. As the head of digital affairs, she will oversee such matters as big data, innovation, cybersecurity and artificial intelligence, along with antitrust.

In the U.S., efforts to establish such an agency would be met with many obstacles. Republicans, who opposed the creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in 2010, would likely fight another bureaucracy. Democrats may see it as diluting antitrust inquiries. The tech companies, too, would likely try to stop it. An agency with the power to require changes to their business practices could be even more threatening to their bottom lines than budding federal and state antitrust investigations.

President Donald Trump might welcome a digital authority, which could also monitor socialmedia companies for alleged bias. He has been a persistent critic of Facebook, Google and Twitter Inc. for what he says is suppression of conservative political opinions, a charge the companies have denied.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X3S-YNM1-JCM7-R1XG-00000-00Momentum grows for digital watchdog2019-09-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisBPg. 7Momentum grows for digital watchdogBEN BRODY Bloomberg News

WASHINGTON - With Big Tech accused of everything from decimating industries to abusing privacy, calls are growing for the creation of a federal regulator.

Presidential candidates, consumer advocates and some antitrust enforcers have focused on breaking up Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc., Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google - or at least forcing them to unwind past acquisitions. Yet those moves could take years and face lengthy court challenges.

The desire for faster action is fueling demands for a new agency to oversee the industry, an idea that's gaining traction among liberal and free-market economists in the U.S., Europe and Australia. They say there's plenty of precedent: The U.S. and other countries have watchdogs for specific industries, such as aviation, medicine, financial services and the environment, so why not digital markets?

Advocates say a digital regulator could referee disputes between competitors, set standards for privacy, make it easier to move one's data between networks, and make sure the biggest companies aren't squelching innovation or smothering potential rivals.

"If the search engine discriminates against you vigorously enough, you're not alive for very long," said Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale University economist and a former antitrust official at the Justice Department. "You need a regulator to be alerted to the problem on Monday and be able to have a hearing the next Monday, figure it out and keep the victim alive rather than taking two or three years to bring a case."

The European Union recently took a big step in this direction when the president-elect of the EU Commission enlarged the portfolio of Margrethe Vestager, one of the world's toughest antitrust regulators as the bloc's competition commissioner. As the head of digital affairs, she will oversee such matters as big data, innovation, cybersecurity and artificial intelligence, along with antitrust.

In the U.S., efforts to establish such an agency would be met with many obstacles. Republicans, who opposed the creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in 2010, would likely fight another bureaucracy. Democrats may see it as diluting antitrust inquiries. The tech companies, too, would likely try to stop it. An agency with the power to require changes to their business practices could be even more threatening to their bottom lines than budding federal and state antitrust investigations.

Besides Scott Morton, who led a University of Chicago panel that produced a report on the digital economy in July, supporters include Jason Furman, President Barack Obama's former chief economic adviser who was the lead author of a similar study for the British government.

President Donald Trump might welcome a digital authority, which could also monitor social-media companies for alleged bias. He has been a persistent critic of Facebook, Google and Twitter Inc. for what he says is suppression of conservative political opinions, a charge the companies have denied.

It's notable that a digital agency was a key proposal in the report by the University of Chicago's Stigler Center for the Study of the Economy and the State. The so-called Chicago School's laissez-faire thinking on antitrust has dominated the approach of courts and enforcers since the 1970s. Many experts now think that stance went too far, clearing the way for industry overall to become more consolidated and for the tech giants to rise.

To foster more competition, a digital agency could, for example, mandate that companies can't discriminate against rivals that operate on their platforms. It might ban Amazon, on which many third-party merchants depend to sell their goods, from punishing a successful outside vendor by pushing it down in its search rankings. Or it might require that Apple lower its fee for app store purchases of third-party services, such as Spotify Technology SA's music-streaming service, which competes with Apple Music.

A digital authority was also the central recommendation in Furman's report. The U.K.'s competition authority in July said a new regulator might be needed to police the digital platforms, mirroring Furman's recommendations. A version is under consideration in Australia, whose competition commission also issued a similar report in July.

Some American lawmakers are warming to the idea, including Sen. Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who is a close ally of Trump's.

"It seems that a regulatory body is the right way to go," Graham told reporters after a hearing on technology and competition in May.

Even Facebook's Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg has called for global regulations on data ownership by consumers, policing harmful content, protecting the integrity of elections and guarding privacy rights. Erin Egan, Facebook's chief privacy officer, last week outlined areas where a regulator or other outside group could help improve choice and promote innovation - two goals of antitrust enforcement.

A regulator could oversee data portability, in which consumers move their data from one social-media site to another. It could establish standards to make sure Facebook users who want to move to an alternative network can easily take their lists of friends, photos and posts with them. Congress did something similar when it passed the 1996 Telecommunications Act, which forced carriers to let consumers keep their phone numbers when switching networks.

Quote

"It seems that a regulatory body is the right way to go." ,Sen. Lindsey Graham, South Carolina Republican and chairman of the Judiciary Committee
