MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN HOST: Yes, that is some cash, baby. You are doing good out here today?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, doing good.

FRANCIS: He is the not the only one turning cold weather into cold hard cash because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

Baby, it is cold outside. If you're selling ice cream or offering bike rides, you might expect to see frozen profits and patrons fleeing to the nearest coffee shop. But at the iconic Serendipity 3 in New York City, people are still lining up outside of the restaurant for a chance to sample their signature frozen hot chocolate. And the Pedicab business is also apparently booming despite the freezing conditions.

Here to explain it and braving the cold because they're all good sports, Pedicab operator, Dior Isfandiyor. We also have a Serendipity spokesman Joe Calderone. And joining us from Chicago is FOX Business reporter, Jeff Flock.

Jeff, I have to start with you, because I have no idea why you're standing on top of a giant frozen mountain of ice. Is somebody making money off that?

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It beats standing underneath it, I suspect. Yes, actually, we're in the Pilson neighborhood of Chicago. And if you look, that is the polar ice company. And the sign is almost covered with a pile of snow.

You know what happens when you get temperatures this low, the snow doesn't go anywhere. You just have to keep moving it around. And this is where they moved it here. The seasonal employees are making money moving the snow. That is one way to go in addition to the ice business which continues. You know, they sell dry ice all year-round. Shipments go out. They still have to have ice. Who knew?

FRANCIS: Will be fine. Why would people be buying giant blocks of ice when there is ice outside? You're saying the business is booming there?

FLOCK: How about dry ice? These guys supply air France. And so, there are shipments every day going overseas. And so, these guys have to continue to supply that.

FRANCIS: OK.

FLOCK: And look what they're dealing with outside the ice house. Look what the street looks like.

FRANCIS: It is ironic.

FLOCK: Yes, these poor people.

FRANCIS: It is ironic.

FLOCK: Pretty funny.

FRANCIS: Yes.

Joe Calderone, let me ask you. You know, Serendipity 3 I have one of the famous frozen hot chocolates here on set with me. People are still lining up to come in, and have -- there it is, doesn't it look delicious? They're coming in to get frozen hot chocolates in weather like this? I don't believe you.

JOE CALDERONE, SPOKESPERSON, SERENDIPITY: Yes. No, we sell more, just as many frozen hot chocolates during the winter months that we do during the summer. You know, everybody in the cold weather, everyone wants comfort and what is more comforting than a frozen hot chocolate or bit bowl of ice cream.

FRANCIS: How about a hot, hot chocolate? I think that would be more comforting. I mean, you kind of led me right to that one, more comforting than frozen hot chocolate in cold weather? I could think of 50 things including hot cookies, coffee, regular hot chocolate. Will they still really line up?

Now, your story is so famous. I've been down there with my kids and there is huge line in front. You wait forever to get in. Are you telling me in the arctic weather today there were still people lining up in front?

CALDERONE: Yes, there were still people lining up in front and all coming for the iconic frozen hot chocolate -- frozen.

FRANCIS: Yes. That video must not be from today then.

Dior, let me ask you.

DIOR ISFANDIYOR, PEDICAB DRIVER: Yes, ma'am.

FRANCIS: I mean, after drinking my frozen hot chocolate, the next thing I think I would not do is get in a pedicab to drive around the city, because that would be frozen. Did anyone get in your pedicab today?

ISFANDIYOR: Yes, we got a lot of customers today. You know, after drinking hot chocolate I would say, you know, I will take customers, say you like to go dancing and get in the pedicab.

FRANCIS: What do you do to keep them warm in there because, I don't know, there is a little plastic thing on the front there that --?

ISFANDIYOR: This is like going proof Cowell so wind down go inside. There is also like a blanket like I have, I it is like an old blanket Gortex blanket. It consumes like the wind coming inside. That is why is like -- and it goes, it is a little fun to do. People like to do. I mean a lot of people, I think, if somebody don't ride the pedicab in New York City, I would stay they didn't see New York so.

FRANCIS: Yes.

So Dior, you know, my insides were frozen from the frozen hot chocolate and I got inside your pedicab and pedaled around the city to freeze the outside of my body, what would that cost me?

ISFANDIYOR: I mean, you mean like how much it costs?

FRANCIS: Yes. What does it cost per minute? What will you charge me to freeze my Tucus off out there?

ISFANDIYOR: We have new regulation. We have in the summertime like $2, $3 per minute the ride. But basically, we give the customers more discount in wintertime because, like you know, more want to ride. So, we give them more --

FRANCIS: So, did you charge less today? Is that what you're saying?

ISFANDIYOR: Yes, like a cab. Also pedicab is like a per minute ride. No additional fees. And like companies gives us receipt so we give them receipt after like -- after finishing the ride.

FRANCIS: Do you mind if I ask you how much money you made today? I mean, how many people actually volunteered to get in that pedicab and go around city?

ISFANDIYOR: Like basically, like, the -- because I rent from the company, so like, basically it is like half and half. Like how much every day you make half for company, half for yourself. And also including the -- you pay taxes also.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, I hate taxes. Don't even get me started on that one. Anyone who watches the show knows about that.

Joe, let me ask you would you get in his cab and let him drive you back to serendipity 3 or too cold.

CALDERONE: Sure.

FRANCIS: I don't believe you.

CALDERONE: No. I will put my hood on. Sure. It beats walking, that's for sure.

ISFANDIYOR: Why not?

FRANCIS: You guys are very good sports. Thank you so much.

I will enjoy my frozen hot chocolate. Dior, stay there, I will be done in 55 minutes. We'll head uptown, OK.

ISFANDIYOR: No problem. OK.

FRANCIS: Thank you. And thanks to Jeff Flock as well who I think, you know, is still on top of the ice mountain out there. There he is.

Thanks, guys.

FLOCK: You're welcome.

FRANCIS: Clearly, it is still freezing out there.

The last thing you feel like doing is slapping your laundry through the polar vortex to the Laundromat, right? But if you're down to the last pair of socks, I have to be honest you don't have much of a choice until now! We have entrepreneur who is putting the convenience back into the cleaning service industry and offering pretty competitive prices like the Uber-for laundry. He is going to be here with all the not so dirty details. Stick around for some of that coming up in spare change later in the show.

Up next, it is as cool as it sounds, using Google glass in a crowded parking lot to pinpoint exactly where your car is. Even unlocking and starting it with just a look on a tab. Hyundai is getting Google up and we're going live to Las Vegas for details.

And the U.S. bobsled team is going for gold in a BMW. It is faster and sleeker than ever before. We're talking the brains behind it all.

More "Money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: The consumer electronics show is in full swing and today we're talking about an automaker partnering with Google glass. Controversial? Some say yes. One San Diego woman just got pulled over and ticketed for driving while wearing Google glass. Auto companies and Google glass aren't the best of friend. But one car company is standing out from all the rest in its completely embracing it.

Hyundai announced its new genesis 2015 sedan interacts with the driver through Google glass. Here with all details is Hyundai executive director Barry Ratzlaff and Shelly Palmer is our tech expert who is right next to him to sort of give us his take.

Barry, let me start with you. Are you concerned at all? I mean, we are talking about somebody just got ticketed. And a lot of people are concerned about safety of pairing drivers with those who are wearing, you know, Google glass?

BARRY RATZLAFF, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, HYUNDAI: Yes, you know it is a very important point. Let me just start off by saying that driver distraction is extremely important topic and fundamentally people should not play with their smartphones while driving. And in fact, a lot of what we're trying to do here is help solve the issue.

It is an important point to note that the Google glass app we developed for Hyundai (INAUDIBLE) is intended for use when you are outside the car in pre-drive experience. In fact, we are trying to take some of things you would normally do in the car, save you some time and help you do them before you enter the car.

FRANCIS: Can I ask you because you obviously have them on. Are you distracted right now? What are you looking at? Are they just clear?

RATZLAFF: They're clear. I'm looking in at the camera. They're really out of -- they are kind in the periphery of my vision so I can look up to see the screen when I need to, but I concentrate on task at hand without being distracted as well.

FRANCIS: Can police tell if you have them on and you're actually using them or if you're just wearing them and like you are and not doing with them?

RATZLAFF: So, I am actually I have a screen cast here. So, you can see exactly what I'm seeing in my Google glass. This is the genesis app. I can enter the app and just give you a flavor for kind of things we can do. Remote features. Some things like, it is a little bit of lag time here for the display. Sorry. POI surge. We can do dealer search. So, this is exactly what I'm seeing in the screen.

FRANCIS: So, part of the advertisement was that it can help you find your car if you can't find it in a parking lot, is that right? How does it do that?

RATZLAFF: Yes. It is.

So, we -- Blue link has invented cellular modem, built in to the car so we can connect to the car remotely, the owner can. We have got smartphone app, the glass, app from a Web site. You can locate your car. Say, you forgot where you where you park it in airport parking lot or football game in crowded parking lot. Like how many times have you wandered around trying to find the car, we are providing a solution for that.

FRANCIS: Right or if you had too many drinks, it can find your care for you. That is perfect.

Shelly, what do you think of this? I mean, is this going to be hit?

SHELLY PALMER, TECH EXPERT: This is earl days. First of all, Google glass is not product, it's a concept. And when I look at Google glass helps me look into the future. It tells me nothing about the present. And though apps like this are really awesome because they tell us what we can expect the future, and I mean, the future social logically, not technologically.

These things that we do now are all about how we, as human beings are going to be exo-digitally enhanced. But what is different here is instead of having to look at my smartphone which I carry with me all the time I have a heads up display. So, human beings with heads up displays -- that is the story here. The idea using that I'm using it to get into the car or out of the car, that's a real question. Distracted driving is the number one worst thing you can do in the world.

FRANCIS: Right.

PALMER: So, let's not even start to talk about it. Let's talk -- and you certainly don't need to put on a pair of Google glass to find your car, whether drunk or sober. What you do need to do --

FRANCIS: That is joke, by the way, obviously.

PALMER: No, no, no. But it is not a joke, Melissa. It is actually the whole point. The point is that what we have now is we have a heads up display for people. We're tied to our phone. It outsourced our memory and we got, of course, all wave finding. This is how we can see it better. I'm faster at seeing things. I have mine on with --

FRANCIS: Yes. I was going to ask you that. Are those regular glass or they are Google glass and --

PALMER: No, this is my glasses with Google glass but I'm seeing notifications. People are texting me, hey, Shelly. I'm getting some tweets right now. So, you're on FOX. It is like, that's awesome. I'm seeing you and seeing that. I don't have to look at my phone to do it. I know I'm getting tweeted.

FRANCIS: Barry, let me ask you, you know, about crossover of two these two products here because Google glass, you know, is really marketed to someone who spends a lot of money, is pretty tech-savvy and is relatively high-end. I think of Hyundai buyers as being, you know, very focused on a bargain and good deal. I'm not sure there is a lot of crossover between those two markets.

RATZLAFF: You know, Shelly, Melissa, you couldn't have given me a better setup. On Monday at the Detroit auto show we are going to announce the next version of our Hyundai Genesis. It is premium rear wheel drive sedan aimed at up market customers. And yes, we're still a value brand. You get a lot of car for your money. But it is fantastic premium product and it is the first vehicle that we're using to launch our generation (INAUDIBLE) platform which allows to do great stuff like the Google glass app.

FRANCIS: OK. All right, guys, thank you so much. Send me your glasses. I need to try those out.

BMW is going for the gold. The U.S. Olympic team has not won a gold medal in the bobsled race in 78 years. But BMW is hoping to help turn that around. The automaker designed a brand new high-speed sled for team USA this year. Will it win?

Here now is the president and CEO of BMW North America, Ludwig Willisch.

Thanks so much for joining us.

LUDWIG WILLISCH, PRESIDENT, CEO, BMW NORTH AMERICA: My pleasure.

FRANCIS: So, it is going to win?

WILLISCH: Sure. That's we are. They're going for gold.

FRANCIS: What makes the bobsled special?

WILLISCH: We designed it from scratch. And you know, we can do best is build fast, dynamic vehicles except this time it doesn't have wheels.

FRANCIS: Right.

WILLISCH: So we started building it as I said from scratch with carbon fiber body as it has minimum weight, we could play around with the center of gravity as we like, as we started building the sled as we need it. And we also went to put it into a wind tunnel. It is really top of the art --

FRANCIS: Have you done this before?

WILLISCH: No, we haven't. But we have California-based company called Design Works that can design basically everything. And the designer that actually has done the sled used to design race cars.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: So, he was up for the challenge and that's what it is.

FRANCIS: Is that a lot of pressure? Because if we lose, I am going to blame you.

WILLISCH: Go ahead.

FRANCIS: No -

WILLISCH: We're really confident. Just look at the track record so far. This season we've had four gold medals, five silver, five bronze. So we're knocking it out of the park.

FRANCIS: You talked about the carbon fiber body. And obviously, that is technology that a lot of people are fascinated with, that is new, that is very much state-of-the-art. Has that been done before with bobsleds?

WILLISCH: No, it hasn't. But we have leveraged our knowledge from our new BMW I brand that these cars are made out of carbon fiber reinforced plastic. And so, we're building cars with that material.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: And we could actually, you know, use our knowledge and put, go right ahead and build a body like we were.

FRANCIS: The show is called "Money." So I have to ask you about the dollars of all this. Did they pay you or is this about product --?

WILLISCH: No, this is part of our support for the BMW, for the U.S. Olympic team. We supported them during the Olympics in London two years ago. And now we're supporting them for the winter Olympics. That is part of our commitment to the U.S.

FRANCIS: So, you pay for the sponsorship and you also provide the bobsled.

WILLISCH: Yes.

FRANCIS: Did they give you discount on sponsorship because you give them the equipment they really need?

WILLISCH: They love the bobsled.

FRANCIS: Yes. I was kind of kidding and kind of not.

What is the process of designing the bobsled? I mean, how involved were the actual athletes themselves? Did they test it? Tell me about the process.

WILLISCH: Yes, absolutely. I mean, first of all, we looked what was around so far. Then we went to the drawing board and said, what would a optimal sled look like? And, put it into the wind tunnel knew what regulations were. And then, of course, had some prototypes that we tested and we made changes. But we knew what it would be all about, what was necessary to make the thing fast.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: Which we, anyway, know how to make things fast.

FRANCIS: You're a German company. Why are you doing this for the U.S.A. instead of Germany?

WILLISCH: Well, as our chairman has said quite a while ago, U.S. is our second home and we've been committed to the U.S. for more than 40 years. So, that what's we do here.

FRANCIS: OK, thank you so much. A lot of fun! We look forward to seeing that.

All right, coming up, are unpaid internships ruining the American dream? More and more young people are expected to work for free and the backlash is growing. We're talking to one group taking the issue all the way to the White House.

And you better pack your bags and book yourself a one-way ticket out west because that is where the jobs are. We have a list of the best cities for job growth when we get back. You will be surprised by some of them. Yes, that one is obvious, but we have some surprises too.

Do you ever have too much "Money?"

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether you spent it fetching coffee or doing research or running errand, you probably remember the first internship, but did it ruin the American dream for you?

Mikey Franklin is cofounder of Fair Pay Campaign and says that unpaid internships are ruing it for everyone. How so?

MIKEY FRANKLIN, COFOUNDER, FAIR PAY CAMPAIGN: Thank you for having me. Ultimately, the American dream is about opportunity to everyone. And unpaid internships are only open to people that can afford to work for free. If we are really committed to the notion that everyone who works hard should be able to get ahead, we got to make sure that all jobs, including internships, pay a wage.

FRANCIS: OK. Mickey, I have to stop you and disagree with you right there. Because I worked two and three jobs during a semester so that I could afford to do unpaid internship in this industry because I wanted to, because I was hungry. You don't have to be rich. You have to be industrious and hungry to work and save the money to go do the internship. I mean, that is part of what it does. It separates out the people who are really focused and driven and the people who won't show up unless you give them money.

FRANKLIN: But people who have wealthy family to support them, who have independent wealth, they don't have to be hungry or driven. They can just show up anyway.

FRANCIS: but I think somebody who is hiring interns can smell that. And I mean, as somebody who has interns around all the time, you know the rich kids and then you know kid really focused and want to be there. So I don't think that argument really holds water. You have another one?

FRANKLIN: We've got plenty of arguments.

FRANCIS: OK.

FRANKLIN: Another really important argument is that everyone's work has dignity. Everyone's work has value. It has nothing more important teaching people the work they're doing is important. And in this society, the way we do that is by paying them a wage.

FRANCIS: I think that what an intern is getting not being paid is knowledge. In most cases, interns are not doing work that is worth paying. They're mostly watching and maybe by the end of the summer or the semester they're contributing something. But for the most part, they are not worth paying. So, if you had to pay them you wouldn't have them and that internship would just go away.

FRANKLIN: You know, Melissa, I speak to hundreds of interns. I was an intern myself. I don't hear from interns saying they were sitting and watching. I hear from interns who say that they were doing substantive and important work.

Let's take example of interns on production of black swan who sued FOX searchlight successfully. They were not sitting around watching. They were doing important tasks. They were runners on set of the film. They were doing work that needed to be done. So, we are saying they deserved a wage.

FRANCIS: I think in that case in particular, you know, I mean, they were doing a lot of grunt work and running work and you're right, that that is a type of situation where they would just hire professionals. So, if they're forced to be paid they would have hired someone in the industry. And those kids that were hired in that case would not have gotten that job and wouldn't have gotten a break in the industry.

I mean, they were doing work for free as way to get into the industry. If that were a paid position, there are about 2,000, 3,000 people in Hollywood that would have gobbled it up. And those interns would not have the opportunity or not gotten into the business.

FRANKLIN: I'm sorry. I don't understand your question. I mean, of course, I disagree with your, with your assertion.

FRANCIS: I'm saying those two people, would not have gotten that job if it was paid. It would have gone to someone with a resume' who had a background because there are tons of people in Hollywood who want that job.

So, is that OK with you, that if it is paid, those students who had the job with a break in industry, you don't get a leg up, you don't get the entrance in to the industry? Instead, it goes to somebody already there. Is that OK with you?

FRANKLIN: That is clearly not going to happen. First of all it wasn't job, it was internship. If it was a job it would be paid.

FRANCIS: You're saying pay them. That makes it a job, not internship any longer.

FRANKLIN: The internship, the film industry or the political industry or journalism industry, every industry has to keep on bringing in new people. Every industry needs new talent, new graduates, new workers keen to learn and develop the industry.

FRANCIS: Not in Hollywood. They have more people than can possibly fill. I mean, they have more people than can fill all jobs they have in Hollywood. No one would ever get a start in Hollywood at this point. I mean, there are so many unemployed people walking around Hollywood. I mean, there are industries that can just afford to do it. the industry is, I mean, that is where the unpaid internships go -

FRANKLIN: FOX searchlight can afford to do this. FOX searchlight can afford this as every other production company asking can they not? FOX searchlight is part of billion dollar parent company. The notion of they can afford $7.25 an hour --

FRANCIS: I didn't say they can't afford it. No one ever said that. Of course, they absolutely can afford. But then, no one who is new in the industry would ever get in because you would get somebody who has a resume' would get that job. They can definitely afford it.

FRANKLIN: But every other industry and every other country where the practice changed demonstrates that is not true, other industries in which these practice is less widespread, particularly tech industry. The big tech organization is hugely competitive to work there. They all pay their interns in fair wage, but they are still attracting and bringing in talented young workers and new staff.

FRANCIS: Mikey, thanks so much for coming on. We appreciate your thoughts.

FRANKLIN: Thank you so much for your time.

FRANCIS: Up next, is anyone you know looking for a job? Then stick around. We have the top cities across America for job growth. And you won't believe what's on the list.

And "who made Money today?" This pop siren was rolling in the cash when she released her hit album back in 2011. But rumor has it she is still laughing all the way to the bank three years later.

"Piles of Money" coming right up. That is so obvious, come on.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: The top cities or job growth across America, did your town make the list? A new study from the Milken Institute ranks the best places to be, and here with the big reveal is the man behind the report, chief research officer at the Milken Institute, Ross DeVol. We've also got Fortune editor, Adam Lashinsky, who is a Fox News contributor. Thanks to both of you. Ross, let me start with you. What is the number one city on the list?

ROSS DEVOL, CHIEF RESEARCH OFFICER, MILKEN INSTITUTE: It's Austin, and thanks for having me on, Melissa. Austin has been a perennial top performer. It's a city that has both technology, it has low business costs, it has low regulatory environment, and is overall very business friendly, and also is the top university if you receive Texas, Austin.

FRANCIS: Is it basically all tech jobs? I mean, what's available in Austin?

DEVOL: It's not all tech jobs, but certainly, the leading growth has been in the technology area. Computer systems analysts, for example, make over $82,000 in Austin substantially above the national average wage for all industries.

FRANCIS: Adam, I mean, you're a tech guru, is this whole study going to be in your -- anticipation is going to all be about places where computer programmers can get jobs? Is that what the future is?

ADAM LASHINSKY, FORTUNE SENIOR EDITOR-AT-LARGE: Well, it's not only where the future is but where the growth is now. These sorts of studies show where jobs are growing. I've been a witness to what's going on in San Francisco, which you know, interestingly, has none of the things that Ross mentioned with the exception of a vibrant technology business and great universities, but it's not a great business environment.

It's not a low cost place to live or to hire, and yet, the San Francisco did extremely well on the list for that reason.

FRANCIS: That's true. I mean, it's number three on the list. So, it may be a great place for job growth but it's not where you would necessarily want to move to have those jobs. I mean, the cost of housing, for example, is just a fortune. So, Ross, I mean, do you compensate for that on the list at all?

DEVOL: Well, no, we don't compensate. We don't measure housing costs. In fact, places that have low housing cost have very low job growth because there's no demand. A person going to a tech job in San Francisco to work for sales for Oracle or Twitter, they're looking for the next breakthrough technology to really hit it, and it's not just about the wages, it's also about stock options to be able to cash-in someday.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, and actually, I'll correct you on your own study, because you talk about the cost-of-living. Number two on your list is Provo, Utah and the average cost of living there is eight percent below the national average. So, to me, of all the ones on your list, that seem like sort of the pick of the litter because there's a lot of job growth there, but the cost of living is lower. How is that possible? Ross.

DEVOL: Well, it's an emerging technologies center. It doesn't have the concentration of technology that Austin, San Jose, or San Francisco has. But it's -- using that university, the Brigham Young University which has been spending out technology firms and working with the companies they have there such as Nuvel (ph) in the software field, and they've been very successful. So, there's no one strategy, there's some low cost, low regulation areas, but you can offset that by being very innovative in places like San Francisco and San Jose.

FRANCIS: Adam, what kind of jobs are we talking about here? For people who are out there watching this and are saying, I don't know, maybe I can go and get retrained and learn to do something in a tech industry, because this is where all the jobs are? You know, what kind of jobs are we talking about?

LASHINSKY: My sense is those aren't the kinds of jobs that Ross is talking about at all, certainly not in San Francisco. What we have here for the second time in my short 15 -- almost 15 years here is a gold rush mentality, right? So, young people in particular looking for their fame and fortune as a metaphor are coming here to do whatever they can do. So, if their computer programmers, they're right in the sweet spot.

But, when there's so much money slashing around as there is today, everybody else is looking for a way to make a buck on it, too.

FRANCIS: Right.

LASHINSKY: I don't think there's a huge opportunity for retraining, though, to be candid.

FRANCIS: So, Ross, I mean, does that mean are you better off going to a place like San Francisco where everybody is going to seek their fame and fortune or are you better off going to one of the up and coming cities on this list like Provo, for example? I mean, is there actually more opportunity there because it's a less popular place to go?

DEVOL: It really depends upon what your motivational factors are. If you really want to be with the best and brightest are and hit it big in the technology area, you have that opportunity, the San Franciscos, the Cambridge Massachusetts, the San Joses, Silicon Valley, and the places you want to be, but there are some sleepers out there --

FRANCIS: Yes.

DEVOL: -- that are newly emerging technology centers such Raleigh and Cary, North Carolina. You can look at Portland. Seattle is on our list as well in the top 10. So, there's no one prescription, there's no one place to go, but if you're looking for a more family-friendly atmosphere, you know, eventually maybe you want to get married and have kids, A Provo, Salt Lake City are very attractive.

FRANCIS: Adam, I mean, what about that? Were you surprised to see Utah twice in the top five?

LASHINSKY: No. There's always been a vibrant technology seen or at least there has been for the past 20 years. Of course, they have several good universities in the area. And it's close to nature.

I think it's a place where people enjoy living and I smiled when Ross said about if you want to have a family, that -- for whatever reason, for various reasons, Utah is a very family friendly place, there's no doubt, as someone who is raising a family in San Francisco that San Francisco is a less family friendly place. So, it depends not only --

FRANCIS: Wait, why is it less family friendly?

LASHINSKY: It's expensive. The schools are a challenge. You know, to find a place to live is both difficult and extremely expensive. These are all things that make you work harder -- challenges if you want to raise a family in a particular area. I'm not saying you can't do it. I'm doing it.

FRANCIS: Yes.

LASHINSKY: But it would be easier to go to a lesser market.

FRANCIS: Yes. No. I just want to clarify that for audience. They're not hostile to kids. It's that it's really expensive and it's hard to get into school. I don't know or maybe --

(CROSSTALK)

LASHINSKY: Some have argued that the city of San Francisco is. There've been studies about how families flee San Francisco as soon as kids get to be school age. I'm not necessarily taking that position, but you're not far off.

FRANCIS: OK. Guys, thanks to both of you. A lot of great information there. Appreciate it.

DEVOL: You're welcome, Melissa. Thank you.

FRANCIS: Coming up, forget the year-end bonus, workers want incentive right here, right now. In fact, one study says making employees wait months and months for a bonus can do a company more harm than good. What do you think? Is the once a year bonus keeping you loyal? Watch and tweet me about what you think. Our "Money Talker" panel is ready to go, because at the end of the day, it is all about cold hard cash.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: So, did you start off the brand New Year with a bonus? If you did, was it cold hard cash or a hearty handshake? Companies and employees are ever debating the benefits of the bonus. Is it is a gesture of thanks from employee's hard work or has it become a source of competition and entitlement? And most importantly, at the end of the day, do they even work?

Our "Money Talker" panel is ready to battle over bonuses. We have Julie Roginsky, Mercedes Colwin, and Jack Burkman. What do you, guys, think? What do you think? Is money a motivator? What do you think, Julie?

JULIE ROGINSKY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: So, I'm a champ, because I always give my assistant a bonus every year --

FRANCIS: Yes.

ROGINSKY: He'll tell you right now --

FRANCIS: He knows how much is --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: It's kind of like it's gotten to -- he's been with me for 11 years. so, it's gotten to the point where --

FRANCIS: Something is working. He's been with you for 11 years.

ROGINSKY: He's just probably -- get another job. Knowing him --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: I know, but actually, why would you? Like, you know, you're getting a bonus on top of your salary. It's got for good (ph) one year. I didn't give him a bonus, he'd be like --

FRANCIS: He'd be furious.

ROGINSKY: He'd probably furious. So, you know, I don't know. But I think what's more motivating is actually a hearty thank you. I really do --

FRANCIS: Really?

JACK BURKMAN, RADIO HOST: Oh, come on!

(CROSSTALK)

BURKMAN: The bonuses cost -- I don't care if you're talking about Goldman or if you're talking about my little radio show, if you're talking about a restaurant, anything in between, bonuses cost very, very little. Companies get a huge upside for very little money. Worse part of it is if you don't pay it, there's a huge downside, because people expect this at Christmas --

FRANCIS: Right.

BURKMAN: -- from my lobbying firm, I mean, I don't know. You spend 10 grand, 15 grand on Christmas. I get a million bucks in upside for spending --

FRANCIS: How do you measure that? How do you know that?

BURKMAN: Well, you know it by the way people approach their job. You know it by the way they look when they come in the morning --

FRANCIS: So, why do it once a year then? Because that's one of the points of this is that maybe the bonus works, but doing it once a year doesn't keep -- people motivated --

BURKMAN: For tradition.

FRANCIS: It motivates them in November.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: It motivates them in April.

MERCEDES COLWIN, ATTORNEY: And that's a big issue. So, if it's only going to be once a year at the end of the year, then suddenly, that last quarter, their behavior is going to get better.

FRANCIS: Right.

COLWIN: They're going to be much more industrious. They're going to work a lot harder. Well, you know what, that shouldn't be the case. Start doing it quarterly, start doing it from the beginning. And frankly, it really is generational, too.

FRANCIS: Yes.

COLWIN: If you're talking about the folks that -- the new millennials --

FRANCIS: Yes.

COLWIN: -- they want money.

(CROSSTALK)

BURKMAN: If you break it up, the problem is that it's too small and it doesn't have the impact. If you build the excitement and the anticipation, you hit them at the end, anticipation everybody thinks in terms of the holiday bonus whether you're the investment banker that wants to, you know, by the emerald for your girlfriend or whether you're the poor person that needs to pay the tuition, they all wait for that holiday --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: It was interesting in this business article. They said, studies have shown that financial incentives are poor motivators. I clicked through on the studies, and it went to like a YouTube video. I don't know what studies --

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: -- that money doesn't (ph) motivate. Julie, money motivates.

ROGINSKY: No. And I do what I do because I'm a champ, but I think what actually motivates is if you treat your staff well if they do a good job --

FRANCIS: That actually should be both.

ROGINSKY: Yes, you do, but how many people, actually -- and a lot of people I know who work in investment banking, although, they're motivated primarily by money, but people who are not necessarily just motivated by that get offended because they truly hate their bosses. They do what they need to do --

BURKMAN: But the Christmas bonus makes up for hatred of the bosses.

ROGINSKY: It does but it doesn't provide the good work ethic that you want because if you're actually -- if you know your boss appreciates you --

FRANCIS: So, how do you fix that? How do you -- I mean, some of the suggestions are, you know, that you built out a way that they can anticipate what they're going to get based on goals. I mean, do you do that? Do you sort of set expectations --

BURKMAN: Here's the thing, if you do that, it's easy to say that, but then it becomes part of their salary.

FRANCIS: Yes.

BURKMAN: In other words, if you say, OK, we're going to split the Christmas bonus into five things, they say, oh, that salary. Now, the holiday is coming, there's no bang. There's no push. So then, it just all becomes salary. You have to -- it's like Henry Ford. You have to play a little bit of psychological game with the workers. It's money, yes, but it's also, you have to kind of trick them. It's psychology.

FRANCIS: That is so ugly and it's so true. I mean, either of you guys want to disagree with --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: No. I don't practice it, because as I said an (INAUDIBLE), but what you said is --

BURKMAN: You're just a better person.

ROGINSKY: Yes. I kind of --

COLWIN: I'm a true Democrat. I give it away.

(LAUGHTER)

COLWIN: The money, nothing else, but yes.

FRANCIS: I mean, it's about --

(CROSSTALK)

COLWIN: Talking about the bonuses. Nothing else.

FRANCIS: But it is a little bit about that element of surprise, right? I mean, isn't there that game where if you really like an employee, you're trying to anticipate what they think they're going to get and then surprise them a little bit to the upside? Is there a punishment? I mean, do you take the person who is not as good as they should have been and you still give them something but it's less from they anticipated? It's getting a little tricky.

COLWIN: Yes, it gets tricky, but -- I mean, certainly in our industry. If you're not doing well as a lawyer, you really can't compensate this individual, whether it's a bonus or salary, some other incentives, you really have to have some punitive measure with the attorneys. I think it depends on --

FRANCIS: So, how does the conversation go at Christmas time? I mean, do you bring someone in and you say, I know, you think you're getting a bonus but you're not?

COLWIN: Yes.

FRANCIS: Have you done that?

COLWIN: Absolutely. Unquestionably.

FRANCIS: Does the person cry? Do they throw things at you? Have you called security --

(LAUGHTER)

COLWIN: It hasn't gotten that bad, but yes. I mean, they do. They get really upset. And also, they're like, what? I mean, especially lawyers who have a pretty healthy ego. They're like -- you mean, we don't walk on water? We're not the best thing going? How could you not see how brilliant and great I am?

FRANCIS: Yes.

COLWIN: You got to deal and compete with that ego, too. But no, the bottom line --

BURKMAN: We run the car business. The family was in the car business. There's an old saying, 20 percent of the salesman make 80 percent of the sales. But what you got to do is you have to highly compensate the producers, quickly weed out (ph) and get rid of everybody else. That's the key to business.

(CROSSTALK)

BURKMAN: And bonuses are part --

ROGINSKY: But to your point, I think if somebody is really bad, you don't not give them a bonus, you just fire them, which I've got to do. If they're not good, you just -- they have to go.

BURKMAN: Yes.

FRANCIS: What about non-monetary things? I mean, is that just a total waste of time and people are looking and they want cash? I mean -- this article as well that said the money doesn't motivate. It's says you could give out gift baskets. I think the employee, he'll get status (ph) like, what did you spend on this and why didn't you just give me the 300 bucks or whatever it is? I mean, isn't that true?

BURKMAN: Yes. You can't insult them. You know, that's like saying I'm going to give them a book or something for Christmas. You just have to make a quick decision like we've been saying if there -- it's the Henry Ford thing. If they're a good employee, you want them heavily compensated. Bonus is part of that. If not, boot (ph) --

FRANCIS: Yes. All right. Wow! Very -- harsh but enlightening. Thanks, you guys.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Coming up, New York is one of the most progressive cities in the world, but when it comes to laundry, it is stuck in the dark ages. Well, forget about slamming it down the Laundromat when innovative businessman is turning your undies into big box. Don't move. You can never have too much MONEY.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: It's time for a little fun with "Spare Change." It may seem like a simple mundane task, but hardly, anyone loves doing laundry. The concept of paying for pick up isn't new but using your phone for your dirty desk (ph) could be the next big thing. Seth Berkowitz is co-founder of the new service, FlyCleaners, and he hopes this idea is the answer to all your problems.

So Seth, we were talking about in the commercial break, from the front of my apartment, if I pair off (ph) the window, I can see three different dry cleaners that I could call and they would come over in a second and do my laundry and bring it back. Why do I need your app?

SETH BERKOWITZ, FLY CLEANERS CO-FOUNDER AND CEO: Will they do it at 11 o'clock at night?

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: On a Sunday?

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: That would be a very big difference.

FRANCIS: OK. So, I can find any time of day?

BERKOWITZ: So, we're open from 6:00 a.m. to midnight seven days a week.

FRANCIS: And how long does it take for them to get the laundry back?

BERKOWITZ: So, we have an instant pick-up model where it will come to your house sometimes within 30 minutes, sometimes less, actually checked the app -- is 26 minutes would have been in my house (ph). But it can be back. The app will keep you posted and we'll be back at your house as soon as the next instant pickup. So --

FRANCIS: So, wait. So, you bring it back the next day? I mean, if it's Sunday night and I'm looking to get my, you know, socks picked up. I'm pretty desperate. So, I need it back pretty quick.

BERKOWITZ: All right. So, for a typical cleaning, for laundry, it can be the same day. If we picked it up on Sunday night, would it be Sunday --

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: Monday in afternoon, but for dry cleaning, it could be up to 48 hours.

FRANCIS: You charge a premium for this?

BERKOWITZ: We don't. We actually have very competitive pricing.

FRANCIS: So, how do you make money then because the show is called MONEY? I didn't know if you know that. How do you make money?

BERKOWITZ: So, there's no brick and mortar model here. This is entirely delivery basing technology. So, we're not paying for retail space on the corner of Broadway and --

FRANCIS: But if you're charging $0.99 a pound in the dry cleaners or the Laundromat is making part of that money, it's hard for me to imagine that you're making very much money on this.

BERKOWITZ: There's margin in it. You scale up the business and it can be very successful.

FRANCIS: You were not a newbie to this business of waving your phone or your iPad and getting something done. You started a very successful business called Insomnia Cookies.

BERKOWITZ: That's correct.

FRANCIS: That was based on a similar premise where it's people in the middle of the night who'd just really need a cinnamon oatmeal raisin cookie, and all of a sudden, they need to get their phone out and have it delivered.

BERKOWITZ: Right.

FRANCIS: That's a successful business.

BERKOWITZ: We have 43 locations. We're supposed to open one up tomorrow and six more are coming in the next three months.

FRANCIS: Forty-three locations around the country?

BERKOWITZ: Correct. Yes.

FRANCIS: There are that many people who need cookies in an instant and didn't buy, you know, the pre-made Pillsbury dough from the grocery store and pop in the oven. That's not good enough. They got to call you on the cookies?

BERKOWITZ: Well, so we have a college business market or we have locations at major college market --

FRANCIS: -- college kids, they would need cookies --

BERKOWITZ: Right. Until 3:00 in the morning is the insomnia model. So, that's a pretty robust model (ph) there.

FRANCIS: So, I imagine, the laundry would be big for them as well?

BERKOWITZ: We like a little bit more of a dense (ph) marketplace. So, New York City, big cities would be better more for FlyCleaners than Insomnia. Although, Insomnia thrives in New York City.

FRANCIS: Yes. I mean, the laundry -- the only thing about the laundry business is it does seem like something they would only work in New York because we're the only place where you would pay a million dollars for an apartment and still not have a washer and dryer inside.

BERKOWITZ: Not the only one.

FRANCIS: Where else do you think this would work?

BERKOWITZ: D.C., Boston, but there are many options. We're not sure exactly yet. We have to continue to iterate our model and see --

FRANCIS: The cookies were a huge hit. The laundry sounds like a good idea. What's your next idea?

BERKOWITZ: I don't know. it took 10 years to come up with the second one. So, we'll talk in 2020 something.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: How many laundry companies are signed up to work with you right now in New York? I mean, how big is that business?

BERKOWITZ: We have partnerships with the number of wholesalers. It's not a huge number.

FRANCIS: So, it's not like the local dry cleaner? It's not like you're farming out their business?

BERKOWITZ: No.

FRANCIS: You have like one central place the laundry is going to.

BERKOWITZ: We work with a couple of partner, couple of local partners.

FRANCIS: Yes. So, if you lose one of my socks then what? Are you down there looking in the bin for the lost sock that's gone? It's one always goes missing.

BERKOWITZ: It's true. It's not me, but I mean, FlyCleaners is built on responsibility and tremendous customer service. So, if you lost your sock, you'd e-mail us, we'd pay you back your sock.

FRANCIS: Oh, you'd pay -- you're not going to find it. See, that's honest. You just give me the money for it. No one's going to find --

(CROSSTALK)

BERKOWITZ: I've lost a million socks and I've never got anything back for it.

FRANCIS: All right. Seth, thank you so much. A lot of fun.

BERKOWITZ: I appreciate it.

FRANCIS: Up next, "Who Made Money Today?" The soulful Brit (ph) is still making a ton of money and smashing all kinds of records despite not having an album for three years already. You want to know who it is. Keep watching. You can never have too much MONEY.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's "Who Made Money Today." Anyone who owns Constellation Brand, the wine and spirits maker is still benefiting from its buyout of beer (ph) with its latest earnings jumping by more than 90 percent. The company is so optimistic about its American beer sale that it's raised its earnings forecast for the whole year. That what's the appetite of investors everywhere.

The stock soared more than 9.5 percent. Chief executive, Rob Sands, must be pleased. He owns nearly 3.2 million shares, so he made $21 million today. I'll drink to that.

And making money for charity. Jay-Z, his controversial clothing line made headlines around the world when his retail collaborator, Barney's, was accused of racial profiling. But that hasn't stopped him from bringing the big box. In fact, it's already made more than million dollars and it all goes -- Beyonce's Sean Carter Foundation which helps out young people that can't afford to go to college. Very nice.

Making even more money. Stellar musician, Adele, the British soul diva continues to smash records with her hit album 21 nearly three years after its released. Three years. The record has become the first ever digital album to sell more than three million copies. Industry insiders are surprised it was the top-selling album in all of 2011 and 2012, but here's the weird thing, 21 was actually the 21st best-selling album of last year and also the 21st album ever surpass 10 million copies in sales. Kind of creepy, right?

All right. That's all we've got for you. I hope you made money today. Tune in tomorrow and hear Congressman David Schweikert on the war of economic mobility. It's all wrapped up in the health care -- and it's got everyone talking. That's tomorrow at 5:00 p.m. Be sure to set your DVR every day at 5:00 to get your fix of everything MONEY. We will see you back here tomorrow. "The Willis Report" is next.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5B7R-VWG1-DXH2-63DC-00000-00MONEY for January 8, 20142014-01-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMONEY5:00 PM ESTJoe Calderone; Dior Isfandiyor; Barry Ratzlaff; Shelly Palmer; Ludwig Willisch; Mikey Franklin, Ross DeVol, Adam Lashinsky, Julie Roginsky, Jack Burkman, Mercedes Colwin, Seth BerkowitzNEWSDomestic010801cb.230MONEY for January 8, 2014Melissa Francis; Jeff Flock

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN HOST: Yes, that is some cash, baby. You are doing good out here today?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, doing good.

FRANCIS: He is the not the only one turning cold weather into cold hard cash because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

Baby, it is cold outside. If you're selling ice cream or offering bike rides, you might expect to see frozen profits and patrons fleeing to the nearest coffee shop. But at the iconic Serendipity 3 in New York City, people are still lining up outside of the restaurant for a chance to sample their signature frozen hot chocolate. And the Pedicab business is also apparently booming despite the freezing conditions.

Here to explain it and braving the cold because they're all good sports, Pedicab operator, Dior Isfandiyor. We also have a Serendipity spokesman Joe Calderone. And joining us from Chicago is FOX Business reporter, Jeff Flock.

Jeff, I have to start with you, because I have no idea why you're standing on top of a giant frozen mountain of ice. Is somebody making money off that?

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It beats standing underneath it, I suspect. Yes, actually, we're in the Pilson neighborhood of Chicago. And if you look, that is the polar ice company. And the sign is almost covered with a pile of snow.

You know what happens when you get temperatures this low, the snow doesn't go anywhere. You just have to keep moving it around. And this is where they moved it here. The seasonal employees are making money moving the snow. That is one way to go in addition to the ice business which continues. You know, they sell dry ice all year-round. Shipments go out. They still have to have ice. Who knew?

FRANCIS: Will be fine. Why would people be buying giant blocks of ice when there is ice outside? You're saying the business is booming there?

FLOCK: How about dry ice? These guys supply air France. And so, there are shipments every day going overseas. And so, these guys have to continue to supply that.

FRANCIS: OK.

FLOCK: And look what they're dealing with outside the ice house. Look what the street looks like.

FRANCIS: It is ironic.

FLOCK: Yes, these poor people.

FRANCIS: It is ironic.

FLOCK: Pretty funny.

FRANCIS: Yes.

Joe Calderone, let me ask you. You know, Serendipity 3 I have one of the famous frozen hot chocolates here on set with me. People are still lining up to come in, and have -- there it is, doesn't it look delicious? They're coming in to get frozen hot chocolates in weather like this? I don't believe you.

JOE CALDERONE, SPOKESPERSON, SERENDIPITY: Yes. No, we sell more, just as many frozen hot chocolates during the winter months that we do during the summer. You know, everybody in the cold weather, everyone wants comfort and what is more comforting than a frozen hot chocolate or bit bowl of ice cream.

FRANCIS: How about a hot, hot chocolate? I think that would be more comforting. I mean, you kind of led me right to that one, more comforting than frozen hot chocolate in cold weather? I could think of 50 things including hot cookies, coffee, regular hot chocolate. Will they still really line up?

Now, your story is so famous. I've been down there with my kids and there is huge line in front. You wait forever to get in. Are you telling me in the arctic weather today there were still people lining up in front?

CALDERONE: Yes, there were still people lining up in front and all coming for the iconic frozen hot chocolate -- frozen.

FRANCIS: Yes. That video must not be from today then.

Dior, let me ask you.

DIOR ISFANDIYOR, PEDICAB DRIVER: Yes, ma'am.

FRANCIS: I mean, after drinking my frozen hot chocolate, the next thing I think I would not do is get in a pedicab to drive around the city, because that would be frozen. Did anyone get in your pedicab today?

ISFANDIYOR: Yes, we got a lot of customers today. You know, after drinking hot chocolate I would say, you know, I will take customers, say you like to go dancing and get in the pedicab.

FRANCIS: What do you do to keep them warm in there because, I don't know, there is a little plastic thing on the front there that --?

ISFANDIYOR: This is like going proof Cowell so wind down go inside. There is also like a blanket like I have, I it is like an old blanket Gortex blanket. It consumes like the wind coming inside. That is why is like -- and it goes, it is a little fun to do. People like to do. I mean a lot of people, I think, if somebody don't ride the pedicab in New York City, I would stay they didn't see New York so.

FRANCIS: Yes.

So Dior, you know, my insides were frozen from the frozen hot chocolate and I got inside your pedicab and pedaled around the city to freeze the outside of my body, what would that cost me?

ISFANDIYOR: I mean, you mean like how much it costs?

FRANCIS: Yes. What does it cost per minute? What will you charge me to freeze my Tucus off out there?

ISFANDIYOR: We have new regulation. We have in the summertime like $2, $3 per minute the ride. But basically, we give the customers more discount in wintertime because, like you know, more want to ride. So, we give them more --

FRANCIS: So, did you charge less today? Is that what you're saying?

ISFANDIYOR: Yes, like a cab. Also pedicab is like a per minute ride. No additional fees. And like companies gives us receipt so we give them receipt after like -- after finishing the ride.

FRANCIS: Do you mind if I ask you how much money you made today? I mean, how many people actually volunteered to get in that pedicab and go around city?

ISFANDIYOR: Like basically, like, the -- because I rent from the company, so like, basically it is like half and half. Like how much every day you make half for company, half for yourself. And also including the -- you pay taxes also.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, I hate taxes. Don't even get me started on that one. Anyone who watches the show knows about that.

Joe, let me ask you would you get in his cab and let him drive you back to serendipity 3 or too cold.

CALDERONE: Sure.

FRANCIS: I don't believe you.

CALDERONE: No. I will put my hood on. Sure. It beats walking, that's for sure.

ISFANDIYOR: Why not?

FRANCIS: You guys are very good sports. Thank you so much.

I will enjoy my frozen hot chocolate. Dior, stay there, I will be done in 55 minutes. We'll head uptown, OK.

ISFANDIYOR: No problem. OK.

FRANCIS: Thank you. And thanks to Jeff Flock as well who I think, you know, is still on top of the ice mountain out there. There he is.

Thanks, guys.

FLOCK: You're welcome.

FRANCIS: Clearly, it is still freezing out there.

The last thing you feel like doing is slapping your laundry through the polar vortex to the Laundromat, right? But if you're down to the last pair of socks, I have to be honest you don't have much of a choice until now! We have entrepreneur who is putting the convenience back into the cleaning service industry and offering pretty competitive prices like the Uber-for laundry. He is going to be here with all the not so dirty details. Stick around for some of that coming up in spare change later in the show.

Up next, it is as cool as it sounds, using Google glass in a crowded parking lot to pinpoint exactly where your car is. Even unlocking and starting it with just a look on a tab. Hyundai is getting Google up and we're going live to Las Vegas for details.

And the U.S. bobsled team is going for gold in a BMW. It is faster and sleeker than ever before. We're talking the brains behind it all.

More "Money" coming up.

FRANCIS: The consumer electronics show is in full swing and today we're talking about an automaker partnering with Google glass. Controversial? Some say yes. One San Diego woman just got pulled over and ticketed for driving while wearing Google glass. Auto companies and Google glass aren't the best of friend. But one car company is standing out from all the rest in its completely embracing it.

Hyundai announced its new genesis 2015 sedan interacts with the driver through Google glass. Here with all details is Hyundai executive director Barry Ratzlaff and Shelly Palmer is our tech expert who is right next to him to sort of give us his take.

Barry, let me start with you. Are you concerned at all? I mean, we are talking about somebody just got ticketed. And a lot of people are concerned about safety of pairing drivers with those who are wearing, you know, Google glass?

BARRY RATZLAFF, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, HYUNDAI: Yes, you know it is a very important point. BMW is going for the gold. The U.S. Olympic team has not won a gold medal in the bobsled race in 78 years. But BMW is hoping to help turn that around. The automaker designed a brand new high-speed sled for team USA this year. Will it win?

Here now is the president and CEO of BMW North America, Ludwig Willisch.

Thanks so much for joining us.

LUDWIG WILLISCH, PRESIDENT, CEO, BMW NORTH AMERICA: My pleasure.

FRANCIS: So, it is going to win?

WILLISCH: Sure. That's we are. They're going for gold.

FRANCIS: What makes the bobsled special?

WILLISCH: We designed it from scratch. And you know, we can do best is build fast, dynamic vehicles except this time it doesn't have wheels.

FRANCIS: Right.

WILLISCH: So we started building it as I said from scratch with carbon fiber body as it has minimum weight, we could play around with the center of gravity as we like, as we started building the sled as we need it. And we also went to put it into a wind tunnel. It is really top of the art --

FRANCIS: Have you done this before?

WILLISCH: No, we haven't. But we have California-based company called Design Works that can design basically everything. And the designer that actually has done the sled used to design race cars.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: So, he was up for the challenge and that's what it is.

FRANCIS: Is that a lot of pressure? Because if we lose, I am going to blame you.

WILLISCH: Go ahead.

FRANCIS: No -

WILLISCH: We're really confident. Just look at the track record so far. This season we've had four gold medals, five silver, five bronze. So we're knocking it out of the park.

FRANCIS: You talked about the carbon fiber body. And obviously, that is technology that a lot of people are fascinated with, that is new, that is very much state-of-the-art. Has that been done before with bobsleds?

WILLISCH: No, it hasn't. But we have leveraged our knowledge from our new BMW I brand that these cars are made out of carbon fiber reinforced plastic. And so, we're building cars with that material.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: And we could actually, you know, use our knowledge and put, go right ahead and build a body like we were.

FRANCIS: The show is called "Money." So I have to ask you about the dollars of all this. Did they pay you or is this about product --?

WILLISCH: No, this is part of our support for the BMW, for the U.S. Olympic team. We supported them during the Olympics in London two years ago. And now we're supporting them for the winter Olympics. That is part of our commitment to the U.S.

FRANCIS: So, you pay for the sponsorship and you also provide the bobsled.

WILLISCH: Yes.

FRANCIS: Did they give you discount on sponsorship because you give them the equipment they really need?

WILLISCH: They love the bobsled.

FRANCIS: Yes. I was kind of kidding and kind of not.

What is the process of designing the bobsled? I mean, how involved were the actual athletes themselves? Did they test it? Tell me about the process.

WILLISCH: Yes, absolutely. I mean, first of all, we looked what was around so far. Then we went to the drawing board and said, what would a optimal sled look like? And, put it into the wind tunnel knew what regulations were. And then, of course, had some prototypes that we tested and we made changes. But we knew what it would be all about, what was necessary to make the thing fast.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WILLISCH: Which we, anyway, know how to make things fast.

FRANCIS: You're a German company. Why are you doing this for the U.S.A. instead of Germany?

WILLISCH: Well, as our chairman has said quite a while ago, U.S. is our second home and we've been committed to the U.S. for more than 40 years. So, that what's we do here.

FRANCIS: OK, thank you so much. A lot of fun! We look forward to seeing that.

All right, coming up, are unpaid internships ruining the American dream? More and more young people are expected to work for free and the backlash is growing. We're talking to one group taking the issue all the way to the White House.

And you better pack your bags and book yourself a one-way ticket out west because that is where the jobs are. We have a list of the best cities for job growth when we get back. You will be surprised by some of them. Yes, that one is obvious, but we have some surprises too.

Do you ever have too much "Money?"

FRANCIS: Whether you spent it fetching coffee or doing research or running errand, you probably remember the first internship, but did it ruin the American dream for you?

Mikey Franklin is cofounder of Fair Pay Campaign and says that unpaid internships are ruing it for everyone. How so?

MIKEY FRANKLIN, COFOUNDER, FAIR PAY CAMPAIGN: Thank you for having me. Ultimately, the American dream is about opportunity to everyone. And unpaid internships are only open to people that can afford to work for free. If we are really committed to the notion that everyone who works hard should be able to get ahead, we got to make sure that all jobs, including internships, pay a wage.

FRANCIS: but I think somebody who is hiring interns can smell that. And I mean, as somebody who has interns around all the time, you know the rich kids and then you know kid really focused and want to be there. So I don't think that argument really holds water. You have another one?

FRANKLIN: We've got plenty of arguments.

FRANCIS: OK.

FRANKLIN: Another really important argument is that everyone's work has dignity. Everyone's work has value. It has nothing more important teaching people the work they're doing is important. And in this society, the way we do that is by paying them a wage.

FRANKLIN: But every other industry and every other country where the practice changed demonstrates that is not true, other industries in which these practice is less widespread, particularly tech industry. (CROSSTALK)

BURKMAN: And bonuses are part --

ROGINSKY: But to your point, I think if somebody is really bad, you don't not give them a bonus, you just fire them, which I've got to do. If they're not good, you just -- they have to go.

BURKMAN: Yes.

FRANCIS: What about non-monetary things? I mean, is that just a total waste of time and people are looking and they want cash? I mean -- this article as well that said the money doesn't motivate. It's says you could give out gift baskets. I think the employee, he'll get status (ph) like, what did you spend on this and why didn't you just give me the 300 bucks or whatever it is? I mean, isn't that true?

BURKMAN: Yes. You can't insult them. You know, that's like saying I'm going to give them a book or something for Christmas. You just have to make a quick decision like we've been saying if there -- it's the Henry Ford thing. If they're a good employee, you want them heavily compensated. Bonus is part of that. If not, boot (ph) --

FRANCIS: Yes. All right. Wow! Very -- harsh but enlightening. Thanks, you guys.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Coming up, New York is one of the most progressive cities in the world, but when it comes to laundry, it is stuck in the dark ages. Well, forget about slamming it down the Laundromat when innovative businessman is turning your undies into big box. Don't move. You can never have too much MONEY.

FRANCIS: It's time for a little fun with "Spare Change." It may seem like a simple mundane task, but hardly, anyone loves doing laundry. The concept of paying for pick up isn't new but using your phone for your dirty desk (ph) could be the next big thing. Seth Berkowitz is co-founder of the new service, FlyCleaners, and he hopes this idea is the answer to all your problems.

So Seth, we were talking about in the commercial break, from the front of my apartment, if I pair off (ph) the window, I can see three different dry cleaners that I could call and they would come over in a second and do my laundry and bring it back. Why do I need your app?

SETH BERKOWITZ, FLY CLEANERS CO-FOUNDER AND CEO: Will they do it at 11 o'clock at night?

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: On a Sunday?

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: That would be a very big difference.

FRANCIS: OK. So, I can find any time of day?

BERKOWITZ: So, we're open from 6:00 a.m. to midnight seven days a week.

FRANCIS: And how long does it take for them to get the laundry back?

BERKOWITZ: So, we have an instant pick-up model where it will come to your house sometimes within 30 minutes, sometimes less, actually checked the app -- is 26 minutes would have been in my house (ph). But it can be back. The app will keep you posted and we'll be back at your house as soon as the next instant pickup. So --

FRANCIS: So, wait. So, you bring it back the next day? I mean, if it's Sunday night and I'm looking to get my, you know, socks picked up. I'm pretty desperate. So, I need it back pretty quick.

BERKOWITZ: All right. So, for a typical cleaning, for laundry, it can be the same day. If we picked it up on Sunday night, would it be Sunday --

FRANCIS: No.

BERKOWITZ: Monday in afternoon, but for dry cleaning, it could be up to 48 hours.

FRANCIS: You charge a premium for this?

BERKOWITZ: We don't. We actually have very competitive pricing.

FRANCIS: So, how do you make money then because the show is called MONEY? I didn't know if you know that. How do you make money?

BERKOWITZ: So, there's no brick and mortar model here. This is entirely delivery basing technology. So, we're not paying for retail space on the corner of Broadway and --

FRANCIS: But if you're charging $0.99 a pound in the dry cleaners or the Laundromat is making part of that money, it's hard for me to imagine that you're making very much money on this.

BERKOWITZ: There's margin in it. You scale up the business and it can be very successful.

FRANCIS: You were not a newbie to this business of waving your phone or your iPad and getting something done. You started a very successful business called Insomnia Cookies.

BERKOWITZ: That's correct.

FRANCIS: That was based on a similar premise where it's people in the middle of the night who'd just really need a cinnamon oatmeal raisin cookie, and all of a sudden, they need to get their phone out and have it delivered.

BERKOWITZ: Right.

FRANCIS: That's a successful business.

BERKOWITZ: We have 43 locations. We're supposed to open one up tomorrow and six more are coming in the next three months.

FRANCIS: Forty-three locations around the country?

BERKOWITZ: Correct. Yes.

FRANCIS: There are that many people who need cookies in an instant and didn't buy, you know, the pre-made Pillsbury dough from the grocery store and pop in the oven. That's not good enough. They got to call you on the cookies?

BERKOWITZ: Well, so we have a college business market or we have locations at major college market --

FRANCIS: -- college kids, they would need cookies --

BERKOWITZ: Right. Until 3:00 in the morning is the insomnia model. So, that's a pretty robust model (ph) there.

FRANCIS: So, I imagine, the laundry would be big for them as well?

BERKOWITZ: We like a little bit more of a dense (ph) marketplace. So, New York City, big cities would be better more for FlyCleaners than Insomnia. Although, Insomnia thrives in New York City.

FRANCIS: Yes. I mean, the laundry -- the only thing about the laundry business is it does seem like something they would only work in New York because we're the only place where you would pay a million dollars for an apartment and still not have a washer and dryer inside.

BERKOWITZ: Not the only one.

FRANCIS: Where else do you think this would work?

BERKOWITZ: D.C., Boston, but there are many options. We're not sure exactly yet. We have to continue to iterate our model and see --

FRANCIS: The cookies were a huge hit. The laundry sounds like a good idea. What's your next idea?

BERKOWITZ: I don't know. it took 10 years to come up with the second one. So, we'll talk in 2020 something.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: How many laundry companies are signed up to work with you right now in New York? I mean, how big is that business?

BERKOWITZ: We have partnerships with the number of wholesalers. It's not a huge number.

FRANCIS: So, it's not like the local dry cleaner? It's not like you're farming out their business?

BERKOWITZ: No.

FRANCIS: You have like one central place the laundry is going to.

BERKOWITZ: We work with a couple of partner, couple of local partners.

FRANCIS: Yes. So, if you lose one of my socks then what? Are you down there looking in the bin for the lost sock that's gone? It's one always goes missing.

BERKOWITZ: It's true. It's not me, but I mean, FlyCleaners is built on responsibility and tremendous customer service. So, if you lost your sock, you'd e-mail us, we'd pay you back your sock.

FRANCIS: Oh, you'd pay -- you're not going to find it. See, that's honest. You just give me the money for it. No one's going to find --

(CROSSTALK)

BERKOWITZ: I've lost a million socks and I've never got anything back for it.

FRANCIS: All right. Seth, thank you so much. A lot of fun.

BERKOWITZ: I appreciate it.

FRANCIS: Up next, "Who Made Money Today?" The soulful Brit (ph) is still making a ton of money and smashing all kinds of records despite not having an album for three years already. You want to know who it is. Keep watching. You can never have too much MONEY.

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's "Who Made Money Today." Anyone who owns Constellation Brand, the wine and spirits maker is still benefiting from its buyout of beer (ph) with its latest earnings jumping by more than 90 percent. The company is so optimistic about its American beer sale that it's raised its earnings forecast for the whole year. That what's the appetite of investors everywhere.

The stock soared more than 9.5 percent. Chief executive, Rob Sands, must be pleased. He owns nearly 3.2 million shares, so he made $21 million today. I'll drink to that.

And making money for charity. Jay-Z, his controversial clothing line made headlines around the world when his retail collaborator, Barney's, was accused of racial profiling. But that hasn't stopped him from bringing the big box. In fact, it's already made more than million dollars and it all goes -- Beyonce's Sean Carter Foundation which helps out young people that can't afford to go to college. Very nice.

Making even more money. Stellar musician, Adele, the British soul diva continues to smash records with her hit album 21 nearly three years after its released. Three years. The record has become the first ever digital album to sell more than three million copies. Industry insiders are surprised it was the top-selling album in all of 2011 and 2012, but here's the weird thing, 21 was actually the 21st best-selling album of last year and also the 21st album ever surpass 10 million copies in sales. Kind of creepy, right?

All right. That's all we've got for you. I hope you made money today. Tune in tomorrow and hear Congressman David Schweikert on the war of economic mobility. It's all wrapped up in the health care -- and it's got everyone talking. That's tomorrow at 5:00 p.m. Be sure to set your DVR every day at 5:00 to get your fix of everything MONEY. We will see you back here tomorrow. "The Willis Report" is next.
