Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:59R9-3771-F0HW-54MS-00000-00MONEY for October 31, 20132013-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMONEY for October 31, 2013

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN HOST: Think about this - if you needed surgery, would you be down with a procedure that doctors and hospitals and other places in the country, people you had never met, just to save money? It's happening more and more, because when they say it's not, it's always about money.

Sure, we all love going online to find the best deal, but usually we're talking about a hotel room, a flight, a television. Would you feel comfortable accepting online bid for hip replacement from a doctor you never met? It is newest wave in comparison shopping and the Web site METABID (ph) giving people chance to evaluate offers from doctors across the country and then travel to get the care of their choice.

Here to discuss how it all works, the president, Ralph Weber.

Ralph, what is the experience, I go online what happens?

RALPH WEBER, PRESIDENT, METABID: Well, you go online and make a request. Now, it depend if you work for employer that uses met at that bid as source care or just an individual. So, you make a request and you can put in your parameters, a few health questions, you know, your height, your weight, any medication allergies. You can put in how far you're willing to travel, if at all. And then you request a bid. You can review all the doctors' profiles. So you see where they went to medical school, what their training was, what their experience is. How many of these procedures they do every year. So you really get to see a lot about the quality of the doctor, as you make the request.

FRANCIS: wow.

WEBER: --which with traditional insurance, all you know is in network or out of network.

FRANCIS: Yes. You really don't know that much. I mean, although you are able to ask people in your community, generally, especially if your community is smaller that everybody sort of knows everybody. I have a lot of questions about all that.

OK. So, if I'm an individual do I have to join and pay a fee in order to go look at my employer is not a member?

WEBER: Yes, if your employer is not a member, you can pay $25 just for one request or join $4.95 per month. And then $4.95 per month is a one-year commitment and then you can go on anytime you like to make a request.

FRANCIS: So, you know, the biggest question, I'm sure, that everyone in the audience has what kind of doctors do you have on the network? I mean, does it include everyone? Is it just a small group? I mean, what percentage would you say of the doctors in America are available in your Web site?

WEBER: Well, not a huge percentage. We look for doctors that are not the mainstream big box type of providers. Doctors prefer getting cash at the time of care. The traditional insurance model where they will, you know, charge one price that is called the charge master. And then they carry a re-prices it to the allowable, and then they're paid a portion of that. It sometimes takes 120 days or so for them to get their money. So, the doctors like getting paid at the time of the care. And also they get to set their own prices.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: With traditional insurance they're told what they would be paid that is it.

FRANCIS: No, that is interesting. They get to set their own prices to see what the market will bear. A lot of our viewers tweeted in and said, you know, it is very normal for people to travel to Sloane Kettering or to travel to MD Anderson for cancer treatment. So, they're familiar with the idea of traveling to big. Do you have big names like that on your site?

WEBER: Yes. As a matter of fact, we do Baylor in Houston, MD Anderson is participating on very small level. We have talked to Kerlin Jobe in Los Angeles. They kind of were looking at it. They haven't made a final evaluation. So absolutely, and we have overseas facility like in (INAUDIBLE) and Bangkok.

FRANCIS: Let me ask you about how some financials work, OK. So, say I get to -- the doctor looks great online, you know, I look at it -- for whatever you can tell. I mean, have the same problem when I'm on my own health network and you are looking, you see their education. But until you go see them, you don't really know them. So, say you get out there and you meet them or you see hospital and don't feel good about it. What happens then? Do you lose the travel money? How do the financials work?

WEBER: OK, well, I mean, if you paid for your own flight, then, yes, I mean you've had sort of two-day vacation I guess or whatever. I mean, it is not much different than if you looked in the yellow pages and went to MD Anderson or the local, you know, corner hospital either way. I mean, if you get there, you don't like the physician for whatever reason.

Now keep in mind you've had a lot of transactions before you get to there. A lot of doctors when they respond to a bid they will say, OK, you know, before we go through this, maybe we should have a phone call or talk on Skype or something like that.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: So usually by the time you get there you've actually kind of met the person, sort of online.

FRANCIS: And how does insurance play into this? Because there a couple of articles that I was reading about this, they were saying that in some cases your insurance company will pay for to you fly to another place if it is significantly cheaper for then. How do you get your insurance company involved in shopping for prices?

WEBER: Well, a lot of people use private third party administrators where they have more flexibility and it has to be right in the plan document where it will allow. Some of the big carriers won't actually allow you to negotiate a better price without considering it out of network which means you pay more of a deductible. So, you have to make sure your plan is set up to wraparound this kind of travel arrangement.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: I mean, if you're getting a knee replacement for 21,000 versus 70, it would be foolish for the carrier not to cover. So, it was self- funded employers where they can do this.

FRANCIS: What is the most common type of surgery people are traveling for? What do you see the most? Because I imagine it isn't emergency surgery where people are price comparing.

WEBER: No. That is true. Our app is not quite fast enough to work in the ambulance.

A lot of people are using knee replacement, hip replacement, colonoscopies. Those are some of our more common. Rotator cuff repair, we are getting a lot of requests for cosmetic procedures. But I think orthopedic would be the most common surgery because they're mostly preplanned.

FRANCIS: Yes.

No, it's a very interesting model because of course we're going through these dramatic changes in health care. People are trying to figure out, you know, as they're forced to bear more of a burden of the cost, how they can make it cheaper for themselves. Here in New York a lot of doctors stopped taking insurance all together and gone to all cash because the system is so hard to deal with.

WEBER: Yes.

FRANCIS: So, an application like yours I can see it gaining a lot of popularity as people, you know, realize they're really out there on their own trying to fend for themselves.

Ralph Weber, great stuff, thank you so much. Very interesting.

WEBER: And it is not just about price though, Melissa. It is not just about price. I mean, when you go to hotels.com, you don't look for a motel 6. It is sometimes about access. Sometimes crossing a state line, different medical board has different medical regulations with drastically can increase or decrease the cost. So, it is about accessing and choice and getting the doctor that you want rather than the one that covers you.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, that is a great point. I'm glad you added that.

Ralph, I think it is the wave of the future. Thank you so much for coming on.

WEBER: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: Up next, it won't be long before we're all driving i-cars. Who can help Apple win the race? Stick around.

And people piling on the bandwagon saying oracle's Larry Ellison is making too damn much. It is all the word on Wall Street. We got the scoop coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did I tell you? 88 miles per hour!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: They did it. Forget the Delorean (ph), Dr. Brown. Dr. Brown should try the i-car.

German analyst is now pushing for a partnership between Apple and Tesla saying the tech giant should buy Elon Musk's car company, maybe now is the right time. The electric car maker West Coast Supercharger Corridor is officially open for business. So Model S owners can travel between San Diego, California, and Vancouver, Canada, without worry. But is the buyout a good or bad idea?

Jean Jennings, editor-in-chief for "Automobile" magazine and Dan Ferris is an analyst with Stansberry and Associates.

Jean, let me start with you, is this a match made in heaven, the i-car courtesy of Tesla?

JEAN JENNINGS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, AUTOMOBILE MAGAZINE: Well, you know, for Elon Musk, it might be because he himself has said their company is has a higher valuation than we rightly deserve. So, for him it might be the perfect time.

FRANCIS: Yes. Dan, what do you think?

DAN FERRIS, ANALYST, STANSBERRY AND ASSOCIATES: I think Tesla would be a really bad investment for Apple. Set aside arguments whether or not the technologies work together. Tesla is a horrible investment. It is an unprofitable company in one of most capital intensive, ultracompetitive low margin industries in the world. Not a good idea.

FRANCIS: OK. Well, let me try to make some of the arguments why it might make sense, Dan. I mean, if you look at Apple, stockholder have fallen out of love with Apple basically since the passing of Steve Jobs. Maybe they need that injection, that magic factor. They need the charismatic person to be back in the company, dreaming up new inventions and making Apple what it was. Couldn't Elon Musk be that kind of creative, driving force, who could bring the imagination and the love back to Apple? No, you're shaking your head already. Ready to shoot me down. Let me have it.

FERRIS: Well look, here's the problem, Steve Jobs and Elon Musk, not the same, OK? Steve Jobs is revolutionized four industries, right, music, phones, movies and computers. And all those are insanely profitable businesses today. And Elon Musk is enamored with these kind of very cutting-edge, I mean, he is a dreamer, right? But very cutting-edge technologies and he is not making money at it.

FRANCIS: OK. Jean, Elon is making a whole lot of money for e-bay through PayPal. I mean, PayPal was definitely a $8 home run. Jean, what do you think?

JENNINGS: Right. So, you know, I think Dan has a lot of great points. But let's talk about what Elon has done in an industry that basically no individual is capable of actually making a car like he has done. He has been incredibly successful. I mean, he has had a hell of a month. He has just done a deal with Panasonic to produce batteries. He has done a deal with AT&T wireless to provide internet connectivity. He has done his corridor but he has done the big trio of big moves. Number one, he got two of the four major car magazines in America to name that car an "Automobile" magazine's case, automobile of the year. "Motor Trend" car of the year, because it was flat-out the best and most exciting car produced last year.

In addition to that, "Consumer Reports" has just given it a recommended rating, the same rating they took away from Camry and said it was one of the highest, highest place-getting tests they have ever done in their history. Ninety-nine out of 100 points, just performance-wise. In addition to that, the last piece of that NHTSA safety rating. Five stars in every single category. NHTSA said it is highest rated, safest car they have ever --

FRANCIS: -- of all time it has ever happened.

Dan -- but the problem, I think Dan is going to say to you, show me the money. I mean, unless you own the stock they are not selling a whole bunch of these cars, they are not making a bunch of these cars. Right, Dan?

FERRIS: Exactly. Exactly.

JENNINGS: No argument.

FERRIS: You know, it is a $90,000 car. Yes. But here is a thing.

Look. Let's say the three of us owned Apple all together, OK? We're bringing in 45 billion in cash flow a year, free cash flow, biggest non- financial free cash flow stream in the world. And then, I come to you too, and I say hey, let's spend the 25 or 30 billion we need to take over Tesla?

FRANCIS: But Dan, what is the next i-device? I mean, they need the next big idea. They need the next revenue stream. They need something beyond the phone, the ipad, the computer. Your car, it is the logical extension. That is why German analyst came up with the idea that Apple needs the next thing is i-car, why not? Go ahead. Let me have it.

FERRIS: No, the i-car, look this technology will be in cars one day, we don't argue that point. But the next thing will probably be, the next category is probably going to be TV, right? That would be the next category.

FRANCIS: But they have already got Apple TV. I mean, they're already working on that. They're perfecting it. We're going beyond TV. The next thing is the car.

Jean, go ahead.

FERRIS: But it is not a real i-TV though.

FRANCIS: Go ahead, Jean.

JENNINGS: Next thing is the future of transportation which is going to be the connected car and it is the autonomous car. There is no doubt about it. And all of --

FERRIS: Agreed.

JENNINGS: All of the technology involved that is involved in this is in place now. So it is a matter of knitting it all together. The next technology is -- work on that Elon.

FRANCIS: Dan, you hate the idea of Apple doing cars or do you hate idea of them partnering with Elon Musk?

FERRIS: I don't hate the idea of them partnering with Musk. I hate the idea of Apple spending the 25 or 30 billion you would need to do buy a company that burns 330 million a year in cash.

FRANCIS: Very fair point because at end of the day it is all about money. And you boiled it down to the dollars and I love that we'll end the segment there.

Thanks to both of you, great job.

FERRIS: Thank you.

JENNINGS: Thank you.

FRANCIS: OK, that was billionaire Larry Ellison is making too much money at expense of Oracle shareholders. Pension fund are piling on saying hell yes. It is all the word on Wall Street.

Plus, is Target setting a sight on job seekers with checkered pasts. We will tell you why they are rolling out the welcome mat to workers with criminal records.

Do you have too much "Money?"

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Now, it is time for juiciest part of the day, the whispers, the rumors, what is truer? What is going on behind closed doors? Investors up in arms over Oracle CEO Larry Ellison's pay, shareholders and pensions, are teaming together to wage a campaign opposing the re-election of some of the company's directors at today's annual meeting. And the fury is growing, let me tell you.

It is about whether Ellison is making too much money at shareholders expense. We got all the dirty details in today's word on Wall Street.

With me now, Spencer Jakab and Brian Sozzi.

Guys, thanks for joining me. I mean, this is turning -- Larry Ellison has always attracted a little too much attention to himself with everything that he is doing, whether it enormous yachts, enormous pay day. Is it finally catching up to him? Spencer, what do you think?

SPENCER JAKAB, COLUMNIST, WALL STREET JOURNAL: It definitely is not his behavior that is catching up to him because he has been playing ball for a long time. And that is why when he is making you money, that's fine. The stock is only up a couple of percent this year, not doing so great. And actually, you know, for years, you know, there have been complains about him being highest paid CEO, most years being highest paid CEO. He gets a salary of one dollar like a lot of guys.

FRANCIS: Right. But if you look at total compensation, I mean, and we have a full screen to that to show people. If you look at direct compensation and you compare it to other big CEOs in the same industry, Larry Ellison, you know, out there, there you go. Larry Ellison, 94.6 million. And that is his salary but that is also -- I mean, most of it is his option and his stock and everything else.

Paul Otellini, John Chambers, Tim Cook, Steve Ballmer, I mean, all a tiny fraction of that. You even go to people like Jamie Dimon, you know, 11.5 million. Nothing is even close to what Larry Ellison --

Brian, why is he getting that much money again?

BRIAN SOZZI, BELLUS CAPITAL ADVISORS: Our time slices is got to shred. First of all, it is hard to argue with it first of all because the stock, market cap is almost over doubled since May 2003. So, in many respects he earned it. But what are you getting for oracle? You are paying for past performance like the shrug who hit the free agent market. And here is one stat to share, on Twitter, Oracle shares since mid 2010 have actually underperformed the Dow, right, sap and Nasdaq. Oracle is a little tech stock.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, absolutely. I mean, when you look at it over the long run it has done well, but if you look at it, you know, year-to-date, last year, three months, one month, anyway you slice it, it is lagging the S&P and in some cases by a lot. You are the day that stand about three in the third percent while the S&P is up 20 percent. So it is just, you know -

SOZZI: And that is just the performance of the company.

FRANCIS: And so, Spencer, maybe it is time for him to go?

JAKAB: It is not so, it is time for him to go. But if you look at what does Larry Ellison bring to Oracle? I mean, he was the force behind it. He was the person pushing it. Today, you know, you can't, he is not analogous to Steve Jobs. He is not indispensable person.

FRANCIS: Right.

JAKAB: It happens to be the owner of about a quarter of the stock and one of the richest men in the world. He is worth about $40 billion.

FRANCIS: Is the inspiration, the driver, I mean, is he the person that the company is really all about? You look, I mean, at what Steve Jobs was, of course, but then you look at other people where the company is really about them. Martha Stewart, I mean, you know, is he the guy who is the driving force behind the company or is the company almost independent of him now?

Brain, what do you think?

SOZZI: Well, I sure hope not because the fact is he has made a lot of bad acquisitions, and if I'm shareholder I'm worried about how the guy is spending his money or their money on all his acquisitions over the past year. He is running sailing events. If you look at the Ford structure of Oracle, they only have two independent directors. They have the head of the -- Chairman of the company is former employee. They need more independent directors on Oracle's board.

And third of all, look at Mark Hurd. He is the guy who made inherit this whole entire company. Is he going to step in the face of Larry Ellison, and say hey you're making too much, probably not.

FRANCIS: No. And that is really what they are saying. It is they are saying that we need to get -- before we even tackle the issue of Larry Ellison, we have to tackle the issue of the board which is totally beholden to him, and he is doing exactly what he wants. When you see somebody who is making $94 million a year, you know, big U.K. pension fund among those pressing for changes. You have Calpers, the California state retirement system. I mean, they're powerful. They own 11.5 million shares. New York City, for example, 10.3 million shares. Everybody is clamoring for a change in the board to begin with. Do you think the move will be successful?

JAKAB: No.

FRANCIS: No?

JAKAB: I don't think it will be successful because you have already votes that have been really damning. You had votes on say on pay and they said thanks but no thanks, you know. We kind of -- we like the way that we are paying him.

So, it is very, very difficult, especially with the CEO controlling quarter of the stock and so many people --

FRANCIS: Well, it this live lagging? I mean, maybe this is the problem for the stock. Is it the bad acquisition or is it this idea that you have somebody who is running it, who is just out of control?

SOZZI: You are right, Melissa. And it is because of all the acquisition. And I point to last year, they put up 12 percent pre-tax operating profit increase. What he need beneath the surface, he actually with many respects high single digit. Why is that happening? Because you require a lot of business like Sun Microsystems in 2008, to high a price, had to write it down, business underperforming. This guy has to go. Time for new blood.

FRANCIS: You know, he bought (INAUDIBLE) of the Hawaiian Islands. I mean, obviously, you know, there is a lot of resort there. It was an investment. But it is very high-profile thing to do. I mean, his bank rolled two victories of America's cup. He missed his developers' conference. That was a huge deal. We were talking about that before because of America's cup. He has a $200 Million Japanese-themed compound in Silicon Valley. Should he tone down his life-style a little bit as he sees the tide turning against him? Would it help or is it too late? What is the scuttlebutt?

JAKAB: It looks bad, for sure, to buy a Hawaiian Island, to not attend your developers' conference. The keynote that I think 40,000 people had traveled.

FRANCIS: You don't seem like the $94 million a year man when you are doing that.

JAKAB: No, you don't. No, it doesn't look good at all. But his behavior is not egregious enough yet to have --.

FRANCIS: Really?

JAKAB: Exactly because he is just too much wrapped up in associate with the company. I don't think you are going to see that. I think, you know, once he does something that is really embarrassing or he gets becomes, you know, too old to really hang on --

FRANCIS: Brian, do you agree?

SOZZI: I am very worried. The fact that he is thinking about buying islands, thinking about sailing yachts, and this is the man in charge of the corporate strategy, of acquisition of the company, same strategy, inspiration, means after buying islands, he is worried about worrying how in committee to mow a lawn at one of these islands. That is not good. You don't want to see that as a shareholder.

FRANCIS: All right, guy. Thank you so much. Great job!

All right, up next, thinking of filling out a job application at target? You won't have to answer that pesky criminal history question anymore. Should they make it easier for ex-cons to get jobs? Tweet me and tell what you think. It is today's money talker.

And "who made "Money" today?" The international icon is sure walking on to a whole lot of cash. You got to keep watching to find out who it is.

We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: If you've got a criminal past and you were searching for a job, Target -- hey, it might be just the place to look. That is because now target will not ask if you've been convicted of a crime on their initial job application. Target is not the only one. An unbelievable ten states and 51 cities have signed some version of this practice into law. It's got a lot of people fired up. So, of course, it is today's money talk.

Joining us now, and not submitting to a background check, by the way, Susan Sullivan, Bill Farmkin and our very own Dennis Kneale.

Dennis, you're mad about this? You are fired up?

DENNIS KNEALE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: You know what? This is now the new politically correct, wonderful cause of liberals everywhere. Let's pass a law, an actual law telling companies that they're not allowed to ask applicants at first glance, hey, you have been arrested or convicted of a crime. I say why don't you let companies figure that out instead of dictating to them.

And our federal EEOC is at the forefront of that. It sued BMW. It sued Dollar General because they use screening programs that kind of faired out convicted or arrested (ph). They said the impact of that is racist. And while the intent is not racist, if the impact of it is racist -- disparate impact, when then, by golly, your policies are illegal.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Let him have it.

SUSAN SOLOVIC, SMALL BUSINESS EXPERT: No one would ever accuse me of being a liberal, trust me. But did you know that one out of four American adults have either an arrest record or a conviction? So, you are just --

FRANCIS: So what? So what? So what? So, put it on your application. They're not screened out. You're just putting it on your application.

SOLOVIC: But I think that there probably is a predisposition to see that they're screened out. The problem with that is, what if it's a minor infraction? What if it was a kid who got busted for drugs at an early --

KNEALE: Well, then let the company go ahead and make an exception. Let it decide to instead of some government --

(CROSSTALK)

BILL FRUMKIN, EMPLOYMENT ATTORNEY: It is absolutely right. The concept is there are laws in many states separate and apart from anti- discrimination laws that say that if you have a criminal background or criminal problem, it has to be related to the job for which you're not eligible for.

For example, if you were busted for having a joint ten years ago and now you want to be a cashier, what does that have to do with it?

FRANCIS: Why does it hurt the employer to know? I mean, the employer can say, hey, guess what, that has nothing to do with whether or not you're going to be --

FRUMKIN: Because that can't be the reason. The reason has to be some other reason.

(CROSSTALK)

SOLOVIC: It has to be a justifiable reason. The other thing is I used to practice divorce law, I tell you what, divorce makes the sanest person go nuts.

(LAUGHTER)

SOLOVIC: There's a lot of he said/she said when it comes to divorces. If there is a little domestic dispute, that's the only thing on that person's record, I'm sorry, I'm going to give them some slack.

FRANCIS: The flip side, I mean, I have the right to know if somebody's robbed a bank, I don't want them managing my cash --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: I mean, that's what target is talking about this idea that they're not going to check the box.

FRUMKIN: No, but the point is they won't check the box, but in the interview, OK, it may come out. I mean, they may be able to find out from that screening point. It's not that they can't consider it all, but the truth is, has to be job related.

And just to talk about discrimination for a moment, the bottom line is that if one in seven African-American males end up in the criminal justice system and one in 30 Caucasian males end up in the criminal justice system, this is a facially-neutral way essentially to keep people out --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: I don't buy that at all. A job is a privilege, it's not a right. Employers are in business to make a profit. They get to choose who they have in their store working for them.

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: -- there's something about this. Government always so well with intended, it's cruel, because what they're going to do now is the companies are not allowed. In Minnesota, they're not allowed to ask --

SOLOVIC: That's not true.

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: If I can finish -- and then what's going to happen is after they find out that I was convicted and I got my hopes up, they're going to dash my dreams and not hire me.

SOLOVIC: That is not true. It has got to be fact-sensitive, and you are just taking this and making it too simplistic. All they're doing is saying we're going to at least look into this. If the candidate becomes a serious candidate, they have every right --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: -- up front then.

(CROSSTALK)

SOLOVIC: Because they don't know what it is. It says check the box - -

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: -- leave it up to companies to be intelligent enough to figure out how they want to handle it. Why should government come in and dictate a list of --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Hold on, guys. Why should government come in and dictate to --

FRUMKIN: Because government requires minimum wage laws, and government requires overtime laws and --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: -- women that we don't discriminate against, you know --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: -- because a company wants to know if a person has been arrested? Exactly --

FRANCIS: They've broken the law.

(CROSSTALK)

SOLOVIC: It has a disparaging --

(CROSSTALK)

FRUMKIN: But even if it isn't disparate impact, the bottom line is this, do you want people coming out of jail or coming out and being convicted and never to work again?

FRANCIS: That's right.

FRUMKIN: They'll never getting entitlements and then they'll be getting all these other things. What about taxpayers being functioning in society? That's the --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: Wait a minute. I don't hear you guys worrying about entitlements on any other issue, so you can't now use it on your side when you --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: What about the idea don't you guys realize, government is telling us what to do more and more and more. Government is in our face telling us you've got to have not just any insurance, you've got to have this insurance, telling us -- pretty soon they're going to be telling us -- put our left leg pants on in the morning before the right leg. how about just letting business breathe free and --

SOLOVIC: It I wish that were the --

FRANCIS: Amen! I am weeping. I am weeping. Go ahead. Respond --

SOLOVIC: You are being so idealistic. That is never going to happen. We are talking about one little box on an application that --

KNEALE: If it's one little box, then what are you guys so worried about?

SOLOVIC: Because --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: -- jobs for the people who have not been arrested and convicted of a crime.

(CROSSTALK)

SOLOVIC: You have children. What if your child in college gets busted for having marijuana --

(CROSSTALK)

KNEALE: Should my daughter not ever have to pay a price for what she's done wrong?

FRUMKIN: For the rest of her life and not work?

FRANCIS: That's it. They're saying for the rest of their life not work. They're saying --

KNEALE: Let an employer ask.

FRANCIS: -- so you have to report that going forward. Guys, you were great. Thank you so much. What a spirited discussion. Hoo!

All right. Coming up, he played one of the most influential engineers ever, and now, a top computer company is hiring Ashton Kutcher as a product engineer. What? We're going to go behind the scenes to see if they might be confusing him with the real Steve Jobs. Stay right where you are. At the end of the day, it is all about MONEY and heat here on this set!

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: So, TV's highest paid actor scores a new gig. Ashton Kutcher is joining forces with Lenovo but not to just simply sell the products as an actual engineer. Kutcher could work with the computer company to offer advice on design and software for its yoga tablets. It is a trend in the endorsement industry using their brains behind the popularity.

Here now are celebrity journalist, David Caplan, and tech expert, Todd Haselton. Thanks to both of you for joining us.

David, what do you think? I mean, this is an interesting one, because Ashton, you know, I mean, he's a renowned investor. He's gotten in a lot of things early, Air B&B, you know, a lot of big tech companies. He's not a lightweight in the tech field. At the same time, I have a hard time imaging him actually, you know, designing tablets.

DAVID CAPLAN, CELEBRITY JOURNALIST: Well, you know, there's two things. First of all, he's an influencer which is a word that's bandied around a lot in the celebrity world meaning he's an influence. You know, Lenovo's great for him. He's perceived as young, he's cutting edge, and I think Ashton Kutcher, he's huge on Twitter. He talks a lot about technology.

So, first of all, he's already perceived as having that street cred, but then you want to cross that line, well, does he actually have the street cred to do it, and he seems to be a real tech-savvy guy. Listen, he may not be in the actually drafting these things, but when it comes to ideas, I mean, he's on top of the trends. He knows what people want.

FRANCIS: I guess. But, Todd, I mean, I don't actually know a human being that owns a yoga whatever it is or anything --

CAPLAN: Now, you will because of Ashton.

(LAUGHTER)

TODD HASELTON, TECHNOBUFFALO EXEC. DIR. OF MOBILE: -- yoga products are sort of the ones that are tablets and computer, and they've --

FRANCIS: Do you know a person who owns one?

HASELTON: No. I don't know --

FRANCIS: Do you know a person who owns one?

CAPLAN: No.

HASELTON: But to make a point here, I think as Lenovo tries to expand its market share in the United States, it needs a face to do that. And Ashton Kutcher can be that face, but I don't think he's necessarily the right person -- I don't think he's going to be an engineer back there actually coding, although, he suggested that yes, he does have a background in that.

He has worked closely with start-ups to do so, but I think it's more a play on Lenovos' to get a U.S. presence especially as they move into U.S. smartphones --

FRANCIS: And they are -- I mean, the point of this, though, the larger point, is that consumers are very savvy now. And just having someone out there, you know, hawking your product doesn't get it done. I mean, when you look at -- who was it that was out there trying to sell -- Alicia Keys -- Alicia Keys out there. She's saying, you know, that she's Blackberry, Blackberry's really cool, Blackberry is not, you know, your grandfather's device from work.

It's actually cool for young people, and she's doing all this from her iPhone, and she gets busted along the way. And consumers are very savvy to understand that when you put a celebrity out there, they're just doing it for the dollars. So, they're trying to act like they're more integrated into the actual product. Lady Gaga, for example.

CAPLAN: Polaroid (ph).

FRANCIS: Right.

CAPLAN: I mean, but I think, you know, again, for her, that's actually a good match because --

FRANCIS: What is she actually doing for Polaroid?

CAPLAN: She's their creative director. So, you know, she is a very creative person. So, for example, she'll maybe design sort of special edition Polaroid cameras. She'll be partaking their advertising --

FRANCIS: In what sense? I mean, is she there making drawings --

CAPLAN: I know how this works.

FRANCIS: What do you think?

CAPLAN: I mean, she really is suggesting ideas like, hey, you know, the camera should have this -- you know, be this color, should be pink with this trim.

FRANCIS: Do you think they're all rolling their eyes behind her back while she's standing at this meeting saying that people, like yes, whatever --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

HASELTON: That's exactly what's going on. And I think that Ashton actually is going to have to prove himself. If he goes to China, which he said he was going there this week, he has to show engineers that he knows what he's talking about. And it's on the company to show not tell (ph), not simply --

FRANCIS: Right. And he says he has his engineering background. Well --

CAPLAN: He dropped out of school.

FRANCIS: Right. He went to, what was it, University of Iowa. He was in biochemical engineering. That was his major before he dropped out. I mean, biochemical engineering is not the same thing as what he's doing now --

HASELTON: And he admitted to partying too hard in school.

FRANCIS: Right. And he was doing it because his twin brother has a lot of ailments, so he was looking at medicine. I mean, that's like a far cry from what he's doing now. That that doesn't mean that he has any expertise whatsoever in designing hardware.

HASELTON: I agree, absolutely.

CAPLAN: But you know, I will say, you know, I wouldn't necessarily, though, overestimate the public because just as much as some people are star struck (ph) when they see a celebrity endorsement, a celebrity endorsement is huge. While a lot of people are going to be turned off, I mean, every day there's someone new being signed to something. And --

FRANCIS: Did he sell a lot of cool pix? Wasn't that what he was --

(CROSSTALK)

CAPLAN: Yes. You know, and it worked great for them. There's a whole other category of people out there, specifically, younger people. They like Ashton --

(CROSSTALK)

HASELTON: -- front and center in the Best Buy, right? So, they're going to walk in to Best Buy and say, oh, an icon. But Lenovo's not so well known name in the United States. Blackberry was on its way out. That's why it didn't work with Alicia Keys. So, you have to look at the business where it's going anyway.

FRANCIS: But this is the new trend in advertising. I mean, without question -- well, no, it's not. I mean, if you look at something that -- Kim Kardashian tweeting about something different every single day, and people understand she's being paid for that tweet. She probably has no idea what the product is, doesn't use it, doesn't matter.

That now consumers are demanding something a little bit more authentic, and if you look at other partnerships. I mean, you look at Dr. Dre with the Beatz head phones, working with HP to develop, you know, better sound technology. Here's a celebrity who knows something who does actually know something about the technology --

(CROSSTALK)

HASELTON: So, he worked in studios, right? So, he knows what to do with headphones. But then, you look at Ashton Kutcher. I haven't seen him working on laptop. I mean --

FRANCIS: Right.

HASELTON: You know, he works with start-ups, but not with a laptop. And windows is the problem here. I think people are driving towards that, so what's he going to do to improve windows? That's a Microsoft problem, not a Lenovo one.

FRANCIS: Interesting. All right. Yes. None of us know a human being (ph), you know, anything Lenovo --

CAPLAN: By that, we will now, though. It's come a long way, though.

FRANCIS: I don't know. Let's check back in six months and see if we still don't know anyone who owns Lenovo or anything. All right. Thanks, guys. Happy Halloween, by the way.

All right. From the U.S., every corner of the globe, MONEY has been flying around the world today.

First to Syria, inspectors there have completed the destruction of machinery used to produce chemical weapons. The organization for the prohibition of chemical weapon which just won the Nobel Peace Prize you might remember is overseeing the process. It says in a statement that it has, quote, "verified and seen destroyed all of Syria's declared chemical weapons production equipment. No word, of course, on Syria's undeclared chemical weapons stash.

On to England where the public is about to get access to a database aimed at busting tax evaders. The new database contains company ownership details. In an effort to expose international money laundering and tax evasion schemes, the information is specific to those with 25 percent or more of a company's shares or voting rights.

By making it public, the British government is hoping to put pressure on firms and individuals trying to hide money and profits. We'll see if that works.

All right. Landing in Egypt, the country's tourism board is launching an ambitious campaign to lure back visitors that haven't been scared off by the political turmoil there. Yes, those pictures not helping with tourism. You'd think being home to one of the wonders of the world would be a big enough draw, but Egypt has lost $2.5 billion in revenue since the revolution began in 2011.

About eleven and a half million tourists visited Egypt in 2012. The tourism board, though, is hoping to increase that to 13.5 million next year. We'll see.

Some days, you are too sick to work. Other days, you're simply sick off work. And like Ferris Bueller, you just need a day off. From counterfeit colds to fraudulent flus, you won't believe how far some people go to avoid their job. Stick around for "Spare Change." You can never have too much MONEY or too many sick excuses.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Time for some fun on "Spare Change." Today, we are joined by Veronica Dagher and David Asman. Thanks for joining us. Happy Halloween. We're all in red even though it's Halloween. All right.

So, it's that time of year, holidays are approaching. Everyone's just counting how many sick days they have left for the year. What better way to spend this Halloween night than breaking down the most outlandish sick day excuses ever because there's going to be a lot of people calling in sick tomorrow when they stay out late in Halloween. It's a Friday. What's the worst sick excuse you've ever used? David, have you lied and said you were --

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS: You know, I honestly have to say --

FRANCIS: Come on.

ASMAN: No, no, no, I actually come in. I'm one of these crazy people who loves to work. I actually came in. I had the worst hangover in my life, so bad --

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: And came in anyway?

ASMAN: It took me about two hours to walk one block because I felt like I was 104. And I came in anyway. But once I get to my desk, my head fell down. We used to work at "The Wall Street Journal." I used to work to "The Wall Street Journal." I used to work there, and the editor of "The Wall Street Journal," who never came to my office, that one day he came in.

And luckily, he knew the guy that I'd been drinking with the night before, and I said, I'm sorry, I was out with so and so, and he said, OK, put your head back.

FRANCIS: Veronica, you have no hope of topping that story.

VERONICA DAGHER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: I really don't.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: I'm hoping that you're not the person -- one of the most outlandish excuses that we saw on the Career Builder survey which is, you know, one of the reasons why we're doing this, couldn't make it to work because his false teeth flew out the window while he was driving down the highway.

ASMAN: That's a good --

FRANCIS: Do you think that guy was telling the truth?

ASMAN: No.

FRANCIS: Or do you think something else happened, and they made up that crazy excuse? What do you think, Veronica?

DAGHER: He's crazy.

(LAUGHTER)

(CROSSTALK)

DAGHER: Why would you even share that even if it was true?

FRANCIS: If it's true, why would you share it?

DAGHER: Right.

FRANCIS: So, you have to be lying. That's my thought with something like that, right?

DAGHER: Yes. I mean, I could see that.

FRANCIS: Thirty-three percent of people who called out sick, according to Career Builder, just didn't feel like going to work.

ASMAN: Right.

FRANCIS: They called and said they were sick.

ASMAN: Actually, seriously, I did once when I was at "The Journal," I had to fire somebody because she was always using excuses. But I don't think they were -- this was before the days of all the surveillance devices and everything --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: -- posting on Facebook. I mean, they call in sick and then they tweet or they post on Facebook --

ASMAN: Well, that's it. You can prove it now. In my day, you couldn't necessarily prove it quite as easily. But now, you can prove it. Certainly, if they post anything on Facebook. And I do know of one person who was caught at a baseball game, and they were seen --

FRANCIS: According to a survey, 30 percent of employers check on employees, either ask them for a doctor's note or they look on social media to see if they really sick when they say -- so word to the wise out there. The first Monday in February is the most popular day for employees to call out sick.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: See, I think that makes total sense because you go through the holidays and you have a great time. You come back in January, and you hit -- you're like, ah, we don't have a day off or anything --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Yes, either that or it's the Super Bowl.

ASMAN: Oh, bingo. That's it. Of course.

FRANCIS: Yes. People call in -- but I always think -- I mean, I'm always amazed, I do notice people calling in the day after the Super Bowl, and I'm shocked --

ASMAN: By the way, you mentioned the false teeth. My favorite one is the guy who called in sick because he said a swarm of bees had surrounded his car, and he couldn't get out. Oh, my goodness!

FRANCIS: There it is.

ASMAN: Well, he had proof, i didn't know that.

FRANCIS: He had proof of it, but obviously, he called someone on a phone --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Anyway, all right. Thanks, guys. "Who Made Money Today?" It sure is a beautiful day for him and his investors. Not sure who it is? We'll have the answer right after this. You can never have too much MONEY or too many sick excuses.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's "Who Made Money today." Once again, everyone who owns Facebook. Company reported strong third quarter earnings. Social media giant says it swung to a profit with 60 percent revenue growth, beating the street's expectations. Investors decided they aren't overly concerned about a big decline in daily use by younger teens. And Facebook stock closed up almost 2.5 percent today.

Rock star, Bono, and his investment group, Elevation Partners, owns about 40 million shares of Facebook. They made a very impressive 48 million bucks today. I would take that. Not bad.

Also making money today, a 67 year-old man in Orlando, Florida who just won his second multimillion-dollar lotto in two years. The Florida Lottery says James Boseman Jr. (ph) hit the jackpot for a three million bucks. Last year, he won 10 million bucks. He bought both tickets from the same 7/11. Fun fact. He didn't use the same numbers. In case you're wondering, the odds of a double win like that are about one in 196 trillion.

And not spending money, on the Fresno State Basketball team's opening game, everyone who's going. That's because Indiana Pacers all-star, Paul George, bought every single ticket to his Alma Matters first game. The "Fresno Business Journal" reports all George purchased all 15,596 seats at the Save Mart Center.

And season-ticket holders won't have to worry. They'll have the same seats for the game. It's the NBA star's way of giving back to his former college. And the low estimate for what it costs him, about $265,000. Though given that, he just signed a contract extension worth $90 million over five years, I guess, he can afford it.

That's all we've got for you. I hope you made MONEY today. You've got to watch tomorrow. Our money talker is all about how you should really dress for work. What about those short skirts and too tight dresses? How about the CEO who says women who wear high heels have no brains? Those are fighting words, and we are all over it. That is tomorrow. "The Willis Report" is coming up next. Happy Halloween.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KRW-JXP1-DY0W-408W-00000-00MONEY for October 31, 20132013-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMONEY for October 31, 2013LanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN HOST: Think about this - if you needed surgery, would you be down with a procedure that doctors and hospitals and other places in the country, people you had never met, just to save money? It's happening more and more, because when they say it's not, it's always about money.

Sure, we all love going online to find the best deal, but usually we're talking about a hotel room, a flight, a television. Would you feel comfortable accepting online bid for hip replacement from a doctor you never met? It is newest wave in comparison shopping and the Web site METABID (ph) giving people chance to evaluate offers from doctors across the country and then travel to get the care of their choice.

Here to discuss how it all works, the president, Ralph Weber.

Ralph, what is the experience, I go online what happens?

RALPH WEBER, PRESIDENT, METABID: Well, you go online and make a request. Now, it depend if you work for employer that uses met at that bid as source care or just an individual. So, you make a request and you can put in your parameters, a few health questions, you know, your height, your weight, any medication allergies. You can put in how far you're willing to travel, if at all. And then you request a bid. You can review all the doctors' profiles. So you see where they went to medical school, what their training was, what their experience is. How many of these procedures they do every year. So you really get to see a lot about the quality of the doctor, as you make the request.

FRANCIS: wow.

WEBER: --which with traditional insurance, all you know is in network or out of network.

FRANCIS: Yes. You really don't know that much. I mean, although you are able to ask people in your community, generally, especially if your community is smaller that everybody sort of knows everybody. I have a lot of questions about all that.

OK. So, if I'm an individual do I have to join and pay a fee in order to go look at my employer is not a member?

WEBER: Yes, if your employer is not a member, you can pay $25 just for one request or join $4.95 per month. And then $4.95 per month is a one-year commitment and then you can go on anytime you like to make a request.

FRANCIS: So, you know, the biggest question, I'm sure, that everyone in the audience has what kind of doctors do you have on the network? I mean, does it include everyone? Is it just a small group? I mean, what percentage would you say of the doctors in America are available in your Web site?

WEBER: Well, not a huge percentage. We look for doctors that are not the mainstream big box type of providers. Doctors prefer getting cash at the time of care. The traditional insurance model where they will, you know, charge one price that is called the charge master. And then they carry a re-prices it to the allowable, and then they're paid a portion of that. It sometimes takes 120 days or so for them to get their money. So, the doctors like getting paid at the time of the care. And also they get to set their own prices.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: With traditional insurance they're told what they would be paid that is it.

FRANCIS: No, that is interesting. They get to set their own prices to see what the market will bear. A lot of our viewers tweeted in and said, you know, it is very normal for people to travel to Sloane Kettering or to travel to MD Anderson for cancer treatment. So, they're familiar with the idea of traveling to big. Do you have big names like that on your site?

WEBER: Yes. As a matter of fact, we do Baylor in Houston, MD Anderson is participating on very small level. We have talked to Kerlin Jobe in Los Angeles. They kind of were looking at it. They haven't made a final evaluation. So absolutely, and we have overseas facility like in (INAUDIBLE) and Bangkok.

FRANCIS: Let me ask you about how some financials work, OK. So, say I get to -- the doctor looks great online, you know, I look at it -- for whatever you can tell. I mean, have the same problem when I'm on my own health network and you are looking, you see their education. But until you go see them, you don't really know them. So, say you get out there and you meet them or you see hospital and don't feel good about it. What happens then? Do you lose the travel money? How do the financials work?

WEBER: OK, well, I mean, if you paid for your own flight, then, yes, I mean you've had sort of two-day vacation I guess or whatever. I mean, it is not much different than if you looked in the yellow pages and went to MD Anderson or the local, you know, corner hospital either way. I mean, if you get there, you don't like the physician for whatever reason.

Now keep in mind you've had a lot of transactions before you get to there. A lot of doctors when they respond to a bid they will say, OK, you know, before we go through this, maybe we should have a phone call or talk on Skype or something like that.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: So usually by the time you get there you've actually kind of met the person, sort of online.

FRANCIS: And how does insurance play into this? Because there a couple of articles that I was reading about this, they were saying that in some cases your insurance company will pay for to you fly to another place if it is significantly cheaper for then. How do you get your insurance company involved in shopping for prices?

WEBER: Well, a lot of people use private third party administrators where they have more flexibility and it has to be right in the plan document where it will allow. Some of the big carriers won't actually allow you to negotiate a better price without considering it out of network which means you pay more of a deductible. So, you have to make sure your plan is set up to wraparound this kind of travel arrangement.

FRANCIS: Yes.

WEBER: I mean, if you're getting a knee replacement for 21,000 versus 70, it would be foolish for the carrier not to cover. So, it was self- funded employers where they can do this.

FRANCIS: What is the most common type of surgery people are traveling for? What do you see the most? Because I imagine it isn't emergency surgery where people are price comparing.

WEBER: No. That is true. Our app is not quite fast enough to work in the ambulance.

A lot of people are using knee replacement, hip replacement, colonoscopies. Those are some of our more common. Rotator cuff repair, we are getting a lot of requests for cosmetic procedures. But I think orthopedic would be the most common surgery because they're mostly preplanned.

FRANCIS: Yes.

No, it's a very interesting model because of course we're going through these dramatic changes in health care. People are trying to figure out, you know, as they're forced to bear more of a burden of the cost, how they can make it cheaper for themselves. Here in New York a lot of doctors stopped taking insurance all together and gone to all cash because the system is so hard to deal with.

WEBER: Yes.

FRANCIS: So, an application like yours I can see it gaining a lot of popularity as people, you know, realize they're really out there on their own trying to fend for themselves.

Ralph Weber, great stuff, thank you so much. Very interesting.

WEBER: And it is not just about price though, Melissa. It is not just about price. I mean, when you go to hotels.com, you don't look for a motel 6. It is sometimes about access. Sometimes crossing a state line, different medical board has different medical regulations with drastically can increase or decrease the cost. So, it is about accessing and choice and getting the doctor that you want rather than the one that covers you.

FRANCIS: Yes. No, that is a great point. I'm glad you added that.

Ralph, I think it is the wave of the future. Thank you so much for coming on.

WEBER: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: Up next, it won't be long before we're all driving i-cars. Who can help Apple win the race? Stick around.

And people piling on the bandwagon saying oracle's Larry Ellison is making too damn much. It is all the word on Wall Street. We got the scoop coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did I tell you? 88 miles per hour!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: They did it. Forget the Delorean (ph), Dr. Brown. Dr. Brown should try the i-car.

German analyst is now pushing for a partnership between Apple and Tesla saying the tech giant should buy Elon Musk's car company, maybe now is the right time. The electric car maker West Coast Supercharger Corridor is officially open for business. So Model S owners can travel between San Diego, California, and Vancouver, Canada, without worry. But is the buyout a good or bad idea?

Jean Jennings, editor-in-chief for "Automobile" magazine and Dan Ferris is an analyst with Stansberry and Associates.

Jean, let me start with you, is this a match made in heaven, the i-car courtesy of Tesla?

JEAN JENNINGS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, AUTOMOBILE MAGAZINE: Well, you know, for Elon Musk, it might be because he himself has said their company is has a higher valuation than we rightly deserve. So, for him it might be the perfect time.

FRANCIS: Yes. Dan, what do you think?

DAN FERRIS, ANALYST, STANSBERRY AND ASSOCIATES: I think Tesla would be a really bad investment for Apple. Set aside arguments whether or not the technologies work together. Tesla is a horrible investment. It is an unprofitable company in one of most capital intensive, ultracompetitive low margin industries in the world. Not a good idea.

FRANCIS: OK. Well, let me try to make some of the arguments why it might make sense, Dan. I mean, if you look at Apple, stockholder have fallen out of love with Apple basically since the passing of Steve Jobs. Maybe they need that injection, that magic factor. They need the charismatic person to be back in the company, dreaming up new inventions and making Apple what it was. Couldn't Elon Musk be that kind of creative, driving force, who could bring the imagination and the love back to Apple? No, you're shaking your head already. Ready to shoot me down. Let me have it.

FERRIS: Well look, here's the problem, Steve Jobs and Elon Musk, not the same, OK? Steve Jobs is revolutionized four industries, right, music, phones, movies and computers. And all those are insanely profitable businesses today. And Elon Musk is enamored with these kind of very cutting-edge, I mean, he is a dreamer, right? But very cutting-edge technologies and he is not making money at it.

FRANCIS: OK. Jean, Elon is making a whole lot of money for e-bay through PayPal. I mean, PayPal was definitely a $8 home run. Jean, what do you think?

JENNINGS: Right. So, you know, I think Dan has a lot of great points. But let's talk about what Elon has done in an industry that basically no individual is capable of actually making a car like he has done. He has been incredibly successful. I mean, he has had a hell of a month. He has just done a deal with Panasonic to produce batteries. He has done a deal with AT&T wireless to provide internet connectivity. He has done his corridor but he has done the big trio of big moves. Number one, he got two of the four major car magazines in America to name that car an "Automobile" magazine's case, automobile of the year. "Motor Trend" car of the year, because it was flat-out the best and most exciting car produced last year.

In addition to that, "Consumer Reports" has just given it a recommended rating, the same rating they took away from Camry and said it was one of the highest, highest place-getting tests they have ever done in their history. Ninety-nine out of 100 points, just performance-wise. In addition to that, the last piece of that NHTSA safety rating. Five stars in every single category. NHTSA said it is highest rated, safest car they have ever --

FRANCIS: -- of all time it has ever happened.

FRANCIS: Thirty-three percent of people who called out sick, according to Career Builder, just didn't feel like going to work.

ASMAN: Right.

FRANCIS: They called and said they were sick.

ASMAN: Actually, seriously, I did once when I was at "The Journal," I had to fire somebody because she was always using excuses. But I don't think they were -- this was before the days of all the surveillance devices and everything --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: -- posting on Facebook. I mean, they call in sick and then they tweet or they post on Facebook --

ASMAN: Well, that's it. You can prove it now. In my day, you couldn't necessarily prove it quite as easily. But now, you can prove it. Certainly, if they post anything on Facebook. And I do know of one person who was caught at a baseball game, and they were seen --

FRANCIS: According to a survey, 30 percent of employers check on employees, either ask them for a doctor's note or they look on social media to see if they really sick when they say -- so word to the wise out there. The first Monday in February is the most popular day for employees to call out sick.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: See, I think that makes total sense because you go through the holidays and you have a great time. You come back in January, and you hit -- you're like, ah, we don't have a day off or anything --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Yes, either that or it's the Super Bowl.

ASMAN: Oh, bingo. That's it. Of course.

FRANCIS: Yes. People call in -- but I always think -- I mean, I'm always amazed, I do notice people calling in the day after the Super Bowl, and I'm shocked --

ASMAN: By the way, you mentioned the false teeth. My favorite one is the guy who called in sick because he said a swarm of bees had surrounded his car, and he couldn't get out. Oh, my goodness!

FRANCIS: There it is.

ASMAN: Well, he had proof, i didn't know that.

FRANCIS: He had proof of it, but obviously, he called someone on a phone --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Anyway, all right. Thanks, guys. "Who Made Money Today?" It sure is a beautiful day for him and his investors. Not sure who it is? We'll have the answer right after this. You can never have too much MONEY or too many sick excuses.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's "Who Made Money today." Once again, everyone who owns Facebook. Company reported strong third quarter earnings. Social media giant says it swung to a profit with 60 percent revenue growth, beating the street's expectations. Investors decided they aren't overly concerned about a big decline in daily use by younger teens. And Facebook stock closed up almost 2.5 percent today.

Rock star, Bono, and his investment group, Elevation Partners, owns about 40 million shares of Facebook. They made a very impressive 48 million bucks today. I would take that. Not bad.

Also making money today, a 67 year-old man in Orlando, Florida who just won his second multimillion-dollar lotto in two years. The Florida Lottery says James Boseman Jr. (ph) hit the jackpot for a three million bucks. Last year, he won 10 million bucks. He bought both tickets from the same 7/11. Fun fact. He didn't use the same numbers. In case you're wondering, the odds of a double win like that are about one in 196 trillion.

And not spending money, on the Fresno State Basketball team's opening game, everyone who's going. That's because Indiana Pacers all-star, Paul George, bought every single ticket to his Alma Matters first game. The "Fresno Business Journal" reports all George purchased all 15,596 seats at the Save Mart Center.

And season-ticket holders won't have to worry. They'll have the same seats for the game. It's the NBA star's way of giving back to his former college. And the low estimate for what it costs him, about $265,000. Though given that, he just signed a contract extension worth $90 million over five years, I guess, he can afford it.

That's all we've got for you. I hope you made MONEY today. You've got to watch tomorrow. Our money talker is all about how you should really dress for work. What about those short skirts and too tight dresses? How about the CEO who says women who wear high heels have no brains? Those are fighting words, and we are all over it. That is tomorrow. "The Willis Report" is coming up next. Happy Halloween.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60P0-KTT1-JBSJ-V2HS-00000-00MoneyGram signs remittances deal with Airtel Africa2020-08-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMoneyGram signs remittances deal with Airtel AfricaAlex hamilton

Airtel Africa customers to gain access to MoneyGram services later this year.

MoneyGram International has signed a new partnership with telecoms firm Airtel Africa to allow the latter's customers to revive mobile wallet payments.

The deal is due to go live later this year, subject to regulatory conditions.

MoneyGram says that customers funds are available "immediately" to pay bills or for services.

John Gely, head of MoneyGram Africa, says the partnership will "enable millions of consumers instant access" to the platform.

"We're excited about how this customer-centric partnership with Airtel will expand our mobile wallet capabilities, build upon our strong momentum in Africa, and further accelerate our digital growth across the globe."

MoneyGram has tied up several remittance partnerships this year, including with Al Rajhi Bank and Federal Bank.

Bloomberg reported back in June that MoneyGram is in the sights of rival Western Union. A bid has reportedly been made, but no decision finalised.

Western Union is not the first to eye up MoneyGram. Chinese Big Tech Ant Financial agreed to acquire it 2017, but regulators stymied a conclusion.

Raghunath Mandava, CEO of Airtel Africa, says the partnership is a "significant step forward" for his firm.

he adds that maximising access to global remittances is "a key part" of greater financial inclusion and empowerment.

Airtel Africa signed a financial inclusion partnership with Standard Chartered bank last week.

The bank and the telecommunications firm plan to create "new, innovative products aimed at enhancing the accessibility of financial services".

Related: Kenyan loans via mobile phones drop 50%, says KCB

urn:contentItem:5WN1-4971-F03R-N3C0-00000-00Money in Politics: Facebook, Amazon Set Records for Lobbying Cash2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMoney in Politics: Facebook, Amazon Set Records for Lobbying CashJoseph Vazquez

Jul 24, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook and Amazon set new records for lobbying spending in early 2019, according to recent disclosures.Bloomberg reported[1] July 23, that Facebook Inc. spent more than $4.1 million lobbying, and Amazon Inc.

spent more than $4 million in the second quarter. It further reported that Facebook'slobbying efforts in particular were the highest 'among big internet platforms, an increase from its previous high in the same period a year earlier.' It found Google's lobbying spending 'dipped' to $3.1 million in the second quarter.As The Hill reported[2] July 23, 'The surge in spending comes as Congress and regulators are scrutinizing tech giants' market power and handling of user data.' The federal government has Facebook and Amazon under major scrutiny[3] for potential antitrust violations as well as political bias and censorship of conservatives.'The FTC and the Department of Justice are also said to be conducting a review of tech companies' use of their market power that could potentially lead to an antitrust investigation,'The Hill continued.MarketWatch noted[4] Facebook 'lobbied on issues such as data security, privacy legislation, visas for high-tech workers, artificial intelligence, tax policy and the replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement.'It also reported that Amazon 'Lobbied on U.S. Postal Service reform, American tariffs, facial-recognition technology, cloud computing, music licensing, legislation affecting drones and many other matters.'Facebook is close to settling with the Federal Trade Commission over its mishandling of users' information in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Bloomberg reported that the FTC voted to fine it $5 billion and final details were expected within days.
