urn:contentItem:60YW-7FD1-F03R-N4J5-00000-00Month Ahead: Equity Winning Streak Ends2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:29ZLexisNexisMonth Ahead: Equity Winning Streak Ends

Oct 01, 2020( Action Reports: http://www.actioneconomics.com/info.php#Reports Delivered by Newstex) Month Ahead: Equity Winning Streak Ends By Ryan Brecht On September 30, 2020 Equities suffered in September, as lofty valuations came under fire from ongoing uncertainties even as economic data continued to support the recovery scenario. The lack of another round of stimulus in the U.S., a spike in virus infections in Europe and ongoing U.S.-China frictions weighed on equities. But not all the developments were downbeat, as the Fed, ECB and BoJ reaffirmed commitments to maintain accommodation for as long as it takes for a self-sustaining recovery to emerge. Vaccine development continued to progress, supporting optimism that the pandemic will eventually subside.

It will likely be another turbulent month for the markets in October, as investors continue to juggle the implications of the economic data, virus/vaccine developments and the upcoming U.S. election.News was mixed on the virus: Europe saw a spike in cases associated with the summer travel season, which prompted a return to stricter measures from some governments in the region. The jump in cases prompted worries in the U.S. that a similar scenario could play out this fall, hampering the recovery. Meanwhile, the development of a vaccine continued to make headway, with efforts by Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson in late stage trials. The total number of people infected in the U.S. topped seven million as of late September, and 203k having died of the disease according to John Hopkins data. U.S. stimulus hopes were resuscitated in the last weekend of September after Speaker Pelosi said "I believe we can come to an agreement," with the "we" referring to Treasury Secretary Mnuchin. She said she is ready to make a new "proffer" shortly. The agreement on a CR to keep the government running into the new fiscal year supposedly helped move the two sides to a deal, though they are still far apart with the Democrats wanting a $2.2 tln amount and the Republicans wanting a much smaller "skinny" package. President Trump has reportedly said he could support a $1.5 tln level. The big sticking points remain extra unemployment insurance and funding for state and local governments U.S. China relations remained tense, with Beijing undecided on green lighting an agreement to allow TikTok to become a U.S. based firm. In August, an executive order from President Trump forced the firm to sell its U.S. operations to a U.S. firm or be banned from doing business in U.S. A federal judge subsequently denied the implementation of the ban, leaving the ban and sale in limbo. While this is just one facet of the complex U.S.-China relationship, the enmity on both sides (each nation views itself as the aggrieved party on the TikTok matter) speaks to the low level of cooperation, which in turn lessens the upside for a sustained global recovery. FOMC: Flat Rate Path Ahead The FOMC further codified its lower-for-longer 0%-0.25% rate stance in its first policy meeting (September 16) since the framework review. The policy statement and SEP estimates took a circuitous and somewhat contradictory path to get there. There were two dissenters, Kaplan and Kashkari. Chair Powell said it wasn't surprising to see a range of opinions with respect to the new policy posture, and especially with the big changes in the economy due to COVID-19. Yet, the FOMC member forecasts showed a wide range of estimates for the economy, and a minority of members expected rate hikes despite low inflation estimates that suggested a low tolerance for inflation overshoots.There wasn't any real clarity from the policy statement or from Chair Powell's comments, where he tried to explain the new posture and strategy under the Framework Review. The markets were fully priced for a dovish stance, and they got it in spades as the FOMC underscored its lower for longer rate stance. The Fed is now "aiming" for an above 2% inflation rate for some time. However, the markets got a little more than they bargained for with respect to the dot plot, which showed several rate hikes in the future.The Congressional testimony from Fed Chair Powell and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin didn't reveal anything new or surprising. Chair Powell pushed back against comments that the Fed has "bailed out" banks and some other misconceptions about the Fed's actions, including backstopping corporate debt. Both Powell and Mnuchin did argue for more fiscal stimulus, with Mnuchin emphasizing a more targeted approach for kids and hard hit sectors and industries. The Treasury Secretary lamented the problems in the commercial real estate market and the inability to address them, though he and Powell are working on it. He noted there is some $134 bln in leftover PPP that could be repurposed. He didn't think the administration had the authority to act unilaterally to forgive loans of less than $150,000. The ECB meeting saw the bank remaining in a wait and see stance, with officials still firmly committed to the very expansionary monetary policy and the PEPP program. Lagarde suggested the PEPP is still expected to be used in full. While the "low for very long" message remains in place, there was nothing to suggest that the ECB is in fact preparing additional easing measures. On the contrary, Lagarde not only played down the importance of the negative HICP rate for August, but actually suggested deflationary pressures have receded somewhat compared to June. The meeting was a confirmation of the wait and see stance, with the ECB still committed to a highly accommodative monetary policy stance. The Bank of Japan remained pledged to do whatever it takes to support the recovery, as expected. Interestingly, the BoJ minutes highlighted that some council members are becoming concerned that virus developments will negatively impact the recovery. On the political front, PM Abe resigned due to health reasons. New PM Suga is expected to maintain policy continuity. Economic Trends The U.S. economic recovery continued, contrasting with fears in late August that a pick-up in virus cases and unwind of the CARES act would significantly sap momentum. Indeed, our estimate for Q3 GDP is tracking a 32.5% rebound in growth (q/q, saar) after the -31.4% plunge in Q2. The Q2 GDP data captured the powerful impact of mandatory closures, which left Q2 contraction rates of 20%-40% for most measures of demand, and larger 50%-65% declines for foreign trade. We saw a fifth consecutive quarterly inventory subtraction from GDP that left a record pace of inventory liquidation in Q2. The inventory plunge left considerable room for an inventory rebound into the end of the year.The shift in the U.S. national consumption basket has left demand for many goods and services well above the prior trend, but comes alongside a massive shortfall in demand for restaurant, travel, and entertainment services. Housing may be the starkest example of an industry that is now expected to function well above prior output levels. We still expect business fixed investment in the second half of 2020 to be depressed by weakness in construction of nonresidential structures as the commercial real estate market sorts itself out. Yet, it is noteworthy that many measures of aggregate activity have now more than fully reversed the pandemic-hit, and are setting new highs. In the Eurozone, inflation measures fell into negative territory. The HICP was confirmed at -0.2% y/y in the final reading for August, in-line with expectations. The sharp decline from the 0.4% y/y rate in July was largely due to special factors though, including the temporary cut to the German VAT rate and the delay of summer sales in some countries. Part of the negative inflation environment was also due to still low energy prices, which remained down -7.8% y/y, even if the measure has improved from the low of -11.9% y/y seen in May. Meanwhile, an increasing number of new infections have led to renewed travel restrictions, quarantine measures and regional lockdowns. Hence, concerns are on the rise that the still fragile Eurozone and UK recoveries will be disrupted. While we expect an 8.2% bounce in Q3 GDP (q/q, sa) after the -12.0% plunge in Q2, the market will closely monitor the data released through October for cracks in the recovery.Japan's core CPI remained negative in September, with government travel discounts largely to blame. However, inflation was subdued even without the discounts, and is well below the government's 2% target. Specifically, Tokyo core CPI contracted -0.2% y/y in September after the -0.3% drop in August. National core CPI fell -0.4% y/y in August after the flat readings (0.0%) in June and July. The measure fell -0.2% in both April and May and has not grown since March's 0.4% rise. Final GDP, released in early September, showed a -28.1% tumble in Q2 (q/q, saar), a slight downward revision from the -27.8% drop in the first release. The focus has turned to the magnitude of the expected rebound in Q3, which we've tentatively pegged at 14%. All eyes will remain on the monthly reports during October as GDP estimates are refined -- Q3 GDP is not due until November 16. China's economy appeared to further distinguish itself from the struggling global economy, although the global economy remains a potent source of uncertainty for China's export driven growth model. The official manufacturing PMI improved to 51.5 in September from 51.0 in August, notching the seventh consecutive month the index has been in expansionary territory after posting a record low 35.7 in February. The non-manufacturing PMI rose to 55.9 in September from 55.2 in August, marking the strongest reading since the all-time low of 29.6 in February and consistent with the ongoing strength in services. China was the only growing economy in Q2, rebounding to a 3.2% y/y growth rate after tumbling -6.8% in Q1. We expect Q3 GDP, due October 19 and sure to be scrutinized by the market, to improve to a 4.5% y/y pace.Market Developments Equities came under pressure through September, ending the remarkable rally that stretched to early September. Relentless uncertainty finally took a toll on investor optimism, as the lack of fresh fiscal stimulus in the U.S., pocket of rising virus cases stateside, and a rise in infections in Europe prompted fresh worries regarding the durability of the U.S. and global recovery. In addition, U.S. election jitters were thrown in the mix, with a rancorous first presidential debate seeming to add to the perception that the results of the election will be highly contested. Still poor U.S.-China relations remained a concern. In short, stock market valuations were challenged by still elevated uncertainty, prompting some profit taking though the month of September.The rip roaring rally on Wall Street peaked on September 2, with all three indexes sliding lower through the remainder of the month. The NASDAQ ended September -8% below its record high close set on September 2, having shot 76% higher from March lows to the early September peak as investors bet (correctly) that big tech would outperform in the pandemic economy. The S&P 500 reversed -7% from its all-time high seen on September 2nd, having roared 60% higher from March lows to the record-high closing level. The Dow dropped -6% compared to its September 2nd level (it was the best since March, but not an all-time high), trimming the 57% gain from March lows to the early September peak. After the losses in September, the NASDAQ was 62% above its March low, the S&P 500 was up 49% and the Dow was 47% higher. Meanwhile, modest declines were evident in Europe and the UK: the Euro Stoxx fell -2% by late September versus the end of August, Germany's DAX was off -1% and the UK's FTSE 100 dipped -1%. The gains relative to March lows were 35%, 52% and 18%, respectively. As for Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 was 0.2% firmer by the end of September compared to the last session of August while China's CSI dropped -5% over the same period. Longer dated Treasury yields eased lower into month end after perking up early in September, although the 10-year Treasury was confined to a relatively narrow range. The Fed's ZIRP and the further confirmation that rates will be at current levels for a long time helped anchor rates, while nascent inflation fears and a heavy supply outlook provided support. The 10-year yield moved lower to 0.645% as September came to a close after posting a month high (close basis) of 0.718% on September 4. Global sovereign yields were weaker as well. The German 10-year Bund fell to -0.546% from -0.400%. The UK's Gilt contracted to 0.193% from 0.334% in late August. The 10-year Japanese Government bond (JGB) slid to 0.009% from 0.048% in late August, having tested 0.0% late in September.WTI crude oil traded in a narrow range around the $40 level through September amid concerns over reduced global demand. The global demand for crude oil remains weak relative to pre-COVID levels, suggesting that crude oil prices will struggle to gain traction going forward.Demand worries weighed on the Reuters/CRB commodity index, as did likely profit taking. The index fell -4% to 147 by the end of September from its post March peak of 153 at the beginning of September. It bottomed out at 106.3 in mid-April as oil prices collapsed. Gold prices fell -8% to $1,897 by late September after posting a record high $2,063.55 in early August. Gold traded at $1,529 to begin 2020. Bank of England Looks into Negative Rates as Risks Mount Initially it seemed as though the BoE meeting would not offer up surprises with the central bank keeping all policy settings on hold, the statement suggesting that consumption is stronger than expected at the time of the August inflation report and the outlook for inflation slightly higher. That would back the wait and see stance that was the main message of the statement. The minutes, however, were surprisingly dovish, and showed that officials were briefed on negative rates. This reflected the high uncertainty over the outlook, with the balance of risks tilted to the downside and banks eager to be prepared for negative shocks, which at this point would also include a no-deal Brexit scenario. The main message from the BoE was no real surprise, and this confirmed the wait and see stance. The bank rate was left unchanged at 0.1% and the target for the total stock of assets was kept steady at GBP 745 bln. The overall message was that of cautious optimism on the outlook, with the BoE saying that high frequency data suggests that consumption is now "around its start-of-year level in aggregate, stronger than expected in the August Report." Investor intentions have remained weak but projections for GDP in this quarter are somewhat better than previously expected.The central bank did acknowledge that inflation fell from 1.0% in July to just 0.2% in August, but highlighted that this was mainly the result of temporary factors relating to the Government's Eat Out to Help Out scheme and the cut in VAT for hospitality, holiday accommodations and attractions. While inflation is expected to remain below 1% until early next year, the statement still highlighted that the trajectory until then is slightly higher than expected last month. So at first glance it was a slightly less pessimistic statement, even if the statement also highlighted that the number of paid employees has fallen by around -700K between February and August and that there is still considerable uncertainty on how the labour market will fare once government job support schemes unwind. This also means that there is still the risk "of a more persistent period of elevated unemployment than in the central projection." The BoE also warned that uncertainty remains very high, which means that it is unclear how informative data are "about how the economy will perform further out." Indeed, the statement highlighted that "the recent increases in COVID-19 cases in some parts of the world, including the United Kingdom, have the potential to weigh further on economic activity." The statement concluded that the BoE will continue to monitor the situation closely and "stands ready to adjust monetary policy accordingly to meet its remit." The BoE also promised that the Committee "does not intend to tighten monetary policy until there is clear evidence that significant progress is being made in eliminating spare capacity and achieving the 2% inflation target sustainably. In essence then a pretty similar assessment than Lagarde delivered last week. But what the statement did not mention is the fact that MPC members were in fact briefed on negative rates.However, like in the Eurozone, where comments from council members since the meeting revealed that there are at least some council members who are more uneasy about the outlook and seem to lean towards a further extension of the PEPP program, the BoE minutes also reveal a somewhat more differentiated picture. After the August Monetary Policy Report discussed the effectiveness of negative policy rates as part of the central bank's policy toolkit, the MPC was subsequently briefed on "the Bank of England's plans to explore how a negative Bank Rate could be implemented effectively, should the outlook for inflation and output warrant it at some point during this period of equilibrium rates. The Bank of England and the Prudential Regulation Authority will begin structured engagement on the operational considerations in 2020 Q4." So despite the slightly better than expected developments since the August meeting, the Bank of England is preparing for a worst case scenario amid heightened uncertainty. The elephant in the room that was suspiciously absent from the statement was the deterioration in U.K.-EU relations since the last inflation report. The minutes highlighted that the August inflation report was "conditioned on the assumption of an immediate, orderly move to a comprehensive free trade agreement with the European Union on 1 January 2021." If there was a discussions on developments it didn't make it into the minutes, which only said that the "Committee would consider economic issues relating to Brexit within the context of its wider forecast discussions ahead of the November MPC meeting".By then discussions on the negative rate will also have started, and the outlook on Brexit may be clearer. For now, it seems pretty much a repeat of last year, with Boris Johnson and his government moving on a confrontation course and going as far as threatening to break international law and go back on the already signed and legally binding Withdrawal Agreement with the EU. The government made a concession, however, by including an amendment to the domestic legislation which would now require a parliamentary vote in the event that the government wanted to invoke the parts of it that would break international law. That amendment alone is unlikely to placate the EU, and while there is still hope in some quarters that Johnson's moves are an attempt to get the EU to soften its stance ahead of the showdown at the leaders level in October, that would likely backfire, as developments will only harden the EU's demand to get legally binding agreements on state aid. And while the U.K. last week celebrated its first major trade agreement outside of the EU, the deal with Japan actually just about replicates the deal the U.K. would have had as an EU member. As the FT[1] highlighted, it also makes more concessions on state aid than the EU demands which, again, will only harden the EU's stance in future talks with the U.K. On agriculture, the U.K. didn't get any new quotas from Japan, but Tokyo conceded that for 10 out of 25 products covered in the EU-Japan deal the UK will be able to use any quota left over by the EU. What this means is that far from being able to make better deals outside of the EU, the U.K. barely manages to replicate those that would have been available as an EU member. And while there may be an agreement in principle with Japan, a no-deal scenario would not just leave the U.K. having to fall back to WTO terms with trade to its closest and most important trading partner, but also the vast majority of countries the EU has a trade arrangement with. Clearly that scenario would have a major impact on growth and inflation developments going forward. Investors were already discounting an expansion of the QE envelope before the end of the year and expectations that the BoE will eventually be forced to join the negative rate camp will clearly increase after the most recent statement. [ 1]: https://www.ft.com/content/1cb01980-ee86-4283-b25a-528c5b3b1807

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60HT-Y0N1-JCMN-Y3YY-00000-00Month Ahead: Uncertainty Re-Accumulates2020-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisMonth Ahead: Uncertainty Re-Accumulates

Aug 06, 2020( Action Reports: http://www.actioneconomics.com/info.php#Reports Delivered by Newstex) Month Ahead: Uncertainty Re-Accumulates By Ryan Brecht On August 5, 2020 Uncertainties both fresh and familiar challenged the markets in July, driving volatility in the stock market and pushing bond rates to record lows. However, as the month of August began, equities had again largely defied skeptics, although tech stocks were the clear winners while performance was mixed across other sectors. Fixed income richened in July after seeing modest cheapening in June, as worries over the second wave of the viral pandemic, U.S.-China frictions, the government's inability to pass a new U.S. stimulus bill and the whatever-it-takes policy commitments from the core central banks all weighed on bond yields. Market sentiment in August promises to again be whipsawed by a variety of factors, most notably the progress of the pandemic and the impact on the recovery.There was some optimism a U.S. fiscal package will soon be passed following weeks of wrangling in Washington.

At the time of this writing, there were small positive comments from negotiators, suggesting some progress. Senate Leader McConnell urged an agreement soon, but Republican Senator Perdue said talks could take two more weeks as the Democrats are not "negotiating in good faith." There is still a wide divide on the big issues including the total size of the package, the extra unemployment benefits, evictions, and funding the Postal Service. President Trump has indicated he'll go it alone on the payroll tax cut if he has to. The relationship between the U.S. and China continued to deteriorate. In July, the U.S. ordered China to close its consulate in Houston. China retaliated by ordering the U.S. consulate in Chengdu to close. TikTok has been the latest source of friction, with President Trump pushing for U.S. ownership of the U.S. operations of Chinese firm BytDance's popular video sharing app. On a positive note, the U.S. and China will hold high level talks on August 15 to discuss China's compliance with the bilateral trade agreement signed early this year, reported the Wall Street Journal. Talking is preferable to silence. While some U.S. states reversed re-openings (California did so on July 14), there has been good news on the pandemic. The leading candidate vaccines are reportedly making rapid progress towards final approval and mass distribution. There are well over 100 other vaccines in development. There was encouraging news on the treatment front, as biotech company Synairgen reported what is being touted as the best treatment so far. There is data showing that the novel SARS COV-2 coronavirus is not the apocalyptic event that was feared in March. Fed: Now Triple Not "Thinking About" Raising Rates The FOMC remains fully committed to its accommodative stance. Although there were no changes in terms of the 0% to 0.25% rate band, QE, or hints on forward guidance at the July 28,29 meeting, Chair Powell made it perfectly clear that the very accommodative monetary policy posture will be maintained for a long time. In fact, Powell even tripled down on that notion, stressing "we're not even thinking about thinking about thinking about raising rates," adding one more "thinking about" to June's statement. That highlighted the Fed's concerns over the economy and employment due to the pandemic and the willingness to keep accommodation in place until policymakers are "very confident" the support is no longer needed. The Fed is hoping for the best in terms of a vaccine but is planning for the worst.There were few changes to the policy statement versus June. Chair Powell cited in the presser the high frequency data that were reflecting a slowing in the recovery. The path forward for the economy remains "extraordinarily" uncertain, he said. He repeated several times the sentence from the statement that the "path of the economy will depend significantly on the course of the virus." Much will depend on a vaccine. The number of COVID-19 cases has risen sharply, he worried, and said he is seeing signs that it is weighing on the economy. The Fed is "totally focused" on providing the economy the support it needs, and the economy will likely need the highly accommodative policy and the use of our tools for an extended time. "We're absolutely committed to staying in this until we are "very confident" the support is not needed.The ECB effectively switched to a wait and see stance at the July 16 meeting, with the initial fire-fighting stage of the pandemic response apparently over. That doesn't mean monetary policy won't remain supportive -- Lagarde tried to calm fears that the central bank may not use the full PEPP envelope while stressing that the central bank will remain on standby. Meanwhile, later in the month, the EU struck a fiscal deal and implemented a EUR 750 bln recovery package. The BoJ kept policy settings unchanged, as expected, while predicting a sharp decline in economic activity during the current fiscal year, although less than the bank's worst case scenario in April. BoJ Governor Kuroda assured that the bank won't hesitate to do whatever it takes if necessary. Economic Trends An historic -32.9% contraction in GDP (q/q, saar) was a highlight of the U.S. data docket in July. GDP dropped -5.0% in Q1. The details of the report were dismal as was widely expected, with consumption plunging -34.6% versus -6.9% in Q1. Fixed investment plunged -27.0% from Q1's -6.7%. Inventories subtracted -3.98% versus -1.34% previously. Exports dove -64.1% from -9.5% (was -9.0%), while imports dropped -53.4% from -15.0% (was -15.7%). Net exports added 0.68% versus 1.13% previously. The chain price index dropped -1.8% from 1.4%, and was the weakest since 1949, with the core rate sliding -1.1% from 1.6% (was 1.7%).With the BEA's figures for the record-decline in Q2 GDP released, we are in a better position to calibrate the record-bounce likely to be reported for Q3. Note that a large rebound is already in place even if the economy doesn't grow at all between July and August, given the climb already booked into June and July from the April bottom. We do expect a continued uptrend in consumer spending through Q3 however, though at a much more moderate pace, and a substantial rebound in trade following an out-sized Q2 hit for that sector. We anticipate a 29.0% rebound in Q3 GDP. The bottom line is that the recovery is continuing despite relentless uncertainty over the virus and government containment measures. Of course, there is always the proverbial "other hand" when making economic projections -- high frequency data suggest that the economy may have lost some momentum during July.In the Eurozone, the preliminary Q2 GDP numbers confirmed a sharp contraction in activity, highlighting that even with the emergence of a modest expansion it will take a long time to reach pre-crisis levels of activity. The first estimate of Eurozone Q2 GDP showed activity contracting -12.1% (q/q, sa). National GDP rates varied along the lines of virus developments and depending on the extent of lockdown measures. Spain saw a -22.1% (q/q, sa) GDP plunge, Italy was down -17.3% (q/q, sa) and France fell -13.8% (q/q, sa). Germany, where lockdowns were not as severe as in other Eurozone countries reported a drop of -10.1% (q/q, sa). The second consecutive contraction left overall Eurozone activity down -15.0% y/y in Q2 after a -3.1% y/y loss in Q1. While the results for Q2 were dismal, the report was not surprising. The focus is on Q3, where we expect a 8.2% (q/q, sa) rebound for Eurozone GDP, supported by the easing/ending of lockdowns and massive fiscal and monetary stimulus measures. Japan's economy contracted -2.2% in Q1 (q/q, saar) according to the final GDP report for the quarter that was released at the beginning of August. The Q1 contraction was widely expected and should give way to a -30.0% plunge in Q2 (the report is due in the middle of August) as Japan's economy suffered from the virus and containment measures. The easing of containment measures and re-opening of the economy should lift GDP 15.0% in Q3. China stood out as the only growing economy in Q2, rebounding to a 3.2% y/y growth rate in Q2 after tumbling -6.8% in Q1 to mark the worst quarterly performance since the mid-1970s. The bounce in China's Q2 GDP performance of course contrasts with the declines seen in the U.S., Eurozone and Japan during Q2, and left China with only one quarter of contraction compared to the back-to-back GDP losses evident elsewhere. It remains an open question if China already saw the best of its rebound in Q2, given that global activity remains well below pre-pandemic levels. Factories are widely reported to have returned to full production, though the consumer sector is holding back following the big hits to income and employment in Q1.Market Developments Risk-appetites waxed and waned through July as a variety of factors impacted. Most prominent among those factors was the sustainability of the recovery coming into question as virus cases saw a resurgence in the U.S. and in some other regions. U.S.-China trade tensions provoked worries, while the lack of agreement on another U.S. fiscal package added to the ongoing list of concerns. A very dovish Fed prompted reflection on risk-appetite. There was more good news on the development of a virus and on therapeutics. Underlying the market's moves has been aggressive central bank and government measures to support the financial system and cushion the blow to the economy from the lockdowns. These measures produced a tidal wave of liquidity that had to go somewhere -- Wall Street and other stock markets have been the destination. Corporate earnings for Q2 gushed forth in July, with results running the gamut across industries. Big Tech earnings were very strong, propelling the NASDAQ to fresh record highs.Wall Street stumbled in July, but ultimately moved higher thanks to the leadership of Big Tech stocks, which added to already impressive gains following strong earnings results. Broadly, an acronym soup continues to provide at least a partial explanation for the remarkable run-up from March lows that seemingly flew in the face of dismal fundamentals -- TINA (there is no other option), MOMO (momentum) and FOMO (fear of missing out) have made the rounds as likely explanations for the bull run in stocks. Whatever the reasons, the fact remains that equities have conquered and surpassed the wall of worry that appeared to present an insurmountable barrier in the panic saturated days of March. The NASDAQ rose 8% by early August compared to the beginning of July, the S&P 500 was up 6% while the Dow was down -3%. The Dow was still 44% above its low of 18,591.93 on March 23, which was the weakest level since 2016. The S&P 500 has climbed 48% relative to its nadir in late March. The NASDAQ was up a stunning 59% over the same time frame, notching fresh record highs. Muted gains were evident in Europe -- the Euro Stoxx 50 rose 1% relative to early July, leaving a 36% rise versus the March low. Germany's DAX added another 3% in July, making a 49% rebound from March's low. The UK's FTSE 100 eased -2% lower in July, trimming the gain from March's low to 21%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 improved 2% in July, leaving a 36% climb from March lows. China's CSI 300 rallied 12% in July, leaving a 35% gain relative to March. Treasury yields richened, touching all-time lows to begin August, with the exception of the 30-year bond. The decline in rates came despite the run-up on Wall Street. Treasuries garnered a bid on momentum plays, uncertainty over the fiscal situation, and signs of an economic slowing from some high frequency data. Also, still lofty levels of uncertainty about the pandemic and the economy have kept a strong safety bid in play. Treasuries continue to be viewed as the safest asset, providing still ample demand for U.S. government debt securities.The U.S. T-note fell to 0.5102% in early August from 0.677% at the beginning of July. Global sovereigns saw yields move downwards through July. The German 10-year Bund eased to -0.51% from -0.40%. The 10-year Japanese Government bond (JGB) held near zero, running at 0.0% by early August after perking up to 0.03% early in July. The UK's Gilt eased to 0.074% from 0.21%. The WTI crude oil price surged from the end of April to late July supported by the combination of inventory draw-downs in the U.S., global production cuts, and an improving demand picture as economies have re-opened. The contract rose to $40 by late July (close basis) from $19 at the end of April. WTI crude fell to essentially zero by the middle of April. But the contract was stuck around $40 to $41 range in July as the market mulled still weak demand and a possible increase in supply from OPEC.The Reuters/CRB commodity index improved 6% to 148 by early August from 139 at the beginning of July, leaving a 39% expansion relative to the 106.3 low seen in mid-April as oil prices collapsed. Gold saw a year and record best $2,052 in early August, up 16% from $1,770 in early July. Gold traded at $1,529 to begin 2020. EU and Eurozone Look Stronger After Aid Deal The compromise deal on the EU's recovery fund and the medium term budget is a compromise that manages to gloss over the cracks, without really solving the bloc's underlying problems. The key questions on debt mutualisation and accountability are still being kicked down the road -- yet with a political union of 27 nations with very different political agendas and national economic realities, intricate compromises may always be the best one can hope for. Overall, it helped bolster confidence in the EU and the monetary union, which will go a long way to ensure a recovery from an economic crisis that could have been the end for the ambitious European project. The European Commission proposal for a recovery fund that had topped up the German-French proposal of EUR 500 bln worth of grants to member states by an additional EUR 250 bln in loans had already supported peripheral bond and stock markets. That Germany appeared to realize that this isn't the time for austerity policies helped to boost confidence, especially as Merkel didn't seem to insist on the type of economic reform conditions that were attached to the bailout funds in the wake of the financial crisis. The "troika" of ECB, European Commission and IMF that watched over the implementation of what critics claimed were brutal austerity policies, didn't make a comeback. So, even if the balance of grants versus loans was altered in the final compromise -- only EUR 390 bln of the EUR 750 bln total now coming in the form of cash handouts and the rest as low interest loans -- the move was welcomed by the ECB and hailed as a game changer.German Chancellor Merkel may have turned softer in what looks like her last term in office, but she could also afford to be more "generous" in her proposal because it was clear from the outset that other countries would fly the flag of caution. Indeed, Netherland's Prime Minister Rutte in particular emerged as the opponent of unconditional cash handouts, partly due to domestic pressure as he is facing a general election in March next year. Italy and the Netherlands also represent very different business models, with government debt amounting to just 48.6% of GDP in the Netherlands last year, compared to nearly 135% of GDP in Italy. Without the ECB's extremely generous monetary policy and the backing of the EU, Italy would face a sharp rise in refinancing costs, rather than heading for record low yields. At the same time, however, private sector debt in the Netherlands is nearly 300% of GDP compared to 155% in Italy. That partly explains why the Netherlands is such a strict opponent of public sector debt mutualisation and unconditional cash handouts, especially as Italy still struggles with the type of structural reforms that would be needed to put the economy and public finances on a more stable footing. The compromise cut back the grant part of the package and Rutte, while failing to secure a veto on payments, managed to at least establish a "super emergency break" that allows the delay of payments subject to the review by EU leaders and under the oversight of the European Commission. Rutte also insisted on a clause that will try to get countries to adhere to the EU's rule of law, which seems to be directed mainly at countries like Poland and Hungary, who seem to be flaunting EU rules on issues such as the freedom of press and the independence of the judicial system.This "emergency break" looks a bit like the stipulations laid down in the Stability and Growth pact and may not be particularly effective in the end, but it is enough to feed the charges of the right wing Eurosceptics in Italy, who vehemently opposed the idea of national economic plans, even if the Commission stresses that they will be nothing like the austerity policies demanded under the bailout agreements. Still, Salvini, leader of Italy's far-right League, warned that the Commission will demand reforms that will damage Italy. The leader of the far-right Brothers of Italy party meanwhile warned that the deal leaves the country at risk of "an unacceptable takeover of economic-political decisions of a sovereign nation". These comments highlight the problem, showing that what Italy is looking for is not a joint fiscal policy, which would actually transfer more of the decision making to Brussels, but unconditional cash handouts without any obligations to answer questions on how the monies are spent. That, however, would only further postpone urgently needed reforms, which Italy already avoided by not taking bailout grants during the financial crisis and instead relying on the ECB to buy Italian debt and keep yields low. With the ECB's pandemic emergency program allowing the ECB to more specifically target spreads, and the prospect of sizeable cash handouts from the EU, Italian debt clearly has been one of the main beneficiaries also because the EU's recovery program will be financed through jointly issued debt, which some see as a real game-changer and the first step towards full debt mutualisation. However, in our eyes that is pre-mature -- indeed, this is not the first time that the EU has issued debt. Like the bailout funds, the new wave of EU bond issuance is conditional and clearly focused on a specific purpose. Most importantly, it comes without cross default clauses -- that means individual member states won't become liable if the EU should sink and default. Having said that, the EU's presence in markets will greatly increase now, and with EU debt rated triple A by two of the three big agencies, it will increase the pool of assets the ECB can choose from and make it easier to stick to the capital key condition in its purchase program.Together with the already existing programs, EU market borrowing is estimated to amount to EUR 980 bln by the end of next year, still less than any of the big three, but roughly the size of Spain's bond market. Yields are likely to look more attractive than Germany's and, together with ECB demand, this should secure a good take up. Not quite the secure highly liquid asset EU debt could become if the political situation would finally allow the pooling of debt, but from a market point of view an interesting step in that direction. Confidence not just in the EU, but also the Eurozone project has strengthened and the ability to relatively swiftly (by EU standards at least) agree to such a sizeable and ground-breaking package will go some way to strengthen the unity of the union. That in turn should discourage those in the U.K. that had hoped the united front presented in Brexit talks so far would crumble thanks to the recession and the longer term fallout from COVID-19. However, much of the cross border trade between the U.K. and the EU was due to globalisation trends and real-time supply chains running across Europe. COVID-19 has already sparked a rethink in many quarters and a renewed focus on production capacities closer to home. Hence, the U.K. will remain an important trading partner and clearly one the EU would like to have a deal with, but not one that would undermine the integrity of the single market or allow the U.K. to enjoy the benefits while at the same time setting itself up as a low tax, low regulation competitor on the EU's doorstep.

urn:contentItem:5YCD-KVK1-JCJY-G0ST-00000-00Monzo boss warns Open Banking reforms have 'zero benefit';"The positive effect of Open Banking on innovation has been nil," Tom Blomfield said2020-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:28ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:1Monzo boss warns Open Banking reforms have 'zero benefit'"The positive effect of Open Banking on innovation has been nil," Tom Blomfield saidBy Matthew Field

The UK's efforts to implement Open Banking have had zero positive impact on innovation in the banking sector, Monzo founder Tom Blomfield has warned.

Mr Blomfield cautioned that the flagship regulation, which was supposed to crack open the software of big banks and make it easier for consumers to switch services, has failed.

"The positive effect of Open Banking on innovation has been nil," Mr Blomfield said. "I don't see any businesses based on Open Banking in Europe whatsoever."

Announced in 2016 and introduced from 2018, Open Banking was designed to make it easier for consumers to pick and choose services from banks and rival fintech start-ups.

Banks would have to open up their software so rivals could plug in their own apps and products and make switching simpler. The CMA dubbed it a "revolution".

But Mr Blomfield remains unconvinced. "It is imposing massive costs on challenges like ourselves to implement standards nobody uses," he said.

Repeateddelays from big banksto implement Open Banking standards have left start-up executives furious at the lack of progress. Meanwhile, the tools built by banks to implement the rules to make their data accessible are clunky or fail to work as planned, critics say.

The Monzo boss went on to criticise consumer credit reforms, brought in by the Financial Conduct Authority, which forced his company to change its 50p per day overdraft charge, instead bringing in an interest-based charge.

A CMA spokesman said there were 200 providers making Open Banking products and 1 million using the services.

Mr Blomfield is the latest tech boss to caution the CMA as it expands its efforts to reign in technology giants. The regulator has grown increasingly aggressive in investigation acquisitions and investments by big tech firms in the UK.

The Monzo founder told the panel acquisitions offered a "virtuous cycle" for new founders to launch start-ups and "it is quite rare that an acquisition offer is accepted unwillingly".

This week, CMA chief executive Andrea Coscelli defended the regulator's investigations, which include a phase 2 probe into Amazon's $575m investment into UK food delivery start-up Deliveroo.

Mr Coscelli said: "The claim seems to be we should not investigate. But you think of the importance of Amazon, you would expect the average consumer would want to be satisfied these acquisitions are good for consumers.
